mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means announce.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means chapter.
Look at all those little things sticking out. You could easily use it to comb your hair.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means ten thousand.

You put your hat on the ground and a flag in your mouth. You're letting the world know that they can use your mouth as a warehouse. Your gullet is open for storage business. Need to store some ice cream? Please use my mouth warehouse. ;D ;D ;D

You stand with another woman and, with your fingers, adjoin yourselves together. You are united, you are one. Look around you. Other women are adjoining their fingers and standing with you. There's hundreds, no, thousands of you standing together.
mnemonics.reading: All of the women who are now adjoining together are in sets (せつ). Sets of two, of course. One woman with another woman, standing in unison. Picture a bunch of women protesting together. They're holding hands in sets, adjoined together.

mnemonics.meaning: A leaf has to do the same task again and again. Grow out of a tree, change color, fall to the ground, get absorbed back into the tree, then start all over again. Picture all of the tasks a leaf has to do in its lifetime again and again.
mnemonics.reading: Once again the leaf picks up a saw (さ) and cuts itself off of the tree at the end of fall, like some kind of invincible cyborg (さい). Picture a leaf sawing itself off of a tree. Then picture it again. Now picture Bill Nye pointing to it and saying, "This leaf is a cyborg. See how it has little robot parts, allowing it to do this again and again?"

mnemonics.meaning: There once was an animal with an insect friend who felt very alone unless he was around. An animal and an insect are an unlikely pairing, but these two get along delightfully and hate to be alone without the other. Imagine this animal and this insect. Let’s say it’s a flea and a dog. Imagine them going everywhere together. To the park, getting ice cream, even the drive in movie theater. They’re inseparable.
mnemonics.reading: One activity that the animal can never do alone is solve Sudoku (どく) puzzles. The insect always has to help him out with them, and together they are an unstoppable Sudoku solving team. Picture this animal with the insect on his head doing a Sudoku. See the insect hopping around on the animals head shouting answers and suggestions into the animal’s ear. How cute.

mnemonics.meaning: On the grass near a rice paddy sits a creeper that is some sort of a dog beast, a vicious animal. This creeper isn’t just a normal dog, it is more beast-like, more like a feral animal than domesticated pet. Picture this beast creeping, low to the ground, in the grass around the rice paddy. It's got its eyes on you. Uh oh.
mnemonics.reading: The beast is guarding its precious jewels (じゅう), which it buried in the grass or the rice paddy somewhere. If you don't want the beast to think you're coming to steal those jewels, you better keep your distance. All beasts have something they're trying to protect. In this case, it's some beastly jewels.

mnemonics.meaning: You take some flowers and some fruit and you make a cake out of it. It’s a very nice looking, flavorful cake. The fruit makes it taste great and the flowers make for great cake decorations. Look at this cake you have made. It’s majestic. Now taste some of it. It is one great tasting cake. Imagine yourself eating the best cake in all of ever.
mnemonics.reading: You’re standing back, admiring your cake when you hear a car (か) engine revving and before you know it your cake has been run over. The car came out of nowhere and ran your cake right over, spraying fruit cake bits and flowers all over the place. Stupid car! Hear the roar of the car engine as you get splattered in the face with the cake. Wipe it off of your face just in time to see the car speeding off into the distance. Also, recall that this kanji shares a reading with the similar kanji, 果.

mnemonics.meaning: They say using a measurement device (like a ruler) is a good way to chastise someone. They do something bad? Chastise them by slapping their wrists, their feet, their eyes, ears, anything! They say something out of turn? CHASTISE THEM! Imagine being chastised with a measurement device. Think how horrible it would be getting hit on your knuckles, your nose, or the back of your head. It would be awful. Imagine this experience.
mnemonics.reading: You're being chastised because you tried to say something in English in とうきょう. Everyone around you slowly turned around, eyes aflame and rulers in hand, ready to chastise you for uttering those forbidden words. How could you say something in English while you're in とうきょう?! After you went to all the trouble to learn all this kanji and Japanese? Geez, we almost think you deserve to be chastised...

mnemonics.meaning: The old winter is to blame for today's circumstance. It is the reason things are bad now.  Imagine a poor, broken town. And, imagine the mayor of a town telling their people that things are bad because of that bad old winter. "It's to blame for our circumstance!" he yells.
mnemonics.reading: In reality, this circumstance was actually caused by a single 子 (こ), though. This kid went through town, destroying everything in their path. Imagine your kid character walking through town, using their super powers to destroy buildings and rot food.

mnemonics.meaning: Your new car doesn’t mix well with the other cars in your garage because its color is in stark contrast to the others. All of your other cars are pristine white in color, but this new car is a mix of lots of colors. It almost looks like a peacock or something it’s so colorful. Such a contrast. Imagine this garage of yours with a sea of white cars. Now there is a new car that really sticks out like a sore thumb. Imagine yourself looking out over your cars and seeing this wacky car practically jumping out at you.
mnemonics.reading: What did I say this car looks like? Oh that’s right, a peacock (かく). This car looks like a peacock. It’s the color of a peacock and you’ll look like you’re peacocking when you’re out on the town driving it. It really is such a stark contrast to like, every other car out there. See yourself driving around in this peacock car. Hear the engine purr as strangers jeer and yell at you. This car sure does get a lot of attention, doesn’t it?

mnemonics.meaning: In your warehouse you use your knife to create. You keep old pieces of wood in your warehouse, and you use your knife to carve them into new things that only you could create. What do you create in your warehouse? Picture all the different things you could create in your mind.
mnemonics.reading: When you create it's good for your soul (そう). It's so freeing, in fact, that when you get really into your creating, sometimes you'd swear your soul was floating a little bit outside of your body. But every time you notice, it sinks back down. Hmm. When you create something your soul is happy! It's good for you, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: "A scooter!" you announce. You are announcing this because you decided this is what you would create. Imagine being at a maker's contest. Each person has to announce loudly what they'll create, then they have to create it.
mnemonics.reading: But, a scooter has been created before. What is different about yours? The scooter you will create is specifically designed to keep zombies (ぞう) busy.  Imagine the scooter you created with a zombie on it. It's a perfect place for the zombie to get stuck and scooted off into nowhere.

mnemonics.meaning: The "Cliff of Ten Thousand Power" is where you go if you want to be encouraged. If you can get to the top of the cliff, it will use its "ten thousand power" to encourage you.
mnemonics.reading: When you get there, it does encourage you. The cliff says "Hey, I encourage you to buy a ray (れい) gun." A cliff is encouraging you to buy a ray gun for some reason. This is not the encouragement you expected, but it is encouragement nonetheless. You go back down the cliff and immediately buy a ray gun.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami that is white, traveling in the direction of winter is a fierce and violent force of nature. This white tsunami is chasing after winter, and that’s why the tsunami is white—it’s a winter tsunami. It’s the most fierce and most violent kind of tsunami in existence. Imagine this white tsunami, more violent and fierce than any other tsunami you’ve ever seen, coming toward you. It’s very frightening. Feel the cold wetness it brings to your skin.
mnemonics.reading: The tsunami is too fierce, too violent, and before you realize what's happening, Gecki (げき), your beloved gecko, is lifted up and carried off into the air. "Geecckkkiiiiii!!!" you scream in horror, as he's thrown about by the fierce, winter tsunami. You have to close your eyes. You can't watch Gecki go.

mnemonics.meaning: The fortune radical and the fortune kanji are exactly the same! But it also means occupy as well, so don’t forget that. Fortune and occupy both occupy the same radical. Just remember that this kanji also means occupy and you’ll be just fine.
mnemonics.reading: To occupy some free time you have, you go and get your fortune told at a fortune teller. Your fortune is that you’ll have an encounter with a centaur (せん) in the near future. Just then you realize that the fortune teller is actually a centaur! The fortune has come true! Imagine getting your fortune told by a centaur fortune teller. Do you trust this mythical beast to know your future? Watch him manipulate his crystal ball as his hooves stomp the ground beneath him.

mnemonics.meaning: There's a building standing in the way of the next chapter in your life, and it's hindering you. It's not like you couldn't find another way around, but it's definitely inconvenient. Picture this huge, tall building standing directly in the way. You peer around the other side and there is a book floating in the air that says "Chapter 5: Success and Happiness." Dang, you really want to get over there to that part of your life.
mnemonics.reading: Someone put this building here specifically to hinder you. They knew you were close to the next chapter of your life, and they wanted to hinder you really good. And there they are, sitting on a throne smirking. It's the Shougun (しょう). The Shougun wants to hinder you and your life. He wants you to have to work harder so you become better, faster, and stronger than anyone else. Hindering you is his way of making sure you don't take the easy way out in life.

mnemonics.meaning: Your ego... it's totally out of control. I mean, my ego isn't out of control. I'm the greatest. That's me. But your ego? Ugh, so out of control unlike my amazing ego. Just keep going with this sentence about the ego. You can't stop, because really it's your ego that's out of control. That's I when you're saying it.
mnemonics.reading: I am the greatest in the world! I am no baby like you, that's why. A baby who says "ga (が) ga ga ga!" You're just destroying the ego of that other guy. "Why?" you ask? "Because I am the boss here. And you are the baby. Ego things."

mnemonics.meaning: A loitering mountain king in the winter is an indication or sign of something to come. We don't want to focus too much on what the indication / sign actually is, though, because it will take away from the indication part (which we want to remember). So, focus on the fact that this is some kind of indication that's important, but you don't know what that indication means or is... because we'll use that with the reading.
mnemonics.reading: When you spot a loitering mountain king in the winter, you know it's an indication that soon Mrs. Chou (ちょう) will appear. It's like a Groundhog's Day kind of situation, but instead it means Mrs. Chou is about to come out, perhaps early for the season. Imagine an announcer watching the loitering mountain king, "There he is... and it's still winter. We all know what that means. It's a sign that Mrs. Chou will be coming out of hibernation soon." Then, you can imagine her bursting forth from the mountain, running down her street.

mnemonics.meaning: There are fingers reaching towards you asking you to accept to instruct them. They're the fingers of students. And you're the teacher. See them reach out for knowledge. They want to accept this knowledge into their hearts and brains. Instruct them! Picture yourself instructing a class full of knowledge hungry little kids. They reach out with their fingers to accept the truth you bring to them.
mnemonics.reading: "Yes! I will instruct you, my dear students!" you cry, "I will instruct you on how to open a small juice (じゅ) box!" That's right. These little kids need help learning how to open small juice boxes (small because kids are small). Picture yourself instructing little kids how to punch the straw into small juice boxes. Hold it right-side-up! Don't squeeze too hard! Don't punch it through the other side! No! Don't bite the box! Instructing is hard!

mnemonics.meaning: You loiter around your master until he departs on a journey. You have a lot more freedom to do things after your master has departed, so until that time you just loiter about looking busy and staying out of his way. Picture yourself loitering around your master’s fancy mansion. You’re pretending to dust things off, but you’re actually just waiting for him to depart on his journey.
mnemonics.reading: Finally, it's time for your master's journey and he calls to you and says, "You are the 王 (おう) of the house now. Take care of everything while I'm gone." Your master has departed! You are the 王 now!

mnemonics.meaning: You hold gold fins in your mouth while shopping for pencil lead at the store. This pencil lead store only accepts gold fins as payment, but your fins don’t fit in your pockets and you need your hands to carry the lead so the gold fins go in your mouth. Imagine having these gold fins in your mouth. Taste the metal as your tongue runs over them.
mnemonics.reading: You pay for your lead but the cashier puts it in your mouth where the gold fins were and... everything ends (えん). Lead poisoning, huh? What a way for everything to end...

mnemonics.meaning: A broken car sits in a building. You need to get rid of it, so you put it in the mail. Or, depending on where you live, maybe you put it in the post. You just put some postage on it and watch the mail carrier take it away like any other piece of mail.
mnemonics.reading: Who did you address this broken car mail (or post) to? You sent it to the youths (ゆう) of the world.  You figure youths don't have cars anymore, so they could use one. Ugh, youths these days and their ride share apps.

mnemonics.meaning: In a gold cross, you see a needle sticking out of it. The needle is right in the middle of the gold cross. If Jesus were on there, the needle would be sticking him right in the chest. Picture this golden cross in your head. Why do you suppose there’s this needle stuck in it? You try to pull it out but you can’t. Envision yourself straining, trying to get the thing out.
mnemonics.reading: You're about to give up on the needle when it pops out and flies directly into your shin (しん). Ouch! Now you're desperately trying to pull the needle out of your shin, but it really won't budge this time. Maybe you should have minded your own business. Imagine a needle sticking into your shin. It hurts a ton. How would you try to get it out?

mnemonics.meaning: If you see someone loitering around with horns on their head you'd be correct to obey and accompany them. First of all, this could be really fun. Second of all, if this person is a demon or something, you should really just obey them or they could curse you. What's the worst that could happen?!
mnemonics.reading: If you obey the horned man you'll end up with a ton of jewels (じゅう)! You stole those jewels together and now you're an accomplice for accompanying him! You better hide those jewels!!

mnemonics.meaning: On the moon, it’s easy to turn a pig into pork. The low gravity of the moon makes the whole process much easier and cost efficient. Soon, all the pig farming will be done on the moon and there will never be a pork shortage ever again. Imagine going to a pig farm/restaurant on the moon. You’re in a space suit, eating some space pork. It’s delicious. Imagine the best pork you’ve ever had. This is better than that.
mnemonics.reading: At this particular pig restaurant, they have a secret ingredient that goes onto their pork. Lots and lots of butter (ぶた). Okay, so it’s not that big of a secret. But boy is it delicious. Mmm, butter. Butter and pork. A match made in heaven! Imagine yourself scarfing down this buttered pork by the pound. You’re stuffed, but you have to eat more. It’s soooo gooood.

mnemonics.meaning: You loiter around a black hole, waiting for it to finish destroying and switch to restore mode. You were told all black holes finish eventually, and when they do you can press a button to restore everything back to the way it was. Imagine loitering around near (but not too near!) the black hole waiting for it to finish so you can restore the galaxy.
mnemonics.reading: Finally there's nothing else for the black hole to eat so you hit the restore button.... but nothing happens. "Oh f**k (ふく) you!" you scream as you realize you were lied to. Maybe if you yell f**k you enough things will be restored. Ha. No. Everything's gone and it's your fault for being gullible.

mnemonics.meaning: During a tsunami, your lip ring is ripped off while you’re trying to cross a river. There was no other path to safety, you had to cross the raging river, but you lost your footing and smashed your face on a rock and lost your lip ring. Imagine how painful this would be, having your lip ring ripped from your lip. It would hurt a lot. Touch your lip and imagine missing half of it. Yikes.
mnemonics.reading: But why were you trying to cross this river anyway? Well your car (か) was on the other side of it, and you figured if you could get to your car you could outrun the tsunami and be safe. Too bad you fell and ripped out your lip ring though. Imagine yourself fording the river, all wet and cold from the water. Keeping your eyes on your car, you move slowly across. Look at the car. Look at it!

mnemonics.meaning: You keep all of your shellfish under a roof down the street and it's your savings. Shellfish used to be used as money way back, and these aren't shellfish you're spending, they're ones you're saving up for later. Imagine walking down the street to deposit more shellfish into your special savings and gaze happily at the huge pile you keep far enough away that you aren't tempted to spend it.
mnemonics.reading: When you want to withdraw from your savings you force yourself to use chopsticks (ちょ) to pick up the shellfish. They're especially slippery, hard to use chopsticks too, that way it's really hard to take too much out of your savings. Imagine trying to lift up a shellfish with a pair of smooth chopsticks. It slips right out. Ugh! I guess that's good though, because it's a savings for a reason (you shouldn't be spending it)!

mnemonics.meaning: You take this comb, break the handle off, and use it to stamp your official seal of approval onto a document. It's kind of a messy marking process, but it gets the job done. Imagine breaking and bending a comb so you can use it to stamp your seal onto things.
mnemonics.reading: You need this seal to stay at an inn (いん). All inns require official paperwork, so you had to improvise and make a seal on the fly. Hopefully the inn accepts this seal... or you aren't going to have a place to sleep tonight. And it kind of just looks like you dipped a comb in ink and pressed it around on some paper.

mnemonics.meaning: You're trying to use your fingers to cause a landslide so you have to shake the earth. You probably won't succeed, but the best you can do is to shake your hands on the dirt as hard as you can. It looks like you're trying to wave at the ground now. Imagine shaking your fingers at the dirt. Do you think you can shake the dirt hard enough to cause a landslide (spoilers, no).
mnemonics.reading: You think you finally got the earth to shake but when you look down it's just your shins (しん). Darn you shins, I thought I made some progress. Hey wait... why won't you stop?! Imagine your shins shaking, your hands are waving, and they won't stop. No! You shouldn't have tried to start a landslide. This was a bad idea!

mnemonics.meaning: There is a head pinned to a tree by a knife. This person has been stabbed! They were stabbed so hard that they were pinned to the tree here. Imagine how much force you would need to stab someone to have the knife and go all the way through them and pin their head to a tree. That's a lot of force.
mnemonics.reading: You want to know who did the stabbing, so you look around to see if the stabber is still in the area. But all you see is a sheep (し). Sheep can't stab people, right? They have hooves and probably can't pick up knives... right? Imagine getting closer to the sheep and seeing blood on its wool. You squint your eyes and see some knives strapped to its back. Even closer and you see a little sign around its neck that says, "Hello, I'm the Stabbing Sheep." Uh oh.

mnemonics.meaning: In a hole, you see a big guy who looks like he wants to stab you. You don’t want him to stab you, so you make sure not to fall into the big hole that houses the big guy that wants to stab you big time. Look at this hole – it’s like, super big. The guy is really big. They’re terrifying enough on their own, but put them together and you’ve got a big problem. You feel very afraid of this hole and getting stabbed. Just don’t fall in, okay?
mnemonics.reading: You fall in the big hole. What did I just tell you not to do!? He’s totes (とつ) going to stab you for sure. Totes. This big guy inside the big hole is totes going to stab you. Why did you fall in?? Feel the big guy press you up against the wall of the hole as he begins to stab you repeatedly.

mnemonics.meaning: You see a soul floating around a tombstone acting suspicious. To be fair, if a soul is going to be anywhere, a tombstone is probably high up on the list, but this one seems like it's doing something weird. Imagine inching closer to this suspicious soul floating around a tombstone. What do you think it's doing?
mnemonics.reading: You sneak around the tombstone to see what this suspicious soul is doing, and you realize it's pretending to kayak (かい). The soul is sitting behind the tombstone, in a small kayak, moving its arms like it's rowing through water. Even more suspicious, the soul seems to be holding a kettle (け). Considering the soul is already dead, this doesn't seem like something it will need. Picture a suspicious, kettle holding, kayaking soul. The afterlife may be more interesting than you thought.

mnemonics.meaning: The tsunami going down your dry face is just sweat. Sweat really does feel like a tsunami though. Wow, it's dry and hot out right now!
mnemonics.reading: The sweat isn't just on your face, it's also dripping down your ass (あせ). The one place you wish sweat wouldn't go, but somehow it always does: the ass.

mnemonics.meaning: Out of bamboo, you make a brush – a writing brush. This is no ordinary brush, mind you. It is a brush specifically designed for writing elegant characters. And it’s made from bamboo! Imagine yourself using this bamboo writing brush. Do you know many kanji? Of course you do! Imagine yourself writing them all with this nice writing brush. It’s actually fun to write things with it!
mnemonics.reading: Once the writing brush hits (ひつ) that paper, it’s like you transform into a totally different person. All of a sudden you’re a master calligrapher, writing anything and everything in a most beautiful fashion. Once that brush hits the paper, it’s on! Imagine the sound the brush makes when it hits the paper. It’s a bit of a plop, and then kind of a scratching sound as the brush bristles move around. Really focus on this sound that the brush makes when it hits the paper.

mnemonics.meaning: The actions he took as well as the particular circumstance is what caused this accident. It all aligned too perfectly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ひき逃げ事故のせいで、買ったばかりの牛肉が挽き肉になった。
Due to the hit-and-run accident, the beef he bought became ground beef.

mnemonics.meaning: Needle medicine is when you stick needles into people to cure them. This is done via an acupuncturist.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading for 針 and the on'yomi reading for 医. You haven't learned this reading for 針 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you do acupuncture and stick a bunch of needles in your back it's going to look really hairy (はり). Needles look just like metal hairs when they're coming out of someone. Just picture hairy little needles all over your body and you'll never forget this reading!

sentences: 針医の技術の進歩には驚くばかりです。
It’s amazing to think that acupuncturist techniques have come this far.

mnemonics.meaning: Again with that occurrence? That occurrence has now happened again.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that there's a い hiding in there!

sentences: 相手は、埋め立て計画に反対する請願書を再度持ってくるかもしれませんよ。
They may bring forward a petition against our landfill project again.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the adverb version of 再, so it shares the meaning again and also has the meaning once again.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Once again, you put a footer in your note because you can't remember the reading to this word because the mnemonic is so bad (sorry!).

sentences: もしできるなら、再び肘を舐めてみるべきだ。
If you can, you should lick your elbow again.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is different from the one you learned (this is kun'yomi). There's an easy way to remember it, though. 一人 and 独り share the same readings and mean almost the same thing. Just try to remember that this ひとり is used to emphasize solitude and independence.

sentences: 彼は独り住居だ。
He lives alone.

mnemonics.meaning: We waited an interval of time, and at each interval it was different. They're all supposed to be the same. Is there some kind of mistake?
mnemonics.reading: Take the reading of 間 (ま from 間に合う) and 違う and you'll have the reading for this word too.

sentences: 新しい市場に参入したことは間違いじゃなかった。
Expanding into new markets was not a mistake.

mnemonics.meaning: A person created item is artificial, not "real."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その外交官は人造人間十八号に刺された。
The diplomat was stabbed by Android No.18.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  A beast... what do you think of when you think of a beast? How about a thing (物, もの) full of fur (毛, け), aka a けもの (fur thing)? A beast is a fur thing, and in Japanese that's けもの. Punnnns.

sentences: あの男の人、獣のような目をしていて、恐いわ。
That guy has eyes like a beast. He’s scary.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are of the beast type or animal type are within the beasts and animals category.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 引越しを考えてるんだけど、どこも鳥獣類禁止ばっかりなの。
I’m thinking of moving, but just about everywhere prohibits birds and animals.

mnemonics.meaning: 違い is difference, so a big one of those is a big difference.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 違う plus 大 of 大きい (おお) put together. You can remember this because when you see the difference (the BIG difference), you say "oohhhhh" (お), because you were surprised you didn't see it before.

sentences: 堅い木の椅子と柔らかい快適な椅子じゃあ大違いだよ。
There is a big difference between a hard wooden chair and a soft cushy chair.

mnemonics.meaning: The act of alcohol creation is done via brewing and distilling.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ジムの会員権や食事だけではなく酒まで無料の特典として提供されるので、私はこの酒造での仕事が好きです。
I like working for this brewing company because they offer all these perks like free gym membership, free food, and even free sake.

mnemonics.meaning: Take your name and stab someone with it... using your business card. Your business card has your name on it. Also, you "stab" it at people who are willing to take it and read it. Not a real stab, but a metaphorical.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼が受話器に戻ってきて会社の住所を尋ねたので、名刺に記載されていることをお伝えしました。
He came back on the line and asked for our company address, so I told him that it’s on my business card.

mnemonics.meaning: It can carry a river. It's a canal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The か goes to が, probably while floating down said canal.

sentences: 冬には運河の上でスケートができますよ。
You can skate on the canal during the winter.

mnemonics.meaning: A special indication on something or yourself is a special characteristic. It's a distinctive feature that exists.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 優柔不断と事なかれ主義が彼の特徴だ。
His personality is characterized by indecision and immobilism.

mnemonics.meaning: A compare and contrast will give you a comparison of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 偽物のダイヤと本物のダイヤを直接比較してみれば、どっちがどっちだかすぐに分かるよ。
If you directly compare a false diamond with a real one, you’ll know which one is which right away.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of the kanji celebrate, so when you put a お before it to raise it up, it means congratulations! When someone has something to celebrate you should congratulate them.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

sentences: 引っ越しお祝いを渡さなくちゃいけないわね。
You have to bring a moving gift.

mnemonics.meaning: This company (会社) has done the ritual required to create stocks for their company. When a company has stocks, they become a corporation.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for everything here are the readings you learned with the individual kanji, though not all are on'yomi. This word is usually rendaku'd too, but sometimes you'll see the non-rendaku version when it comes to English language legal stuff, so keep that in mind.

sentences: トーフグ株式会社に電話を入れて、ファックスの送信がきちんと完了しているかどうか確認してくれる？
Can you call Tofugu Corporation to make sure the fax went through alright?

mnemonics.meaning: Your energy is ... well ... different. That's the nice way to put it. You're crazy, actually. WARNING: We're teaching you this word because it's used quite a bit still (especially online) and we want you to be able to understand it if you see it. But please keep in mind that this is considered to be a discriminatory word against people with mental illnesses, so we strongly recommend you do not use or direct this word toward anyone. Think of it like a really inappropriate swear word that makes you really uncool if you say it. Please!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 気 plus 違い.

sentences: この吹雪の中、パンツ一丁で踊るなんて、気違いにも程がある。
Dancing around in a snow storm in nothing but your underpants is just too crazy.

mnemonics.meaning: Create! Create! If you do this, you are doing creation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 神様は本当に人間を創造したんですか。
Did God really create human beings?
常に新たな創造を求められます。
We're always required to create something new.
私は、天地創造のを目の当たりにしました...というのはウソです。
I witnessed the Creation... okay that's a lie.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to  chastise you about this theory. When I do this, this is a debate. Doesn't it feel like you're being chastised when people are debating with you sometimes, especially with your own theories? I think so.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は給与削減と年金減額に関する討論に加わった。
I participated in the discussion about salary cuts and the reduction of pensions.

mnemonics.meaning: When one person is in a position to judge everyone alone by themselves, they're definitely a part of a dictatorship. One person should never be alone to judge everyone because that's how dictators are made and they're not so great.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あの会社では社長が独裁しているから働きたくない。
I don't want to work at that company because the president runs it like a dictatorship.
俺は世界一の独裁者になるんだ。
I’ll become the best dictator in the world.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to direct and adjoin the routes together. No more multiple stops. This is direct.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 君と彼が僕のベーコンを食べたって話は、彼から直接聞いたんだよ。
I heard that you two ate my bacon directly from him.

mnemonics.meaning: There is damage that hinders you from doing things normally. This is a disability.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 障害があることがバレて、内定が取り消された。
When it leaked out that I have a disability, the job offer I had was cancelled.

mnemonics.meaning: There are not any shakes or waves or anything fun like that. It is just pure dullness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私のCDはしばらく売上不振に苦しんでいたが、ラジオで紹介されてから今月は売上げが上昇しています。
My CD was suffering from a slump in sales for a little while, but since being introduced on the radio, sales are rising again this month.

mnemonics.meaning: You must obey your business. When you're in this situation, you've found employment through them, which is why you must obey them (if you weren't employed, you wouldn't have to listen to them).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ここの従業員たちは、大阪支店の従業員たちより楽観的なようだ。
Employees here seem to be more optimistic than their Osaka-branch counterparts.

mnemonics.meaning: Some fierce encouraging is what you need. Some encouragement!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: テレビ番組が放映された後、何百にも及ぶ激励の電話が、数時間に渡って掛かってきた。
After the TV show, hundreds of calls offering encouragement came pouring in for hours.

mnemonics.meaning: Create it and stand it up. This is your establishment, your founding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは、死ぬまでにトーフグ大学を創立するつもりだ。
Koichi intends to establish the University of Tofugu before he dies.
今日はトーフグの創立記念日なんです。
Today is the anniversary of the founding of Tofugu.
電車に乗り遅れて、会社の創立記念のイベントに遅れそうだ。
I’ve missed my train and I’m running late for my company’s anniversary event.

mnemonics.meaning: The first (第一) phenomenon is what's sealed into your head. This is your first impression of something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: オペレーターは、電話をかけてくださったお客様にとって、会社の 第一印象になるということを教えられました。
We were all taught that an operator is the first impression that a caller has of our company.

mnemonics.meaning: Although this has a い on the end it's tricky and not an adjective. The kanji is fortune, and the vocab word is fortune telling.
mnemonics.reading: I'm going to do some fortune telling on you... hmmm... I see... ohhhh... Looks like you'll be living on Uranus (うらな) in your near future, that will be $50. What a dumb fortune telling for $50, you definitely won't be living there, unless he meant your butt, then maybe.

sentences: 星占いによると、フグと私ってあまり相性が良くないみたいなんだよね。
According to the stars, Fugu and I aren’t supposed to have so much chemistry between us.

mnemonics.meaning: The only kind of writing brush you can use for ten thousand years is a fountain pen! All other pens run out of ink and then you're out of luck. But fountain pens can be refilled, making them work for pretty much exactly ten thousand years.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 万年筆を落とされましたよ。
You dropped your fountain pen.

mnemonics.meaning: The river pig is what's known as fugu or blowfish. That's the mascot for our best friend, the Tofugu!
mnemonics.reading: The reading makes no sense, really. Neither kanji readings work. But, if you remember that a river pig is a fugu, you can know the reading is ふぐ as well! YOU ARE A BLOWFISH, JESSE!

sentences: 「豆腐と河豚のサンドイッチをお願いします。」 「同じく。」
"I’ll have a blowfish and tofu sandwich." "I’ll have the same."

mnemonics.meaning: If you discuss the suspicious you're talking about something that may or may not be real. One of those things you could be discussing is a ghost story... you know that one with the hook?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アメリカで有名な学校の怪談はありますか。
Are there any famous school ghost stories in America?

mnemonics.meaning: Look at that suspicious beast... it's Godzilla, walking around looking suspicious. What is Godzilla? He is a giant monster.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: スーパーマンは、怪獣に数分遅れて現れた。
Superman turned up a few minutes later than the giant monster.
ワニカニって怪獣なの？
Is Wanikani a kaiju?
怪獣が私の白いスカートにどろをはねかけた。
The kaiju splashed mud on my white skirt.

mnemonics.meaning: An ice river is some ice that moves (very slowly) like a river. That is a glacier. In fact, many inlets and sounds were created with glaciers, because glaciers moved through them like rivers... not very quickly, though.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 氷 is the one you didn't learn. Think of the glacier coming slowly to your door. It rings your doorbell and says heyo (ひょう). Note that the か becomes が here.

sentences: 地球温暖化のために、毎年溶けている氷河が増えている。
The number of melting glaciers has been increasing every year due to global warming.

vocab: おたんじょうびおめでとう

mnemonics.meaning: 誕生日 is birthday. おめでとう is like "congratulations." So, congratulations for your birthday is like happy birthday!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 誕生日, so if you know that you know this!

sentences: 遅れたとしても、「お誕生日おめでとう」って言う方が言わないよりもいいよ。
Better late than never with saying happy birthday.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you remember:  It is I! Due to my ego, I love the Wii and no other gaming device. I love playing all the Wii-ware (われ) that's available, and everything else sucks.

sentences: 再度のチャンスを与えてもらえ、我にもなく泣いてしまった。
I cried in spite of myself when he gave me another chance.
我関せずって感じのアイツの態度、超嫌なんだけど。
I hate how he acts as if he doesn’t care.

mnemonics.meaning: The transport of things that enter your country are imports.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 兄の会社が輸入家具マーケットにビジネスに広げるのですが、私はそのプロジェクトマネージャーに抜擢されました。
My brother’s company is going to expand its business in the import furniture market and he chose me as the manager for the project.

mnemonics.meaning: Alone I stand. I have independence!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 会社を辞めて独立した人で成功した人は多くないって言うなら、そのデータやその人たちの計画、そしてどうしてそれが失敗したのかを示してくださいよ。
If you say not many people who left the company and went independent succeeded, show me the data, their plans, and how they failed.

mnemonics.meaning: Your person distinction finger is the finger you use to point at people to distinguish them from other people. This is your pointer finger... your index finger.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are all the kun'yomi readings of everything. The word 人, the word 差す, and the word 指. Take your time with this one, it's kind of weird.

sentences: 電気コードに躓いた時に、人差し指を切っちゃったんだよね。
I cut my index finger when I tripped over the electrical cords.

mnemonics.meaning: After an interval of time it will adjoin, but not right away. That is because it was being indirect.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 寝室用の落ち着いた感じのロマンチックな間接照明を探しているんです。
I’m looking for soft, romantic, indirect lighting for our bedroom.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fierce and violent? Fierce and violent! That's intense.
mnemonics.reading: What is fierce and violent? That old hag (はげ). Imagine her coming at you attacking you violently!

sentences: 時々、夜になると激しい不安を感じるの。
Sometimes at night I feel an intense anxiety.
コウイチのダンスはいつも激しいです。
Koichi's dancing is always intense.

mnemonics.meaning: The circumstance was caused by the idea I had. Because I had this idea before the circumstance, it shows I had intention of doing it. I did it on purpose.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチの秘密のベーコンを故意に食べた罪を認めます。
I plead guilty to intentionally eating Koichi’s secret bacon.

mnemonics.meaning: Our faces have adjoined in this one room to talk. You did the telephone interview where you didn't show the face of your face. Now you're showing it, so we can begin the real interview.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 面接の合否に関して、印刷物の郵送は行っておりません。
We don’t send out any hardcopy materials for the interview results.

mnemonics.meaning: It can hinder a child, but that's about it. This is a Japanese Sliding Door. They're often made of rice paper after all, so, you know, an adult can go through it but a child would be hindered by it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The 子 is changed from し to じ, though, so be careful.

sentences: 障子から差し込む光で、朝目を覚ますのが好きです。
I like being woken up by the sunlight filtering gently through shoji screen.

mnemonics.meaning: A river juvenile... not what you think. It's a kappa, a mythological Japanese creature. That being said, it lives in / around rivers and is about the size of a juvenile, so maybe this makes sense.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 河 makes sense. The reading for 童 however is weird. Since the meaning is "kappa" though you can use that to remember the reading as well. If you don't know what a kappa is do some research on the internets and figure out about them. It's interesting, and it will help you to remember this word.

sentences: まるで河童が存在していることを信じているかのようにリアクションしてもらえますか？
Can you react as if you believe Kappa really exist?

mnemonics.meaning: Create a garden? You'll have to know a lot about landscape gardening.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大学を卒業した時、造園会社から内定をもらっていました。
When I graduated from the college, I had a job offer from a landscape gardening company.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Lots of lead, all in bullet form. That's what it was like in nam, 'arry" (なまり).

sentences: 今日はすごくやる気が無くて、体が鉛のように重く感じる。
I’m so unmotivated today, my body feels as heavy as lead.

mnemonics.meaning: A lead pipe is a lead pipe. Don't hit people with this in the knees.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 水道の配管には、かつては鉛管がよく使われていました。
Lead piping was once often used in plumbing systems.

mnemonics.meaning: Lead poison is lead poisoning.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: かつてたくさんの歌舞伎役者が鉛毒中毒に苦しみました。
Many Kabuki actors used to suffer from lead poisoning.

mnemonics.meaning: The instruction business is when you give a lesson or class to someone.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 昨日病気で欠席したため、今日は授業の遅れを取り戻すために忙しい。
Yesterday I was absent from being sick, so today I’m busy trying to catch up with the lesson I missed.

mnemonics.meaning: Mail (or post) has convenience because it is sent for you in the mail (or the post!).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The reading of 便 (びん) in this vocabulary is an exceptional reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you out. You get a lot of junk mail so you throw it in the waste bin (びん). The waste bin is where junk mail goes.

sentences: おくさーん、郵便ですよー！
Madam, we have mail for you!
郵便業においては、効率とスピードが全てだ。
Efficiency and speed are everything in mail service.
こう空郵便で送るか、船便で送るかまよっています。
I wonder if I should ship this by airmail or sea mail.

mnemonics.meaning: The circumstance is that the thing you're using is a hinderance. Usually it's a help, but now it's out of order and has a malfunction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あのファックス機は故障中だよ。
That fax machine is out of order.

mnemonics.meaning: 管理 is "management." A management person is a manager.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 忙しい一日を終えて、管理人に「早く仕事を切り上げて帰りたい」という魔がさした。
After such a busy day, the manager was tempted to close up and go home early.

mnemonics.meaning: Manufacture and create. That is manufacturing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 織り物の製造元でアメリカで事業を拡張しているところがいくつかあるって聞いたんだけど、一体どうやって拡張してるのか知ってる？
I heard some textile manufacturers are expanding their operations in the United States. Do you know how they’re doing it?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same. This word means mark.
mnemonics.reading: You see a beautiful woman in front of you. She shows you a mark on a piece of paper. It's a mark that tells you she's Russian (しるし)!

sentences: 私は手紙の最後にハートの印を付けるのが好きです。
I like putting a heart mark at the end of letters.

mnemonics.meaning: When you read something in a different way from the way you're supposed to it's a misreading.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今日、超恥ずかしい読み違いをしてしまった。
I made the most embarrassing reading mistake today.

mnemonics.meaning: A person who is different from the person you thought it was is a mistaken identity. Whoops, sorry, I thought you were someone else. 人違い!
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 人 and 違い put together.

sentences: はい、私達も結合双生児ではありますが、申し訳ありませんがあなたは人違いをしていると思います。
Yes, we are also conjoined twins, but I’m afraid you are mistaking us for a different set of twins.

mnemonics.meaning: You are alone in what you occupy. Nobody but you occupies it. You have a monopoly. You monopolize it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: うちの家族の場合は、父がテレビを独占しています。
In my family’s case, my father monopolizes the television.

mnemonics.meaning: If you come across a suspicious thing it's probably a monster! Run away!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: この山には、心の優しい怪物が住んでいるという言い伝えがある。
Legends say there is a kind hearted monster living in this mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: The next month (来月) isn't enough... one more next month, please. Let's do it again. That month is the month after next.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 再来月に一週間の休暇が取れるんだけど、どこか一緒にいかない？
I have the vacation time to take a weeklong getaway the month after next so do you want to go somewhere with me?

mnemonics.meaning: When you obey orders people consider you to be an obedient person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: あいつは犬のように従順だ。
He’s as obedient as a dog.

mnemonics.meaning: You are alone in what you are able to create. Nobody else can create like you, because you have originality and creativity on your side.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼が独創性に欠けていることは非常に残念です。
It’s so disappointing that he is lacking in originality.

mnemonics.meaning: Your lead writing brush has lead in it. What kind of writing instrument has lead in it? How about a pencil?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: そのパグは、このHBの鉛筆で描いたんだよ。
I drew the pug with this HB pencil.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 上司に豚呼ばわりされて腹が立ったので、速攻で人事課に退職届けを叩きつけてやった。
My boss called me a pig and I was so upset that I immediately turned in my letter of resignation to the Human Resources department.

mnemonics.meaning: A pig's meat is called pork.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ランチに食べた豚肉に当たったかもしれません。すごく気持ち悪いんですが、早退させてもらえませんかね。
I might have gotten food poisoning from the pork I had for lunch. I feel so sick. Is it okay if I’m out of the office for the rest of the day?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When thinking about the circumstance of your current situation and the reason you're there (which is studying kanji and vocab). Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

sentences: 故あって、この製品のローンチが中止になりました。
For some reason, the launch of this product has been cancelled.
ここは火山が多い。それ故に、地震もよく起きる。
There are many volcanoes here. For that reason, there are often earthquakes too.
若さ故の過ちだったんだよ。大目に見てやろうじゃないか。
The mistake was down to his youth. Let's cut him some slack, shall we?

mnemonics.meaning: Again you build it. This is rebuilding.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

sentences: 潰れかかった会社を再建するまで、彼は毎日規定よりも長い時間働いた。
He worked longer hours than he was supposed to every day until he rebuilt his crumbling company.

mnemonics.meaning: Many times you restore something. You do this over and over for the recovery of this thing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: インターネットへの接続はまだ回復していません。
Our Internet connection hasn’t recovered yet.

mnemonics.meaning: Renew it by creating something anew. This is remodeling because you're creating something and changing something that exists already, renewing it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 言うのは恥ずかしいんですが、あの改造バイクに乗ってるのは私の兄です。
This is embarrassing to say, but the guy riding the modded motorcycle is my brother.
コウイチ総理には、内閣を改造する気はさらさらありませんよ。
Prime Minister Koichi has no intention of reshuffling his cabinet.

mnemonics.meaning: Again it is opening. This is the reopening or resumption.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just don't forget that extra い!

sentences: 警察は捜査を再開したそうだよ。
I heard the police have reopened the investigation.
戦争の再開条件は十分に満たされている。
The conditions for resumption of war have been fully met.
コウイチとビエトの交渉は、近々再開される予定だ。
Negotiations between Koichi and Viet will be reopened soon.

mnemonics.meaning: Restore what you learned with reviews. That's what you do on WaniKani, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 予習と復習はどちらも大切です。
Preparation and review are both important.

mnemonics.meaning: Your right arm is your right arm.
mnemonics.reading: The reading can either be a combination of the kun'yomi readings (more common) or the on'yomi readings (pretty uncommon, and only used to talk about sports players, especially baseball). That being said, you've seen all of these readings except う. Here's a mnemonic for if you want to remember う: Your right arm got pricked by a poisonous uni (う), and it has to be amputated. Hope you're not right-handed!

sentences: 奴の右腕には、龍のタトゥーがあるハズだ。
I think that’s supposed to be a dragon tattoo on that guy’s right arm.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same like the word 川 which has the same meaning. Associate the two to remember!

sentences: 毎日夕方頃、河の土手で犬を散歩させる。
I take my dog for a stroll along the river bank every evening.

mnemonics.meaning: Depart and then restore yourself back to your original departure spot. If you do this (departing and coming back) you have a round trip.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ここから大阪まで、往復でいくらですか？
How much is a round trip from here to Osaka?

mnemonics.meaning: Your savings gold is your savings. You'd be good to have gold right now in your savings, actually. Melt it down into bars, manngggg.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もし退職金が一括で支払われることになったら、それを使い切ってしまわずにちゃんと貯金することができますか。
If your retirement money was paid to you in one lump sum, would you be able to not use it and put it in your savings?

mnemonics.meaning: The second needle is the thin hand that indicates seconds on your clock. That's the second hand of a clock.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 腕時計の秒針が折れちゃってるの。
My wrist watch’s second hand has been broken.

mnemonics.meaning: If you preserve and don't hinder, you're providing security, you're safeguarding something. This word is used in contexts where the emphasis is on protecting from harm. For example, you'll see it in compound words like 社会保障 (social security) 安全保障 (security) and 人権保障 (safeguarding human rights).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本にはどんな社会保障がありますか。
What kind of social security is there in Japan?
明日は、国家安全保障会議に出席する予定です。
Tomorrow, I will attend the National Security Council.
学校で、基本的人権の保障について学びました。
At school, I learned about safeguarding basic human rights.

mnemonics.meaning: There is not any of I. It is all about everyone else. It is all about selflessness.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチはついに無我の境地に達した。
Koichi finally reached a state of selflessness.
自分に優しくない人は、他人に優しくなれないだろう。だから、自分を大切にすることこそが、無我なんだよ。
If you are not kind to yourself, you will not be kind to others. So, taking care of yourself is what selflessness is all about.
私は鮫に追いかけられて、無我夢中で泳ぎました。
I was being followed by a shark so I lost myself swimming for my life.

mnemonics.meaning: You are alone in your study. You are studying on your own. This is self study.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: インターネットの普及によって、独学で外国語を勉強することは昔よりもずっと簡単になった。
Due to the spread of the Internet, it’s become much easier to learn other languages through self-study nowadays.

mnemonics.meaning: Somebody who is alone is single or unmarried.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は独身で、婚活中です。とりあえずそんな感じですが、何か他に聞きたいことがあれば、遠慮なくご連絡ください。
I’m single and looking for someone I can marry. That’s really it for now. But please do not hesitate to contact me if you need any further information about me.

mnemonics.meaning: Cake is a child's favorite snack food. This word refers to all the junkie snacks you can imagine, candy, pastries and sweets, but also savory snacks too. You know, like chips and stuff... 🤤
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 小さい頃、お菓子の家に住むことが夢でした。
When I was a little, my dream was to live in a house made of candy.
甘くないお菓子だったら、ポテトチップスが人気ですよ。
For a snack that isn't sweet, potato chips are a popular choice.

mnemonics.meaning: You have all these little stabs that are very fierce on you. They tingle like crazy. This is quite the stimulation on your body. *tingle tingle tingle.*
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 周りに若い人が多いので、私も刺激を受けています。
Because there are so many young around me, it's stimulating for me too.
コウイチをこれ以上刺激しないで。何しでかすか分からないよ。
Don't encourage Koichi any further. You never know what he might do.
彼女には会ったんだけど、お互いにいまいちピンと来なかったんだよな。俺としては、もうちょっと刺激的な女性の方がいいっていうかさ。
I met her, but we didn't really hit it off. For me, I'd rather have a woman who is a little more exciting.

mnemonics.meaning: The location in the city where the stocks ritual takes place is the stock market. Just think of what happens in a stock market... the stock ritual, where people buy and sell stocks. And, of course, this is located in the city.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are all readings you've seen before - either from other words or from the kanji. Go through each kanji here and figure out which is which and try to remember. Just think of Joe (場) the stock broker for the last kanji.

sentences: 世界的な景気の減速は、私たちの株式市場にも影響を及ぼした。
The global slowdown has significantly affected our stock market, as well.

mnemonics.meaning: A suspicious incident (事件) always has a strange mystery behind it. It also always turns into a mystery case.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ホームズでさえもその怪事件の糸口を見つけることはできないだろう。
Even Holmes wouldn’t be able to find a clue to that mystery.

mnemonics.meaning: First you have to set up the structure of something to create it. This structure is important for the creation of everything, otherwise it would just fall apart.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今日はエッセイの構造とルールについて授業をします。
I’ll teach you guys essay structure and rules today.

mnemonics.meaning: You stab nature suddenly... why you do that? So suddenly, too... Now nature is going to die for sure!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 突然、猫のお化けが台所に現れて、「ニャーニャーソング」を歌い始めたんだ。
Suddenly the ghost of a cat showed up in my kitchen and started singing the mew-mew song.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of suspicious? Also suspicious!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you think of people who are suspicious or shady, you naturally think of people named Aya. Just think of our artist Aya, she's super suspicious and shady!

sentences: 彼女は同僚に比べて病欠が多いし、本当に病気なのか怪しいよね。
She takes more sick time than the other coworkers, so it’s suspicious whether she’s really sick or not.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same one you learned with the kanji. Also, your sweat smells like ass (あせ).

sentences: 彼の額は汗でピカリと光っていた。
His forehead was shiny with sweat.

mnemonics.meaning: If your sweat is smelly (臭い) you are sweaty-smelling, smelling of sweat, or smelling like sweat.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は彼の汗臭い枕が好きだった。
I liked his sweaty-smelling pillow.

mnemonics.meaning: A phenomenon of some kind that's an indication of something else is a symbol.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 鳩は世界共通の平和の象徴だ。
The dove is a worldwide symbol of peace.

mnemonics.meaning: If you teach and instruct then you are doing teaching. Who does teaching? A professor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その教授は、ファイルよりも書類整理箱を好んだ。
That professor prefers filing cabinets to digital files.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means replace, and this word means to be replaced, to be submitted, and to be switched. This verb is intransitive, meaning it doesn't take a direct object. You'll sometimes see it with the particle を, though, because the を is showing a "path" rather than a direct object in this case.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: ドラえもんの声優が替わってから、観なくなってしまった。
I stopped watching Doraemon after the voice actor was replaced.
今回の選挙で政権が替わることになりました。
The government will be replaced in this election.
もしご迷惑でなければ、席を替わってもらえませんか？彼女と一緒なんですが、席が別々になってしまったんです。
If it's not too much trouble, could you switch seats with me? I'm with my girlfriend, but we're seated separately.

mnemonics.meaning: When something attaches a burn to something that something is about to catch fire.
mnemonics.reading: This is the readings of 燃える and 付く put together.

sentences: 化学の実験をしている最中に、前髪に火が燃え付いた。
My bangs caught fire during a chemistry experiment.

mnemonics.meaning: 届く is "to be delivered." This word is when you're doing the actual delivering, making it to deliver. You can remember this because you care (ける) about the package so much that you deliver it yourself, thus doing the action of delivering it!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 届く and you can use that to deliver the memory to your brain.

sentences: 今夜お前のところに俺のパソコンと外付けハードディスクを届けるよ。
I’ll deliver my computer and external hard drive to you tonight.

mnemonics.meaning: 差別 is discrimination. This is the verb version, to discriminate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 誰かに差別されたことはありますか。
Have you ever been discriminated against by someone?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means encourage and the verb vocab version is to encourage someone (or to encourage).
mnemonics.reading: Think about encouraging a hag (はげ). She needs encouragement because she's a hag, and nobody likes her much because of that.

sentences: 落ち込んでいる人を励ますのは難しい。
It’s hard to cheer up someone who’s depressed.

mnemonics.meaning: If you pass a duty on to someone, that means you're going to entrust something to that person, or you're going to delegate something. In other words, you're going to leave something to them, so that they do it for you.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi of the kanji. You haven't learned that reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: In order to entrust something to someone, you need to make a (まか) list. It's no good delegating tasks if the person has no idea what to do, so be sure to make a list, okay?

sentences: この会社では、若い会社員にも重要な仕事を任せています。
In this company, even young employees are entrusted with essential tasks.
本当に大事なことなので、他の人には任せられません。
It's really important, so it can't be left to anyone else.
任せることを学ばなければ、自分が大変になりますよ。
If you don't learn to delegate, you'll make things hard for yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: You examine it but you also chastise it, because you want to make sure this examining is correct. This is to examine or to study or to look into. All require chastising things to be sure for sure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 分厚いノートパソコンから薄型タブレットへの買い替えを検討している。
We’re looking into replacing our bulky laptop with a slim tablet.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 輸出 is an export? This is the verb, so this is to export.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will also help to know the word 輸出.

sentences: 彼らはライオン、トラ、くまなどたくさんの動物を輸出する。
They export a lot of animals like lions, tigers, and bears.

mnemonics.meaning: 触る means "to touch." This means to feel. It's kind of similar but somewhat different and also uses a different reading, making this word very hard in some ways. Just think how it's rare (れる) for you to feel anything at all, but this time you are, so that's nice, I guess. The word also means to touch on, not in the physical sense, but when you touch on a subject. That's why it also means to refer to or to mention. It's worth mentioning that this word is most often used with the particle に, so it's intransitive in Japanese. However, you'll also see it with the particle を, in which case it's considered transitive. The English translations are usually transitive, too.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is totally different from 触る so don't let that fool you. In this case, you feel some fur (ふれ).

sentences: この車にはお手を触れないようお願い申し上げます。
Kindly do not touch this car.
その話にはもう触れないでください。
Please don't mention that topic again.
誰かが肩に触れるのを感じて振り返ったが、そこには誰もいなかった。
I felt somebody touch my shoulder and I looked back, but nobody was there.

mnemonics.meaning: You've seen how 燃やす is to burn something. Now something is just getting burned but you're not doing the actual action yourself. You know this because of the える part which refers to the letter "L" which is getting burned. You like L okay because it stands for "love," but others don't like it so they burn it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the word 燃やす.

sentences: 城は燃える木のにおいで充満しているようでした。
The castle seemed to be full of the smell of burning wood.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a really polite way to say "to give," probably because you're lowering yourself down and raising the item above your head so far that you have to point at it because if you were touching it you'd be defiling it anyways so, you know, point at it and raise it way up, you little worm on the ground.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 差す and 上げる put together, both hopefully words you know okay by now.

sentences: パソコンの動作を速くするのに役立つアプリケーションを無料で差し上げます。
I’ll give you this application that helps make your computer run faster for free.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means transit, but the vocab isn't quite the same. You are transiting one object over to another person (the word is to hand over), though, so it kind of makes sense. You see the す? You're suing somebody, so you hand over the papers telling them you're suing them. Don't confuse this with 渡る which is "to cross over." す is sue.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 彼が私にペンを渡してくれた時、胸がどきどきした。
When he handed me the pen my heart was pounding.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the verb version of hinder, but it's what happens when you hinder someone else enough. You'll start to irritate and to annoy them.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you want to irritate me, all you have to do is make what I'm eating sour (さわ). Did you know sour food is known to be bad for you, too? Don't make that sour face, stop eating sour things!

sentences: ごめん。気に障ったのなら、あやまるよ。
I'm sorry. I apologize if I offended you.

mnemonics.meaning: When you create something you make something. This type of creation is usually for large things (perhaps ships) that you'd want to manufacture so you can make a lot of them.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is like 作る, which means "to make." They have very similar meanings, but different kanji. Use 作る to help you to remember the reading of this word.

sentences: 私の最近の趣味は、手作りのビールを造ることなんですよ。
My recent hobby is brewing homemade beer.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means narrow, so the verb version is to narrow.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: You have to narrow the width of something. The only way you can do that is to sever (せば) off each end. Maybe you're trying to get a sofa up a tight stairway. The only way to do that is by severing off each arm to narrow it.

sentences: もう少しここの幅を狭めることはできますか？
Can you narrow the width a little more here?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means obey so the verb vocab version is to obey.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  I am going to obey you. I think your order is a bit of shit が (したが), I'll do it and obey you.  (Little side note, did you know が in the middle of a sentence can mean "but" in Japanese? Think of it as that meaning here.)

sentences: もし彼の命令に従わなければ、どうなると思う？
What do you think what would happen if I didn’t obey his orders?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means occupy so the verb version is to occupy.
mnemonics.reading: What is it you want to occupy most in the whole, entire world? Your own flock of sheep (し). Also, a fortune teller (this kanji also means fortune, remember) told you that if you occupy her sheep, you'll have good luck! Gotta do as she says!

sentences: トーフグがベーコン市場を買い占めるつもりだと聞きましたよ。
I heard Tofugu is thinking of cornering the bacon market.

mnemonics.meaning: You remember how 載る is "to be published"? This one is to publish, as in you do it yourself. You know this because you self (せる) publish, which makes it so you're able to publish something (no publishers would accept that rubbish about the vampires, sorry).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is shared with 載る, so as long as you remember that you can remember this.

sentences: 自分の写真をインターネットに載せるのには、ちょっと抵抗があります。
I’m a little uncomfortable publishing my own picture on the Internet.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means savings, so the verb vocab version would become to save or to put something aside. Basically, you're saving up, which is good to do, I'm told.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to save, so you take one (たくわ) and put it aside, then take another and use it. This way you will have saved at least half.

sentences: 大きなビジネスを始める前に、元手を貯える必要がある。
We need to save up some funds before we can start a big business.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shake and this verb is transitive, meaning that you're shaking something. So this verb means to shake something, to wave something, or to swing something. You'll often see it paired with 手, as in 手を振る, meaning "to wave one's hand" or, as we'd usually say in English, simply "to wave". This word can also be used when you shake someone off in the less physical way, as in to break up with someone.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Someone is trying to shake something. And unfortunately, that something is you. The most unfortunate thing here is that you're totally full (ふる), and you throw up because of the shaking (and you're full, gross!).

sentences: よく振ってから飲んでください。
Please shake it well before drinking.
コウイチは首をたてに振ったが、ビエトは首を横に振った。
Koichi nodded his head, but Viet shook his head.
「彼に振られたなんて信じられない。」「あんた、浮気してたんでしょ。自業自得だよ。」
"I can’t believe he broke up with me." "You cheated on him. You had it coming."

mnemonics.meaning: 過ぎる is to surpass... 過ごす is to spend time on... for some reason. I suppose if you surpass something or someone, you must spend time to do it.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 過ぎる. Time to surpass this kanji? Or, maybe it's time to spend time on it instead.

sentences: 電気料金の支払いが三ヶ月遅れて電気を止められちゃって、あのクソ暑い日をエアコン無しで過ごさなきゃならなかったんだ。
Our electricity stopped because we fell three months behind on our utility bill, so we had to spend the hot day without an air‐conditioner.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version must also be to stab.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to get stabbed, don't get stabbed two (つ) times. You can remember that this is the "two time stab" stab because it has a hole that's big. The hole is big because you got stabbed twice.

sentences: 「それじゃあ、いくらお金があれば幸せになれるっていうの？」 「う～ん。痛いところを突かれたな。」
"Well then, how much money do you need to be happy?" "Ah. You can really poke at my sore spots."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means stab so the verb vocab version is to stab. This is a transitive verb, meaning that you are the one doing the stabbing... should I be afraid of you? 😅
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to stab someone, use a saw (さ). It may seem more difficult to stab them with a saw at first, but when you see the damage, plus how hard it is to get back out, you'll realize a saw is the ideal stabbing tool.

sentences: 母親をナイフで刺したにもかかわらず、私はその夜熟睡した。
Although I had stabbed my mom with a knife, I slept soundly that night.
