mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means weave so the verb vocab version is to weave.
mnemonics.reading: When you have to weave the only thing you can weave is an O (お) shape. That's it. Just O's.

sentences: 私の母親は、最近手織り機でカーペットを織ることにはまっているんです。
My mother is very much into handwoven carpets lately.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means worry so the verb vocab version is to worry.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, so no need to worry about it.

sentences: 「どうしたの？何を悩んでいるの？」「昨日、彼女に振られたんだ。」
"Hey! What’s troubling you?" "My girlfriend dumped me last night."

mnemonics.meaning: You've been led astray and you've been misguided. What a trouble and annoyance all this is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本語が下手なので、あなたに迷惑をかけてしまうかもしれません。
I am bad at Japanese, so I might be an inconvenience to you.

mnemonics.meaning: You are trying to research the extremes. If you do that, you'll be able to figure out the ultimate weapon. Just researching the safe middle-ground stuff won't get you ultimate. Extreme research, however, will.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの榊氏までもが、私が宇宙の究極の原理を解明したことに祝いの言葉を述べてくれました。
Even Mr. Sakaki congratulated me on finding out the ultimate fundamental truth of the universe.

mnemonics.meaning: We're cut right down to the end, reaching that urge position where urgency and pressure are so strong.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The せつ of 切 gets shortened to a small っ. The はく becomes ぱく.

sentences: ヤクザからお金を借りなければいけないという切迫した危機に直面している。
I’m facing an imminent crisis so I need to borrow money from the yakuza.

mnemonics.meaning: Your salary fee are the moneys you get for your salary. These are your wages and pay.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「君の上司が、君の給料を上げるつもりだって聞いたよ。」「まさか！そんなことあり得ないよ。」
"I heard your boss is going to give you a raise." "Really? That’ll be the day."

mnemonics.meaning: You stick an umbrella with a big slide on it into the mountainside to make your barracks. You're going to use these barracks to teach soldiers how to slide slides and hide from bad weather. It's ingenious!
If you were to look at a giant from above, this is what you would see. Do you see the head and two arms? The giant is facing towards the right.
I don't know what this thing is, but it's lovely. It has two eyes, a funny mouth, and a scraggly beard. It's lovely, and nothing else, okay? So remember it that way.
A big lip ring is a pretty odd thing to have. If it's big, it'll stretch your lip out, which is odd too.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means specialty.

Construction in the winter leads to aggression. Just think about it. It's cold, it's unpleasant, and you don't want to be there. So, you start to develop an aggression towards other people working with you on this winter project. Imagine yourself walking through the winter construction site, taking out your aggression on anyone you see. You hate this winter construction!
mnemonics.reading: You're taking your aggression out on everyone. Then, the sexy construction worker from WaniKani Level 1, こういち, walks by without a shirt on. You take out all your aggression on him. "Aggression" is going to depend on you, so you should imagine a scene where you take your aggression out on こういち, whatever that entails. Hint: When you see 工 in a kanji it will often take the こう reading.

mnemonics.meaning: If someone is coming toward you in a car, holding a weapon in their hand, they're going to attack you! Picture the car, weapon out the window, preparing to attack you full force!
mnemonics.reading: Right before the attack begins, you recognize the hand holding this weapon and driving this car. It's Gecki (げき), your long-lost gecko who you may or may not have let fly off into a really fierce tsunami. Oops. I think he may be here attacking you out of revenge. Gecki is attacking you now. He's hitting you over and over with his tiny car. He's yelling and smacking your ankles with his weapon. And all you can do is wait and let the attack happen, because you know you deserve it.

mnemonics.meaning: After a tsunami, you find an axe on the ground next to some fins on the beach. The tsunami was pretty violent, and it looks like this axe got blown into some fish and cut off their fins and now those things are just on the ground by the beach. See these things on the beach. It makes sense to see fins, as fins are usually in the ocean, so seeing them on the beach is logical. Pick up the stuff you find as you feel the beach sand between your toes.
mnemonics.reading: Walking down the beach a bit more, you also find a hammer (はま). Gosh, looks like the tsunami hit a workshop or a hardware store or something. First the axe, now a hammer. Pick up the hammer in your hand. It’s pretty heavy. The tsunami must have been very strong to pick up such a heavy hammer.

mnemonics.meaning: This thread is odd, but that's what makes it beautiful. It's a little frayed, it's a little miscolored, but that's what makes it appealing to you. If something is a bit odd, it's usually beautiful in its own way, just like this beautiful thread.
mnemonics.reading: You take this beautiful thread and lock it up with a key (き). You want to keep it all to yourself, you want its beauty to be for your eyes only! To remember that there's a beautiful thread hidden away, you tie a not-as-beautiful thread to the end of the key.

mnemonics.meaning: There are some horns on the ground next to fins on a plate that are meant to benefit everyone. If you're a member of this town, one of your benefits is this little set up. You pick up the horns off the ground and put them on your head, then eat some fins off the plate. This is just one of many benefits to living here. You'll never go hungry!
mnemonics.reading: Another benefit is free 駅 usage! Whenever you come back home from places on the train, this 駅 is completely free. Okay, so using the 駅 is probably a better benefit than eating cold fins off a plate on the ground, but you take what you can get. They're all free!

mnemonics.meaning: Pointing your magic solar powered wishing stick at the sun, you attain the legs of a child. You’re old and want young legs to carry you around, so you took your wishing stick that’s powered by the sun, and you wished for the legs of a child. Imagine yourself getting new legs. Legs that belong to a child. They’re limber and young and full of energy! Feel your legs of a child underneath you!
mnemonics.reading: As you delight in your new legs, Jesus (じ) descends from the sky. “My child,” he says, “why have you pointed the stick at the sun and wished for the legs of a child? You were already perfect, just as all of God’s children are perfect.” Say back to Jesus, “I’m not your child Jesus! And you’re just jealous of my new legs! You wish you had the legs of a child, Jesus! Your legs are like super old!” Actually say this out loud, and remember how Jesus wishes he could be a child again too.

mnemonics.meaning: The roof protecting your life and the net protecting your heart are both protected by the constitution. The constitution makes it so that everything you hold dear is locked away, nice and safe on a piece of paper, and no one can change the rules or hurt you without your say so.
mnemonics.reading: Your country's constitution is being protected by none other than Ken (けん) the samurai, hero for hire. Picture Ken standing in front of your constitution. But keep a close watch, cause wily ol' Nic Cage is in the business of thievin' on constitutions.

mnemonics.meaning: You got your ice orders. Of course, your ice orders are to make things cool and cold. Making things cool and cold are pretty much the only orders you'll hear from ice. Ice is very simple in that regard.
mnemonics.reading: How will you make things cool and cold? You'll use a special ray (れい) gun that shoots a cold ray. Imagine a cold ray coming out of your ray gun. Anything it touches becomes cold. "Stay cool, bird boy," you say. Hint: when you see the radical orders it's fairly likely the reading will be れい.

mnemonics.meaning: A winter table would be an odd thing to deal with. Winter can be hard to deal with on its own, but turn your table into winter? Just dealing with your food getting cold would be the worst! Look at this winter table. How are you ever going to deal with it? Just think of your favorite warm food and then imagine it getting cold. Deal with it, dog.
mnemonics.reading: This winter table is something you have to deal with, sure, but what if you just gave it to a circus show (しょ)? They like weird stuff like this. Feel the relief of getting rid of this table. No more having to deal with it anymore. The circus show can have it.

mnemonics.meaning: You loiter on the mountain, reading off the numbers of pi on this winter morning. Everything is so perfect, so mathematical here. You view it as delicate. Not in the sense that it will break apart at any moment, more in the sense that there are smaller, more subtle things to be enjoyed on this mountain, which is why you loiter here doing math. You'll have to imagine the things you consider to be "delicate." Is that the snow falling on the branches? Is it the breeze? Is it something else? That's for you to decide, but imagine it vividly whatever it is.
mnemonics.reading: Ah! Of course! The delicate bumble bee (び), that is your epitome of delicate. It lands upon your finger, and you look at its every fiber of being. Picture yourself looking at the bee, thinking how each hair on its body is so delicate. Maybe it has a delicate aroma to go with it. A faint smell of honey?

mnemonics.meaning: A leader uses a stick in the winter made of hair to enforce discipline. The leader uses the stick made of hair to discipline his followers. He hits them with it. Imagine the leader disciplining his people with the hair stick in the winter. Imagine him yelling “DISCIPLINE!!” with each hit of the stick as you feel the cold winter air around you.
mnemonics.reading: If the leader uses a stick to discipline his followers, eventually they'll fight back. The disciplined masses start to take off their shoes (しゅう) and throw them at the leader! Watch as the leader gets pelted with all sorts of types of shoes. Boots, high heels, baby slippers. They're all colliding with him as the people shout, "Discipline solves nothing!"

mnemonics.meaning: You wear a great big cross on your chest and you attend a specialty exhibition for gambling. The big cross on your chest is your badge for being admitted into the exhibition. Everyone at the specialty exhibition has a cross, and everyone is gambling. Picture yourself at this specialty exhibition. Feel the weight of the cross shaped badge on your chest as you continue gambling at the exhibition.
mnemonics.reading: You’re not very good at gambling, but you are pretty good at cheating. You hack (はく) the specialty exhibition gambling machines to pay out lots of cash just for you. You hack quickly and quietly, so luckily no one notices that you’ve hacked the system. Hack the gambling machines. Imagine the sounds of the exhibition around you as you work to hack the machines. Look at the computer parts and cables as you work.

mnemonics.meaning: The Grain Mouth King pours grain from his mouth for you and his other subjects. You go to him and pull his finger. When you do this, grain pours from his mouth. But we were greedy. We didn't understand the extent to which we were harvesting his mouth wheat. Of course, you need to imagine pulling the Grain Mouth King's finger, to some extent. You can't just read what we write for you, without going to the imagination zone. Pull that finger real hard a couple times, and watch an extra large purge of grain pour forth.
mnemonics.reading: The extent to which we were harvesting grain from his mouth was too great. The Grain Mouth King has run out of grain. He worries he will lose power if he has no grain to offer, so he switches to barfing out tater (てい) tots instead. Imagine hearing the rumors that the Grain Mouth King ran out of grain, so you go check the extent of his failure yourself. But tater tots taste pretty good too. Imagine eating one of his mouth tater tots and go ahead and comment about it to him.

mnemonics.meaning: Sometime in the future, thread of every color will be faced with extinction. Eventually there will be nothing else to make thread out of, and thread of every kind and color will reach extinction. Imagine what the world would be like without thread. No thread of any color. How would you fix tears in clothes or make new ones? It would be a strange world where thread is extinct.
mnemonics.reading: The extinction of thread was brought on by a very strange thing. Deadly zits (ぜつ). These zits killed off all the producers of thread, and eventually the thread went extinct. Dang zits. Pretend you have deadly zits. They’re everywhere, not just your face. You can’t pop them or you’ll die, but they’re all bulging and extremely painful. Now you’re facing extinction. Lousy.

mnemonics.meaning: Ice from the east is frozen. Well, of course, all ice is frozen, but ice from the east is like, really super frozen. Imagine this super frozen ice from the east. You’ve never seen anything quite like it before. It’s so frozen, it’s like it was frozen once and then frozen again. Twice frozen. Feel the ice and how freezing cold it is. It’s super cold, guys.
mnemonics.reading: Japan is a country in the east, and this ice was frozen in とうきょう. とうきょう is really good at freezing frozen things, so it makes sense that this frozen ice came from there. Imagine being in とうきょう and seeing all this frozen ice. Hear people speaking Japanese all around you as you touch and feel the freezing twice-frozen ice.

mnemonics.meaning: The giant radical and the giant kanji are exactly the same! Massive!
mnemonics.reading: Just recently, a giant rampaged through Little Kyoto (きょ), so now it's even smaller than before. Poor Little Kyoto. See Little Kyoto after the giant rampaged through it. It looks even smaller and more pathetic than ever. Look at all the smoldering rubble and smell the smoke with your nose.

mnemonics.meaning: Only give grains to a turkey if it's immature. Adult turkeys should be eating healthier things, like insects and grass. But immature turkeys don't care if they get fat, so they whine and whine and whine until you give them grains. Imagine an immature turkey complaining at you until you give it grains. Now it's taking selfies with the grains and posting pics to Instagram and hashtagging them #GRAINLIFE.
mnemonics.reading: Another thing immature turkeys (and people) love is cheese (ち). Most of us non-immature people and birds still like cheese, but if you didn't have an immature cheese phase as a kid or teen, you won't be able to like cheese as a mature old person. Imagine a bunch of immature kids and turkeys eating cheese together.

mnemonics.meaning: Super poop is a super power you have in infancy. Those in infancy have the power to poop at will, whenever and wherever they please. Infancy poop power! Infants poop a lot. There's poop everywhere. The powerful aroma overwhelms you. Eww. Also refers to childhood, when you still have some of your poop powers, but they're already starting to go away.
mnemonics.reading: In infancy, one eats a lot of soft foods, such as yogurt (よう). Yogurt is the food item above all others that grants superior pooping power. See this infant gobbling up all the yogurt he can get his grubby little hands on. Soon, he begins to poop all over the place. Hear the infant screaming, "Goo-goo! Yogurt poop power! I'm a baby! Wahhhh!!"

mnemonics.meaning: You stick horns in the ground using them as spikes and you line up the horns in a straight line. Horns are pretty much the same thing as spikes once you stick them in the ground, and you line these ones up precisely for optimal protection. Imagine yourself lining up these horns in the ground. The spikes are sharp and you poke yourself with one. Ouch. Need to be more careful as you line these up.
mnemonics.reading: As you line up these horns and stick them into the ground, you notice a bull munching on hay (へい) nearby. It's staring at the horns you're lining up. Somehow it feels like it's munching that hay angrily. You gulp, looking at its horn as it grabs another mouthful of hay, and you feel pretty guilty. Imagine the hay in that bull's mouth as it chomps angrily, watching you line up horns in the ground. It probably wishes you were the hay.

mnemonics.meaning: If you know the radical meaning lovely, you know the kanji meaning lovely as well! You know what would make learning this radical lovely? Studying your radicals.
mnemonics.reading: "Lovely" is the name of my ray (れい) gun. It's more lovely than any other thing. Try to imagine feeling this way about your ray gun. It's so lovely.

mnemonics.meaning: The odd radical and the odd kanji are the same. They're both... really strange. Remember how odd this one is?
mnemonics.reading: You're odd too, just like this kanji. But you don't want anyone to know, so you lock away your strange habits with a key (き). You only give this odd key to people you trust, so they can unlock your odd secrets and see how odd you are deep down.

mnemonics.meaning: Blood and hair and tofu make up the populace. Those are the three categories the entire populace fits into, anyway. Blood shows that all the people are related. Hair shows that we're all humans. Tofu is food to all. So, as you can see, those three words describe the entire populace.
mnemonics.reading: The entire populace deserves shoes (しゅう). It's a basic thing all humans should have like flowing blood, hair (somewhere), and tofu to eat. If you see people in your populace without shoes, it's your job as a fellow member of society to help them get some!

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami takes life, cuts it like a sword through thread, and leaves everything behind completely pure. Everything is dead and gone, wiped clean off the face of the earth, thanks to the tsunami. It's back to the way it was before humans were here, it's completely pure. Picture the tsunami purifying the land of life, and in your mind see the sword cutting clean through the thread of life.
mnemonics.reading: After the tsunami pulls away, everything left is pure white. You hate this, so you run over and squirt ketsup (けつ) all over the place to make it not so pure. The area is SO pure that the ground absorbs the ketsup and now it's all pure... ketsup color.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami that's blue is pure. Some tsunami are other colors, like brown or red because they aren't pure, they'll full of trash and poop and other horrible things. But a blue tsunami is completely pure! Picture this pure blue tsunami. You can see every crystal clear drop of water in it.
mnemonics.reading: Seeing this pure blue tsunami inspires you to pull out your glowing blue saber (せい)! As the pure water comes toward you, you take one, long slash! SPLAASHH! The tsunami's pure water splits and it absorbed into your saber. Now it's pure too. And transparent!

mnemonics.meaning: A gold Wolverine swam in the water while his father made a record of it. Wolverine is gold in color because he just won the gold medal in swimming, so now he is gold. Way to go, Wolverine. See this gold Wolverine holding his gold medal after getting out of the water. His dad doesn’t want to forget anything about this precious moment so he makes a record of it. Imagine him scribbling furiously in his notebook.
mnemonics.reading: Since Wolverine is actually a mutant, he is soon disqualified from his gold medal. His father makes a record of this also. One angry fan threw a rock (ろく) at Wolverine afterwards. Then another threw a rock. And another rock. Before you knew it, everyone was throwing rocks at Wolverine. Wolverine’s dad didn’t step in to help though, he just kept keeping records. Imagine a pitiful Wolverine crying on the ground as each rock hits him. All he wanted was some recognition from his father. Poor guy. Imagine poor Wolverine like this as his dad just looks on and writes in his notebook.

mnemonics.meaning: Your scooter takes you to the barracks, drops you off, and then goes in reverse all the way back home in the opposite direction. Imagine riding your scooter to the barracks. It literally drops you on the ground when you get there, and then drives in reverse back the opposite way you came.
mnemonics.reading: Your scooter going in reverse and leaving you here is opposite of what you want. You want to ride it back home when you're done, so you stuff the wheels with Gak (ぎゃく). If you don’t know what Gak is, check out this Gak commercial. You Gak up the wheels so when the scooter tries to switch to reverse it gets stuck. Success! But now it can't go forward either. Darn you Gak, you tricked me again.

mnemonics.meaning: A grain, from one evening to the next evening, experiences a shift. After two evenings, the grain has shifted from one location to another. Picture the grain in your head with a time-lapse of one evening after another happening in the background. Slowly, the grain shifts.
mnemonics.reading: This shift is caused by the eagle (い) that wants to eat the grains. Every other evening, the eagle swoops down, shifts the grains (eating a few) and then flies off. Picture the eagle flying down on the second evening, scattering the grains it doesn't eat, shifting their location.

mnemonics.meaning: Rice that is blue has a strong spirit. Our spirits are blue, so if you ever see rice (or other food, or even people) that's blue, you know that's their spirit radiating out! Picture this rice, the pulsing blue spirit of each grain is glowing so bright!
mnemonics.reading: You want to see the spirit up close, so you take your saber (せい), throw the blue rice in the air, and slice it in half! The rice explodes and blue light fills everything! Then it's gone. As you release the spirits in the rice, your saber begins to glow blue too. Their spirits are going inside your saber, making it stronger!

mnemonics.meaning: This building has a pig with horns on it because it's our squad's place. Our symbol is the horn pig and we put it on everything to show the whole world our squad owns this turf. #SQUADGOALS
mnemonics.reading: Our squad also wears special ties (たい) with our horned pig on it. And we don't care if you think that's lame, because we're A FAMILY. Picture our squad. It's Koichi, Viet, the Crabigator and Tofugu. We're all wearing matching horned pig ties and walking toward you in slow motion, our squad building towering behind us with the pig smirking down at you.

mnemonics.meaning: A canopy is over your car because your car is in storage in a large warehouse. The canopy just protects your car from the elements as it sits in storage for long periods of time.
mnemonics.reading: Your car is in this storage warehouse, just sitting there. A 子 (こ) notices this, and decides to take your car on a joyride. You won't notice, right? You never drive it. Imagine a kid sneaking into your canopy to steal your car that's in storage. Maybe it's two 子s, one stacked on the other with a trench coat. One 子 works the pedals while the other 子 works the steering.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman is one of the few strange things in the world. Everything but a woman can be explained and made sense of. There are only a few strange things in this world, with woman being one of them. Imagine saying this to a woman. Try and imagine her face as you tell her how strange she is.
mnemonics.reading: But when you think about it, we're all a little strange. Me, you, myou (みょう) everybody! Who's strange? Me and you. Me, you - we are strange! Strange, strange, strange!

mnemonics.meaning: The gladiator in front of you draws his sword. He points the sword at your chest and right when you think everything is about to end, you realize he's pointing the sword at the ticket in your hand. Right! You needed to buy a ticket to see the gladiator! He doesn't want to kill you, he wants to check to make sure you bought a ticket.
mnemonics.reading: The gladiator happily marks your ticket with his blade, when Ken (けん) the samurai pushes past you. He holds up his own sword, challenging the gladiator, who just shakes his head and points at your ticket again. Ken takes a long time to examine your ticket. I don't think he understands that he needs a ticket to fight the gladiator. Maybe you should give him yours.

mnemonics.meaning: As a hat, four people holding a cross use an umbrella. The umbrella is big enough to be a hat for all four people, so it makes sense. All four of them are religious missionaries, so that’s why they’re holding the cross. See these four people all under one umbrella. No one is carrying the umbrella, it’s just resting on all of their heads like a hat. Their hands are busy holding that cross, anyway.
mnemonics.reading: You know the Spanish phrase “Mi casa (かさ) es su casa”? Well this is kind of like that, but only with a hat. And that hat is an umbrella. Mi casa es yours too, because it’s an umbrella and also a hat. This makes sense, trust me. Imagine the four people in the umbrella hat again, only this time imagine them skipping along singing “Mi casa es su casa”. It’ll help you remember.

mnemonics.meaning: That woman dressed as Wolverine with a towel tied around her forehead is your wife. You're cosplaying together! Picture your kick-butt wife in her Wolverine costume, the towel around her forehead so she doesn't sweat into her eyes, as you prepare to go to a convention together.
mnemonics.reading: Your wife suddenly looks at you and calls you a fool (ふ). Wuh! Then you look down and see that you're also dressed as Wolverine. Your wife is shaking her head saying, "You fool, it's my turn to be Wolverine, you're gonna have to change." Then she smooches your cheek, calls you a fool one more time, and leaves without you.

mnemonics.meaning: Extinction will happen as you go versus extinction. It will happen absolutely. It will happen without fail. There's nothing you can do to stop extinction.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful though, 絶 is normally read as ぜつ, but in this case it is shortened to ぜっ.

sentences: 学校のある夜は、外出できないって言ってるでしょ。だめだと言ったら絶対にだめだからね！
You can’t go out on a school night. If I say it’s no good, it’s absolutely no good!

mnemonics.meaning: You advance and attack! This is a charge on someone or something, though it can also be an advance on them. Yep, this is the 進撃 from 進撃の巨人, the popular anime and manga. Don't say you never learned anything useful here.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the ones you learned with the kanji. Advance! Charge! Move on to the next item!

sentences: どうにかして敵の進撃をはばんでくれ！
Do something to halt the enemy's advance!
ビエトは敵に進撃した。
Viet advanced on the enemy.
進撃の巨人にはまっています。
I’m hooked on Attack on Titan.

mnemonics.meaning: A ticket you sell beforehand are advance tickets. This is a ticket sold in advance. Buy your tickets early, or how else will you get in on a Conan audience?
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 前, 売る and 券 combined into one awkward word.

sentences: 前売り券は他の割引とは併用できませんって書いてあるよ。
It says that tickets sold in advance can’t be used with other discounts.

mnemonics.meaning: A giant person is a giant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ある巨人が別の巨人をヘッドロックで締めつけているのを見ました。
I saw one giant gripping another in a headlock.
あいつは巨人だが、胃弱体質だ。
He's a giant, but he has a weak stomach.
「何してるの？」「俺達、進撃の巨人を見てるんだよ。って、あぁ、しまった。最後の字幕見逃しちゃった。ちょっと巻き戻してくれない？」
"What are you guys doing?" "We are watching Attack on Titan. Oops. I totally missed the last subtitle. Can you rewind it a bit?"

mnemonics.meaning: The army squad is an army. It's also just the army. It refers more to "an" army rather than "the" army. Just a group of people who do army things.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この鰐蟹軍隊の成功のためには、あなたが必要なんです。どうか入隊してください。
I need you. You are crucial to the success of this crabigator army. Please join us.

mnemonics.meaning: This combines the kanji arrow and the vocab word 印 (mark), to give us the type of arrow you use for pointing at things (as opposed to firing at things). It could be an arrow on a sign, or on piece of paper, or a document or whatever. We can just call it an arrow, or an arrow symbol.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 矢 and 印 put together into one. The 印 is like the actual vocab word 印, but watch out for rendaku changing it from しるし to じるし.

sentences: 矢印にそって進んでください。
Please follow the arrows.
あの矢印の道路標識は何という意味ですか。
What does the arrow road sign mean?

mnemonics.meaning: Gold storage is where you put your gold. You want it to be safe, so you put it in a safe.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼が私の金庫を盗んでいた時、私はその物音が聞こえないふりをしていました。
I pretended not to hear him when he stole from my safe.

mnemonics.meaning: 占い is "fortune telling." Star fortune telling is when you use the stars for fortune telling. That's known as astrology or horoscope.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the words 星 and 占い put together into one. Did you foresee that one coming?

sentences: 今日の星占いで、頭にたんこぶができないように気をつけた方がいいと出ていたの。
Today’s horoscope says I should be careful of getting a bump on my head.

mnemonics.meaning: With aggression you attack the enemy. This is an attack.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: サーバーがサイバー攻撃を受けている。
The server is under cyber attack.
敵はまず巨大都市を攻撃してくるだろう。
The enemy will probably attack the megacities first.
昨日、武力攻撃が開始された。
Yesterday, an armed attack was launched.

mnemonics.meaning: A beach area is just a beach!
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 辺 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Beach starts with be. Be is べ! (I mean, it's pronounced differently, but they're spelled the same!) When you think of the beach, think of べ!

sentences: 一緒に浜辺を散歩しないか。
Shall we take a walk on the beach together?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It's worth mentioning that a more common way to say beach is ビーチ, and many people actually say 海 even though this literally means "sea".
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

sentences: エンジンの調子がおかしくなったので、浜に着くほんの手前で車を止めなきゃいけなくなっちゃったんだよ。
Our car’s engine was making strange sounds so we had to stop right before we were going to arrive at the beach.

mnemonics.meaning: When someone asks you 何故, or "why," you did something, you respond with, "何故なら blah blah blah." That makes it mean because. Why did you do that? Because I was mad! Why did you dance? Because I was happy!
mnemonics.reading: This reading is an exception but you learned them already because they're the same as the word 何故, which you learned a few levels ago. It just has some kana attached to it!

sentences: 何故なら、彼は魔法使いだったのです。
Because, he was a wizard!

mnemonics.meaning: To have benefit is to be beneficial.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 非常に有益な情報を提供して頂き、誠に有り難うございます。
Thank you very much for your very useful information.

mnemonics.meaning: A 間違い is a mistake. A big mistake is a big mistake.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 大 and 間違い put together into one not so mistaken word.

sentences: 彼女をデートに誘ったが、それは大間違いだった。
I asked her to go out with me, but it was a big mistake.

mnemonics.meaning: Many times is how many times you can use this number of tickets. That means there are many tickets, making this a book of tickets.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 電車の回数券は金券ショップでも買えますよ。
You can also buy a book of train tickets from a ticket outlet.

mnemonics.meaning: お菓子 is "candy," right? Add store onto that and you have a candy store.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the readings you learned with the kanji. It will help to know the word お菓子 as well.

sentences: お母さん、心配しなくていいよ。あのお菓子屋さんなら僕、一人でも行けるよ。
Don’t worry mom. I can go to the candy store by myself.

mnemonics.meaning: You have 時代 as a "period" of time you're talking about. What period? The infancy years. Those years are not just when you're a baby, but when you were growing up, too. That was your childhood.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「昨日、幼年時代の友人に偶然会ったの。彼には何年も会っていなかったんだけど。」「そう言えば、サーモンって、幼年時代の友人のフグと結婚したのよね。」
"I ran into a childhood friend yesterday. I hadn’t seen him in years." "Speaking of which, Salmon married her childhood friend, Fugu."

mnemonics.meaning: He who is both in his infancy and immature is probably childish and immature.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どうして幼稚な喋り方をする日本人女性が多いのですか？
Why do so many Japanese girls speak like children?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji means infancy. The adjective version refers more to your entire child-times, including baby times. But, if you're described as being like a child from child times, what are you called? Childish.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you were childish and immature you were sent off to do prayers to ask for forgiveness. One of the things you had to do was sing "hosanna (おさな) in the highest."

sentences: 私が幼い頃は、何事もうまくいっていたんだ。
When I was really young everything went smoothly.

mnemonics.meaning: Children in their infancy are children.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの幼児のテディベアの毛はベルベットのように滑らかだった。
The fur of that little kid’s teddy bear was as smooth as velvet.

mnemonics.meaning: The child who is a juvenile is just a child. A group of them is children.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 児童の九割が欠席しました。
Ninety percent of the children were absent.

mnemonics.meaning: Something so pure it's pure twice must be really clean! Cleanliness is next to pure...liness, after all. I'm sure that's how the saying goes.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 実際には清潔だけど、見た目は汚らしくてちょっと影がある男の人がタイプです。
My type is a guy who is actually clean but looks dirty and sketchy.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is cool is cold. This refers to something that is cold to the touch, not the weather or something like that (which is 寒い).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's mnemonic to help you: Something that is really cold to the touch is cold enough to make ice cream with.

sentences: 冷たいコーヒーのことを、日本語では「アイスコーヒー」と呼びます。
We call cold coffee "ice coffee" in Japanese.

mnemonics.meaning: 比較 is a comparison. Add 的 to it and you have  comparatively.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know the word 比較.

sentences: 彼は新しいプログラミング言語を比較的速く修得します。
He learns new programming codes relatively quickly.

mnemonics.meaning: The constitution laws are what makes up the constitution.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 憲法改正案の見直しで依然として忙しい。
I’m still busy reviewing the constitutional amendment.

mnemonics.meaning: A constitution government is a constitutional government.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 憲政の危機って何ですか。
What is a constitutional crisis?

mnemonics.meaning: You're cool and quiet. That's you, daddio. Nice and cool-headed and calm. So much composure
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: できるだけ冷静な口調で話すようにした。
I tried to keep my tone as calm as possible.
冷静を保つことはとても有益です。
Staying calm is very beneficial.
冷静にネット上の荒らしに対処する方法を学ぶ必要があります。
You need to learn how to be cool-headed when handling internet trolls.

mnemonics.meaning: Anti aggression is when you receive some aggression, then respond to it with anti aggression, aka your counterattack.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いつ誰に対して織田軍が反攻を開始したのか覚えてる？
Do you remember when and who Oda’s army started the counterattack against?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 兄弟 means "siblings?" Well when they're siblings you have to obey they're not your brother or sister, they're your cousin.
mnemonics.reading: The entire reading for this is an exception. Sorry about that. Here's a mnemonic to help you: What are the two defining traits your cousin has? They're good and a child. いいと子, or いとこ for short. Just remember your good, kid cousin. Your いとこ cousin.

sentences: 従兄弟同士は結婚できるんだぜ。
Cousins can get married?!

mnemonics.meaning: If 創造 is creation, then you add 的 to it, which means you have a creational thing, which is quite creative wouldn't you say?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これで、あなたには創造的な仕事にもっと集中してもらえます。
Now you can focus more on creative work.

mnemonics.meaning: If 創造 is creation and you add power to it, you have creative power.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well!

sentences: あなたのような創造力のある人と仕事ができることを、とても楽しみにしています。
I’m so excited to work with a creative person like you.
私の妹は、創造力がとても豊かだ。
My little sister is very creative.
ニュース記事のライターには、創造力はいらない。
News article writers don't need to be creative.

mnemonics.meaning: I can deal with it, no matter what the reason. I can take care of this problem, process it, and deal with it on my own.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は、上司が顧客のクレーム処理をしないことについてぶつぶつ文句を言っている。
He complains that his boss doesn’t deal with clients’ complaints.
パソコンがデータを処理しきれずにフリーズしてしまった。
My computer couldn't process the data and froze.
あの選手はゴロを処理するのが上手い。
That player is good at taking care of ground balls.

mnemonics.meaning: The extent degrees show to what degree or extent you're willing to take something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は実際は35歳だが、3歳児と同程度の知能水準しかない。
He is actually 35 years old, but has no more intelligence than a three year old kid.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is delicate, and the vocab has this meaning too. It's that kind of "subtle" delicate, not so much that something will break (like it is with the kanji). Something that is a bit faint and indistinct is going to be delicate in this sense, perhaps, too.
mnemonics.reading: If you're going to cuss (かす) up a storm, that's not really being delicate.

sentences: 彼女の微かな香水の香りに、妙に興奮してしまった。
I got strangely excited by the faint smell of her perfume.

mnemonics.meaning: When hope has died out, you have no more hope, only despair.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 相手チームに15点差で負けているので、かなり絶望的な状況です。
The other team is fifteen goals ahead of us, so we are in a pretty hopeless situation.

mnemonics.meaning: 直接 is direct. Add 的 to the mix and you have directly.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 直接 already.

sentences: 幸運なことに、私の家族はあの日本の大地震や大津波による直接的な被害は受けませんでした。
Fortunately, our family didn't take any direct damage from the huge earthquake or the tsunami in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Please deal with part of this trash. It is too much to handle all at once when it comes to the disposal of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の息子は、ある生徒に苛めを行い、退学処分を受けました。
My son was expelled from school for bullying a student.

mnemonics.meaning: Enter into a squad... an army squad. When you do this, you enlist in the army.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本人男性がアメリカ軍に入隊することはできますか。
Can a Japanese man enlist in the U.S. army?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: You'll remember this kanji to the extent that you study it. If you study it like Hodor (ほど) would study it, you won't learn it at all. You would only be able to say "hodor, hodor," over and over again, which isn't helpful at all.

sentences: まだ夜明けまでは一時間程あったが、驚く程青い目をした男は既に起床し、珈琲を作り始めていた。
It was still an hour before dawn, but a guy with startling blue eyes already had gotten up and was making coffee.

mnemonics.meaning: Not pure things are filthy and dirty. Ewughh.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「わっ！君にビールをこぼしちゃったよね！本当にごめんなさい。」「大丈夫よ！このスカート、妹のなんだけど、妹はそもそも不潔だから多分気にしないと思うわ。」
"Ah! I just spilled beer on you, I’m really sorry." "It’s okay! This skirt is actually my sister’s and she’s pretty filthy anyway, so she probably wouldn’t care."

mnemonics.meaning: When things are frozen they get tied up in ice, causing a freeze.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は道路の凍結についてよく文句を言っています。
She often complains about frozen roads.

mnemonics.meaning: A cool frozen storage is one which is really cold on the inside, so cold it can freeze things. This is called a freezer, not to be confused with 冷蔵庫, which is refrigerator, and doesn't have the kanji for "freeze" in it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 良い冷凍庫が見つかるといいですね。
I hope you find a good freezer.

mnemonics.meaning: A frozen death isn't a bad way to go, I hear. Still, you don't want to freeze to death if you can help it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 警察が昨夜私の見込み客が雪山で凍死しているのを発見したので、私に事情聴取をしたいそうです。
The police discovered that a potential client of mine was frozen to death on a snowy mountain last night and they want to talk to me.

mnemonics.meaning: 振る is "to shake." 仮名 is kana. This word refers to furigana, which is the little kana that's put next to kanji for the people who don't use WaniKani and can't read anything. As to why it's called "shake kana"? I have no clue. Just imagine putting little kana next to kanji and watching them shake around, though, and you should be good to go.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 振る and 仮名 put together into one. If you know those words, you won't need no furigana to help you with this word.

sentences: 漢字に振り仮名を振る仕事を見つけました。
I found a job where I write furigana above kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: A gambling hit can be multiple things. One type of gambling in Japan that was popular in the day involved betting these awesome wooden block things. You'd gamble by hitting them down on the ground, making a nice thunk sound. Another way to think about it is like blackjack. You want a card? You hit! Either way, it's gambling.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is weird on this one, but gambling is weird, I guess. はく goes to ばく, maybe because you're playing some gambling backgammon. The ち can be cheating, where you cheat at this gambling backgammon. So, you're backgammon cheating (ばくち), you big cheater.

sentences: 博打を打つことは日本では違法です。
Gambling is illegal in Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: Car storage is where you store your car. It's your garage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 両親の車を車庫に入れる時に、柱にぶつけてしまいました。
When I was backing my parents’ car into the garage I ran it into a pole.

mnemonics.meaning: A big populous place sounds like a place with a lot of people but it's more like a big part of the populace. It's most of the populace, sure, making it the general public.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 大衆の感じ方次第です。
It depends on how people feel.

mnemonics.meaning: Somebody shakes something at you. It was a finger, it seems. What a weird little gesture.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 身 and 振る put together, where the 振り gets rendaku'd to ぶり.

sentences: 日本人の人たちと、身振り手振りで何とかコミュニケーションをとることができた。
I managed to communicate to Japanese people with gestures.

mnemonics.meaning: The person who governs your house like a wife is your housekeeper.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 家政婦を雇おうかと思っているんです。
I think we should hire a housekeeper.

mnemonics.meaning: It's the institution that does deliberation on behalf of the populace. They represent the people. They are the house of representatives.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ある衆議院議員が公費でボートを借りたことが明らかになりました。
It was revealed that a member of the House of Representatives chartered a boat at government expense.

mnemonics.meaning: The master wife is the one that takes care of all your stuff for you. She is the housewife, a very common profession for married ladies in Japan, though things have been changing little by little. Still, being a housewife means you control the money, which is pretty neat if you ask me.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの主婦の肌はものすごくスベスベしている。
That housewife has really smooth skin.

mnemonics.meaning: A giant big thing is something that is huge and gigantic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼はとっても忙しい巨大企業の社長さんなんだから、アポの約束は絶対に早目に取っておいた方がいいよ。
I strongly suggest that you schedule the appointment with him well in advance because he is the president of an enormous company and he is very, very busy.

mnemonics.meaning: A husband and wife combo are a husband and wife.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ねぇ、あなた。これから先、私たち夫婦の間で色々なことがうまくいくといいわね。
Oh, honey. Now that we’re husband and wife, I hope things go smoother between us.

mnemonics.meaning: Shift the peoples of that country into this country. Immigration nation!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は、自分が違法移民であるという秘密を彼女に告白した。

mnemonics.meaning: A wife person is a lady, because I guess ladies are wife people? I'm guessing this is pretty sexist somewhere, somehow, but words were made a long time ago so hopefully you can give all those dead people a break.

sentences: あの婦人、俺の手には負えなくなってきたよ。どうしたらいいかな？

sentences: どうやって私の小さな郵便箱にこの本が入ったんだろう。
How could this book fit in my small mailbox?

mnemonics.meaning: Your specialty, which you focus on with aggression, is your major in college (your college major). Study hard, young grasshopper.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私はファイン・アートを専攻しています。
I’m majoring in fine art.

mnemonics.meaning: The discipline of a samurai. You need this in order to complete your master's degree. It's hard to get one of those things, and even though samurais didn't really get master's degrees all too much, they had the discipline for it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: アルバイトをしながら、修士号を取るために勉強しています。
I’m studying to get my master’s degree while working part time.

mnemonics.meaning: A delicate life thing (生物 = biology) is a life thing that is very delicate. So small and delicate. It's a microorganism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 微生物学の専門家は何時に来る予定ですか。
What time is the microbiology specialist scheduled for?

mnemonics.meaning: Shift your dwellings! Everyone shift! Somewhere else, please. Time for a migration.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: それはあなたがこの国に移住して来るか来ないかによります。
That depends on whether or not you will move to this country.

mnemonics.meaning: Shift and move to create movement.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: バスで長距離の移動は疲れる。
You get worn out when you migrate long-distance by bus.

mnemonics.meaning: An exhibition for things is put in a public building for anyone to see. This place is a museum.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「サーモン、昨日の博物館デート、どうだった？」「ひどかったわ！」「どうして？何があったの？」「フグったら、ずっと他の女の子をじろじろ見てたのよ！すごくむかついたわ。」
"How was your museum date yesterday, Salmon?" "Horrible!" "Why? What happened?" "Fugu was checking out other girls the whole time! I got pissed off."

mnemonics.meaning: The country will benefit from these actions. It will create national benefit or national interests.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日本人の英会話力不足によって、将来国益が損なわれる可能性がある。
Japanese people’s poor English could damage national interests in the future.

mnemonics.meaning: This word is pretty weird. It has two distinct sort of meanings. One is the "not so good" meaning, and the other is the "delicate" meaning. Lately the "not so good" meaning has taken priority, I think, so let's focus on that for now. Something is both delicate and strange. This delicate strange thing really is just not so good. It's not terrible, but it's not great either. It's just not so good. Why? Because if you touch it too hard, it will break. Also, it's not that normal either, so it's not helpful to you. Imagine a thing that could be like this, then think: Is this good? not really. It's not so good.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: うーん…なんとも微妙な感じですね。
Well... I have mixed feelings.
微妙なコメントしか思いつかなかったので、結局何も言いませんでした。
I could only come up with doubtful comments, so I ended up saying nothing.
彼氏から誕生日に極楽鳥花を貰ったんだけど、彼のセンスちょっと微妙だと思わない？
My boyfriend gave me a Bird of Paradise plant for my birthday. His taste is not so good, don't you think?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well, though "odd" is getting the number one definition for this word, and strange comes in later.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is actually the same as the kanji you learned. On'yomi all the way, despite being all alone. Strange!

sentences: 妙だな。今日はまだお袋から電話がかかってこないよ。
It’s strange that my mother hasn’t called me yet today.

mnemonics.meaning: 効果 is "effect," so the opposite of said effect is the opposite effect. Whoops!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as  well. Will help to know 効果 as well.

sentences: 彼女に焼き餅を妬かせようとして他の女にキスをしたら、全く逆効果になってしまった。
I kissed that other girl to make my girlfriend jealous, but it really backfired.

mnemonics.meaning: The things that line up are the ordinary and average things. The extraordinary things skip the line, because they don't have to wait. Sad for all the ordinaries.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember: All the people who went off to fight in Nam (なみ) were just ordinary, average folk.

sentences: 運動神経は並だったが、頭はすこぶる良かった。
He had ordinary reflexes, but a great mind.

mnemonics.meaning: It is reverse to the theory! What is going on? Things aren't right. There must be some kind of paradox going on, where all theories are reversed! D:
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 逆説的に聞こえるかもしれないが、長い結婚生活を送ってきた年配の人達は、ちょっと違ったことに取り組むことは夫婦関係の刺激になると認めている。
It may sound paradoxical, but many long-married old people admit that some differences can spice up a relationship.

mnemonics.meaning: Line up and go together. If lines did that, they'd be parallel.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 複数の言語を並行して勉強することは、ひとつだけを学習するよりも効率的だと聞いたことがあります。
I heard that studying multiple languages at the same time is more efficient than only studying one.

mnemonics.meaning: Your trip ticket is the ticket that lets you go on ALL of your trips. It's not your airplane ticket, it's not your boat ticket, it's the trip ticket. It's your passport, which allows you to take trips.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ホテルの金庫に貴重品と旅券を預けたいのですが。
I’d like to deposit my valuables and my passport into the hotel safe.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that a 郵便 is the mail and that a 番号 is a number. So a "mail number," what is that? Usually refers to your post number or postal code. It is also often referred to with a symbol, which is 〒, so look out for that.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: まだ新しい郵便番号を覚えていません。
I haven’t memorized my new postal code yet.

mnemonics.meaning: With 郵便 being mail and 局 being bureau, we have the "mail bureau." They're more often known as the post office.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 郵便 as well.

sentences: 郵便局のサービスに対して苦情を言いました。
I made a complaint about the post office’s service.

mnemonics.meaning: The degree of your spirit is what helps you to hone your precision and accuracy, for some reason. Just imagine yourself throwing a ball. You miss the target. Hmm, okay... time to power up like on Dragonball. Up that spirit energy. Turn the degrees up on it. Boom. Awesome. Now throw again. Hit! You hit it! What great precision you have gained by honing your spirit!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 3Dプリンタは発明されたものの、我々の高精度の研削盤に技術が追いつくにはまだ時間がかかるだろう。
Even though the 3D printer was invented, it would take a while for its technology to catch up with our high precision grinding machines.

mnemonics.meaning: Surpass the extent... okay, what does that even mean? You figure out the extent of your abilities, and then you surpass them to get better. You have to do this over and over again in order to keep getting better. It's a process that must be accomplished if you ever hope to get better than you are now.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 普通の主婦が無差別に脅迫状を送りつける気違いに成り下がった過程を説明してもらえますか。
Can you explain the process of how an average housewife ended up being a psychopath who sent out a bunch of threatening letters to random people?

mnemonics.meaning: The profit is really a benefit. Let's make more profit then.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この新しいタイプの下着が、莫大な年間利益を上げることを予想しています。
We are expecting that this new type of underwear will yield a large annual profit.

mnemonics.meaning: Something for public benefit is for public benefit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は公益法人で働いています。
I’m working for a nonprofit foundation.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pure? It's pure.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: "In order to stay pure and clean, you shouldn't ever do anything dirty or bad. That is the key, yo (きよ)."

sentences: 彼女は清い心を持っており、人々をとても思いやります。
She has a pure heart and is very considerate of others.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pure? It's also pure. People like this are also usually really gracious to others. This type of pure heart would even be a gracious loser.
mnemonics.reading: Oh man, the reading for this is... like... crazy. First part can be something like it's soggy (いさぎ)... then the second part is like the word 良い (good). So, you can think of a pure hearted person eating soggy cereal. He/she is so pure hearted that it doesn't matter to them how soggy it is. In fact, they seem to enjoy it! They keep saying "it's soggy, good!" over and over again while eating the terribly soggy food.

sentences: 俺にもお前みたいな潔い心があればいいんだがな。
Wish I had a pure heart like yours.

mnemonics.meaning: Write down a record of the events so we have a record, please. Don't want people to forget about this momentous occasion, when King Felix got his perfect game.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は、バイク事故で投げ飛ばされる飛距離の世界記録を樹立した。
She set the world record for the person thrown farthest by a motorcycle accident.

mnemonics.meaning: Climb up and record your information here. This is registration. It's work to get yourself registered (from the climbing) and even if you get your name recorded on there, you may not get in. So record your information, wait, and hope you get in.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 三宅結花です。携帯電話を変えたので、新しい電話番号とメールアドレスの登録をお願いします。
This is Yuka Miyake. I’ve changed my phone, so could you register my new number and email address in your address book, please? Thank you.

mnemonics.meaning: Discipline is the reason why you're able to do a repair on things. It takes a lot of time to fix something, and takes a lot of studying. That discipline is what you need, and you have it. Thus, it was repaired!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「おい、修理屋。これはすぐに直せるか？」「って、君たちの関係ってこと？悪いけど、それはできないよ。」
"Hey, repairman. Can you fix this right now?" "You mean, you guys’ relationship? Sorry. No can do."

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji as well. Lucky! Reverse face time!

sentences: 私はホットドッグのことが好きで、逆もまた同じ。こないだ夢であるホットドッグに’好きだ’ってちゃっかり言われちゃったんだから。
I like hotdogs, and the reverse is also true. I was told by a hotdog that they like me very much the other night in my dream.

mnemonics.meaning: The discipline in which you study words so that you can out talk anyone is called rhetoric. Get the rhetoric right and you can be a boss in any word related situation or discipline, yo!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は修辞学の先生に恋をしています。
I have a crush on the rhetoric teacher.

mnemonics.meaning: Slash somebody, take their flesh, then eat it raw. This kind of food is known as sashimi, yum!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a little weird. It's double kun'yomi where the 刺す becomes stem form and gets pushed inside the kanji to become さし. The 身 is just the word 身's reading.

sentences: 会合の後、素晴らしい刺身弁当があるレストランで昼食を予定しています。
After the meeting, we’re scheduling lunch at a restaurant that has a great sashimi bento box.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 貯金 is your savings? A box you put said savings in is a savings box.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 兄は、十年前に私の貯金箱を盗んだ事を白状しました。
My brother confessed that he had stolen my piggy bank ten years ago.

mnemonics.meaning: The extent of the day is that we're going to do this, this and this. That is our schedule and agenda, so stick to it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 演奏会の日程は、次の日曜日に変更されました。
According to the concert schedule, it’s been changed to next Sunday.

mnemonics.meaning: A soldier in a squad is a real soldier or sailor, unlike those "soldier" who are not in a squad. They don't have jobs, and can't be called real soldiers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 兵隊ごっこをしているの？面白そう。私も入れてよ。
Are you guys playing soldiers? That looks fun. Let me in too.

mnemonics.meaning: A record of sound is a sound recording of some kind. Might be minidisk, might be CD, might be digital. Whatever it is, it's still the record of sound.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 誰かがいびき録音用枕の特許を取得したというのは本当ですよ。
Someone actually got a patent for a snore recording pillow.

mnemonics.meaning: Spirit of the gods. This refers to both the "religious spirit" and the "spirit spirit." It's your spirit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先生は「精神を養わなくてはならない」と言った。
My teacher told me that I must cultivate my mind.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the kanji reading you learned, probably because this is stuck onto things, describing various squads.

sentences: 海上自衛隊音楽隊に採用された時、彼女は他の自衛隊員と同様に肉体的にも厳しいトレーニングを受けなくてはいけないことを知らなかった。
When she was hired by the Japan Maritime Self-Defense Force Band, she didn’t know that she had to physically work out as hard as them as well.

mnemonics.meaning: All good things are fleeting. When a scene in front of you dies out, it is gone. But, it was beautiful, it was amazing, it was a superb view.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 世界の息を飲むような絶景をたくさん紹介している有名なFacebookページがあります。
There is a famous facebook page that introduces lots of stunning views from around the world.

mnemonics.meaning: 独り is when you're alone. 言 is when you say something. So, when you say something and you're alone, you're just talking to yourself.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 独り is just the reading for 独り. The reading for 言 is an exception, though. It's ごと, which comes from こと. Just think that as you're talking to yourself you're telling yourself over and over to go to hell. You're mean to yourself, and you're also insane, which is why you keep saying that out loud to nobody but you.

sentences: 君が女性に対して口がうまいのは知ってたけど、その練習のためにそんな風にブツブツ独り言を言ってるなんてこれっぽっちも知らなかったよ。
I knew you were super smooth with the ladies, but I had no idea that you practice talking to them by talking to yourself like that.

mnemonics.meaning: With 故 meaning "reason" if you head towards that reason, you transition towards it. To say that in words, you might say therefore or consequently. You stated your case and ideas, then in order to go towards reason we use these words to transition towards it.
mnemonics.reading: By knowing the word 故 you'll know the reading for this word too! Here's a mnemonic in case you need a reminder, though: You're using WaniKani, therefore you're studying kanji and vocab. Whose fault is it? It's WaniKani's fault! But, your brain has been beaten to a mush from all the studying, so when you say "it's your fault" it comes out as "it's yue fault!" Go ahead and say it out loud that way.

sentences: 度重なる無断遅刻故に、 休暇日数が減らされてしまった。
I was repeatedly late without permission and consequently my vacation days were cut short.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Usually it's attached to things, because it tells you what kind of ticket something is.

sentences: 三ヶ月の定期券をもらえますか？
Can I get a commuter pass for three consecutive months?

mnemonics.meaning: You don't say "to aggression." When you do aggression on someone, you're probably doing something to hurt them in some way. This is an attack, making this word to attack. This refers to a planned attack, though. Think about what you're going to do. Plan it out. Then, 攻める!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When you (I'm talking about you) attack something, you don't use weapons or thinking or anything silly like that. No, you use your intense sexiness (せ). Bam! So sexy. Attack!

sentences: そのピッチャーはバッターを変化球で攻めることが多い。
That pitcher often assaults batters with curve balls.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means line up so the verb vocab version is to be lined up. You know this is the version where things are just lined up (you're not doing the lining up) because you keep saying boo (ぶ), why is everyone already lined up? I should have got here earlier so I don't have to wait (if you were doing the lining up yourself, you'd put yourself in the front, duh).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Only for you, when you visit Nara (なら), the deer there are to be lined up for you to inspect, as you are the deer inspector. If you don't know about Nara and its deer, you should look it up, they're pretty awesome.

sentences: エコバッグを買うために十二時間も行列に並ぶなんて信じられないよ。
I can’t believe that people wait in line for twelve hours just to get some eco-friendly bags.

mnemonics.meaning: 痛い is "painful." The verb version of that is to hurt or to be painful. It's an intransitive verb, so it happens without you trying to cause it. It describes the sensation of feeling pain 🤕
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi reading, which you learned already!

sentences: 昨日の夜から歯が酷く痛むんですが、診てもらえますか。
I’ve had a bad toothache since last night, so could you check that for me please?

mnemonics.meaning: 比較 is comparison. So, verb version of that? It's to compare.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help a lot to know the word 比較 as well.

sentences: 同じ年齢の女の子と比較すると、私の娘は体力があまりありません。
My daughter lacks physical strength compared to the other girls at her age.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means frozen, so the vocab version is to freeze.
mnemonics.reading: The reading actually comes from the word 氷, which means "ice." You can kind of see where the origins of these words come from, now... really cold frozen things. So, think back to こおり, then change the り to a る and put it outside the kanji. That makes the reading for this こおる, in all (or most) of 氷's glory.

sentences: オレンジジュースを凍らせて氷を作ったことはありますか。
Have you ever made ice cubes by freezing orange juice?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means opposite so the verb version is to oppose or to go against.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Just like when you play soccer (さか). You never play right, causing you to go against all things you're supposed to do and shoot goals into your own goalie's net.

sentences: 「うわ！お前目のとこに青たんできてるじゃん。」「そうなんだよ。昨日の夜お袋に逆らったら、こてんぱに殴られてさ。」
"Wow! You have a bruise above your eye." "Yeah, I disobeyed my mom last night and I got the shit kicked out of me."

mnemonics.meaning: 輸入 is import. Now let's make it a verb. To import.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 輸入 as well.

sentences: 私はヨーロッパからワインとチョコレートを輸入する仕事をしています。
My job is to import wine and chocolate from Europe.

mnemonics.meaning: 面接 is an interview. Make that into a verb and you have to interview with.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 面接 as well.

sentences: 今日私が面接した男はすごく馬鹿な奴で、オリンピックは三年毎に開催されるって言ってたよ。
The man I interviewed today was so stupid that he said the Olympics are held every three years.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 間違い means "a mistake?" Well this is the verb version. It means to make a mistake, to confuse, or to mistake. This verb is transitive. That means that it takes a direct object. Bear in mind that this one is a bit tricky, though, because although it's transitive in Japanese, the English translation will sometimes be intransitive.
mnemonics.reading: It's read the same as 間違い! Nice and easy!

sentences: こんな簡単な問題を間違えるなんて、悔しいよ。
Making a mistake on such a simple question is so frustrating.
すいません、友人と間違えてしまいました。
Excuse me, I mistook you for a friend.
間違えて他人の児童手当が私の銀行に振りこまれていたみたいです。
It seems that someone else's child allowance was deposited into my bank by mistake.

mnemonics.meaning: 回復 is recovery. Make it into a verb and you have to recover.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 回復, but you can also figure it out via the readings of the kanji as well.

sentences: 彼が意識を回復することは難しいだろうと医者に言われました。
The doctor told me that he is not likely to regain consciousness.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means retreat, and the verb vocab version means to retreat, to withdraw or to resign.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You need to retreat because she re-zoned (しりぞ) where you are standing. Now this is a no standing zone. Who is she? The re-zoner, duh.

sentences: ソフトボールチームのヘッドコーチのポジションを退くには、まだ早過ぎますよ。
It’s still too early for you to resign from your position as head softball coach.

mnemonics.meaning: This one is a little bit off and will take a little extra remembering. The kanji means extinction or die out, but the verb version here is to sever or to cut off. The ideas are pretty similar, but the wording isn't the same. Just think, when you put something to extinction, you have to cut off that thing from your life. Put it in extinction. You have to sever it.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  In terms of things you need to sever, tacos (た) are #1 on your list. No more tacos for you, going to cut those off from my diet.

sentences: 酒を絶つことが約束できますか。
Can you promise me you’ll abstain from alcohol?

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift so the verb vocab version is to shift.
mnemonics.reading: All that dubstep (うつうつうつうつうつ) playing downstairs is causing all of your glassware to shift off the shelf and onto the floor. Damn that dubstep. うつうつうつうつうつ♪

sentences: 私は苺をミキサーに移しました。
I transferred the strawberries to the blender.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means to attack, though it usually means to shoot, because that's a very common way in which to attack someone. Pow!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Who are you going to shoot? You are going to shoot You (う). Why? Because there's another version of you in front of you, so if you don't shoot that version of you who is you, amirite?

sentences: 動くな。じっとしていないと、撃つぞ！
Don’t move. Hold still or you’ll be shot!

mnemonics.meaning: 夢中 is crazy about. So, if I (talking about you here) am nothing when put next to this thing you're crazy about, then you are really, really into it. You have become nothing, at least when you compare yourself to it. This is total absorption (though it can also be ecstasy).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は無我夢中で働き、二十代で家を建てたが、三十代で墓を建てることとなった。
Working feverishly, he built his house in his twenties and built his tomb in his thirties.

mnemonics.meaning: Sharpen your discipline, whatever that might be. Could be kanji, could be baseball, could be curling. Whatever it is, when you sharpen it, you have to study. You have to do training. It's the only way to get better.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その研修は午後3時に始まる予定です。
The training session is set to begin at 3 p.m.

mnemonics.meaning: We're going to deal with it by putting this up your butt and giving you the treatment you need. Kancho!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 一時的な処置をほどこしたはいいけど、また後で同じことが起こらないか心配だ。
It's nice to have a temporary measure, but I'm afraid it will happen again later.
ビエトなら、今はあそこでダリンとバグを処置してるよ。
