If you're looking for Viet, he is disposing of the bug with Darin over there.
誰か彼に応急処置ができる人はいませんか。
Is there anyone who could give him first aid?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 私は傘をクロークに預けました。
I left my umbrella in the cloakroom.

mnemonics.meaning: This is when you take your umbrella and you stand it up. Wait, how is an umbrella standing up? Good question, my dear Crabling, you are putting your umbrella in an umbrella stand.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the readings for 傘 (learned with the kanji) and 立つ (to stand).

sentences: 傘立てに濡れた傘を立てないで下さい。
Please do not put a wet umbrella in the umbrella stand.

mnemonics.meaning: A warehouse is a warehouse, but this usually refers to a traditional style of Japanese warehouse, not a modern warehouse.
mnemonics.reading: What do you put in your warehouse? Nothing that nice. Just your totally crashed (くら) car. So sad, it was a nice car, too and now it's all crashed and stored in your warehouse.

sentences: お宅の庫は何階建てですか？
How many stories does your warehouse have?

mnemonics.meaning: 我 is me, so two of me makes we! Or us!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 我, twice.

sentences: 我々はその問題を熟考する必要がある。
We need to carefully consider the problem.

mnemonics.meaning: A needle made of gold is a wire. Perhaps wires were made from gold mostly back in the day? And they were thin like needles? That's my guess.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the kun'yomi reading of both. You've learned 針 already, but 金 is more like お金, rendaku'd.

sentences: もし値ごろ感が重視されるのなら、我々の針金が圧勝することになるだろう。
If affordability is a necessity, our wires will win hands down.

mnemonics.meaning: A strange drug that seems too good to be true? Sometimes they're not bad. They are known as wonder drugs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: これは二日酔いに良く効く妙薬です。
This a really effective miracle cure for hangovers.

mnemonics.meaning: It's the side of the beach! Well, wait, what is it? This will make better sense when you look at the reading for the word, since it's a place: Yokohama.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 横 and 浜 put together into one nice word, よこはま.

sentences: 「横浜から大阪までずうっと乗せてくれて、本当に有難うございます。」「どういたしまして！」
"Thank you so much for giving me a lift from Yokohama all the way to Osaka." "Don’t mention it!"

mnemonics.meaning: This radical is the same as the kanji. It means above.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means blame.
When the sun gets small, you need to heat up by throwing some big horns in the fire. This turns into charcoal. Nice, toasty charcoal that keeps you warm when the sun gets small.
This radical is the same as the kanji. It means district.
If you look at this radical right, you'll see a NOSE (with a squinty eye on the left).
Hey, it's that giant you learned before. But... but its arms are chained. They're chained because you caught the giant and now it's your servant!

You see a rice paddy and you give it a kiss before granting it the abbreviation, RP. The rice paddy isn’t too fond of this abbreviation, so you kiss it again to soothe it. As you imagine yourself giving a kiss to a rice paddy, think about whether or not the abbreviation RP would ever catch on. Do you think it would?
mnemonics.reading: The rice paddy still refuses to accept this abbreviation despite your kisses. Therefore, you are forced to take the rice paddy and hang it from a torture rack (りゃく) until it agrees to accept the abbreviation. Imagine the rice paddy on the rack, squealing for mercy. Turn the handle to turn the rack, causing the rice paddy even more discomfort.

mnemonics.meaning: Grains get blamed for how much they accumulate. If the grains accumulate too much then they make more work for the farmers. If they accumulate too little, then they're starving the people. Ugh, grains just can't win with you people. They're blamed for everything. Picture a pile of grains accumulating in size while a person watches. No matter how large the pile gets, the person keeps blaming them for something!
mnemonics.reading: Now the grains have accumulated a ton, they're overflowing in their grain sacks, and the farmer freezes and says, "Now those are some sexy (せき) grains." Is that why people become farmers? Because they think... accumulating a lot of grains is sexy? People are weird.

mnemonics.meaning: There’s a tsunami in heaven and you take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Now the tsunami is big enough to destroy all of heaven. The small drop that you appended to the tsunami was just enough to push it over the edge, reaching full destruction capability. Take a small drop of water and append it to the tsunami. Feel the drop of water on your finger and visualize yourself flicking it at the tsunami as it races towards heaven.
mnemonics.reading: Just after you append the small drop of water to the tsunami, it grows ten (てん) stories high. Before it was only nine, but since you appended that drop, the tsunami is now a full ten stories tall. Look up at this ten story tall tsunami. It looks big and powerful. Feel the water spray from the tsunami as it towers over you.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this roof someone odd is trying to approach you. You back up, but they continue their approach anyway. Imagine being under the same roof as an odd person who wants to approach you. You don't want anything to do with them, but they won't back off.
mnemonics.reading: They approach too closely and you can't take it anymore. You run out from under the roof, slam the door closed, and lock it with a key (き). You hold the key tightly in your hand and press your ear to the roof. You can still hear the odd person... thing(?) approaching. Hopefully this key keeps it away.

mnemonics.meaning: Under a roof, but still in the sun, a woman is laying out a fabulous banquet. The woman doesn't want anyone to burn from the sun, but banquets are best outside, so she's set up a roof to protect her and her guests. Picture a large banquet of food on a sunny day, covered by an outdoor roof, and a woman carefully setting it all up.
mnemonics.reading: Unfortunately, the banquet roof comes crashing down right before the guests arrive, and it ends (えん) before it can start. Honestly though, have you ever been to a banquet that ended well? Something always goes wrong when you have that many people under one roof.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're anti-tree, you won't mind if I turn all of them into boards! Hahaha! "Boards are much more useful than trees." - The Anti-Tree Association. Now picture this sign on a big machine that's cutting up all the trees into big boards.
mnemonics.reading: These boards are now being sold to Han (はん) Solo, who's wearing Ray-Ban (ばん) sunglasses, and who's going to smuggle them all over the universe. "Hey kid, I got nothin' against the trees. Business is business, and these trees are gonna get me out of debt," Han says, mussing up your hair. You don't know if you like him anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: You set up a net on a cross to wash your clothes in the river, when a huge wave of dirt smashes into it, breaking the whole thing and sending your clothes tumbling down the river. Oh, why did it have to break! If the net had been strong enough, your clothes wouldn't be even more dirty and lost down the river right now.
mnemonics.reading: You angrily search to see what caused your clothes washing machine to break and you see some kayaks (かい) upriver. The people in the kayaks are jumping around, kicking dirt up, which is what broke your stuff. "Hey you, kayak lovers!" you scream, "How dare you break my stuff, I'll get you and all the kayaks out there! You'll pay!"

mnemonics.meaning: Above you, on a small stool is the eye of your coach. He's really high above you though, and all you can make out is the glint of his eye as he perches on that stool. But he's yelling out orders and corrections, which you can hear very well. Look up from the field or court and see the eye of your coach shining down and watching you closely. It makes you uncomfortable, honestly.
mnemonics.reading: You finally win the big game and the coach is coming down off of his stool, and you see that's he's the ghost of Tokugawa (とく) Ieyasu!!! That explains why you could only ever make out his eyeball! Coach Tokugawa hovers before you, in full shougun garb, and nods his head in approval, winks, then disappears.

mnemonics.meaning: A good leader will use charcoal to mark her colleagues. Sometimes if leaders aren't around all the time, people will get rebellious and act badly toward people who can get them in trouble. So when you mark them with charcoal you know that someone close with your leader is around and you should probably stop being a butt. Imagine seeing one of the leader's colleagues walking around, watching you. You'd get back to work and stop goofing around, right?
mnemonics.reading: You have to be good around her colleagues, because if you aren't your row (りょう) boat permit will be taken away. Row boating is the only fun you ever get to have, besides learning kanji. So act as best you can around the leader's colleagues so you don't lose your row boat rights. Imagine goofing off in your row boat and then seeing one of the colleagues waiting on the shore for you. No! She's gonna take your row boat away!

mnemonics.meaning: A tree is not a cup of liquid or a counter for cups. Don’t get them mixed up. The last time you tried making a cup out of a tree to count your throat got filled with splinters when you used it. There wasn't even any liquid in it. Imagine cutting a tree into a cup of liquid and focus on the pain in your throat when you try to actually use it. Instead you kick the tree and angrily count cups of liquid in your head, because they simply are NOT the same.
mnemonics.reading: Another way to remember the counter for cups using a cup of liquid would be by creating and memorizing a haiku (はい) about them. Aren’t haikus useful? Think of a haiku about a cup of liquid and a counter for cups. Use that haiku to help remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: A woman who is good is my daughter. My daughter is a good woman, I guarantee it. Look at how good this woman is! She’s my daughter! She’s good! You wish your daughter was as good a woman as mine is!
mnemonics.reading: Your daughter, on the other hand, is not a good woman. Your daughter looks like a moose who may (むすめ) not be able to find its way out of a wet paper bag. Your daughter looks like a moose who may lose its way without a map. Your daughter looks like a moose who may do lots of stupid things. Think about how your daughter is basically a moose who may do dumb things. How ashamed you feel. How very, very ashamed. Unlike how I feel about my wonderful, perfect, not a moose-like daughter.

mnemonics.meaning: They say to wear a hat to cover your hair if your doctor diagnoses you with hair loss. It's the best option, folks.  Imagine the doctor diagnosing you with hair loss. He pulls out a hat and places it on your poor, thinning hair.
mnemonics.reading: You just had the doctor diagnose you with hair loss. How terrible! You stumble out of the room, dumbfounded. Not paying attention, you bang your shin (しん) on the table. Your shin really hurts. What an awful day. Hold your shin as you feel the throbbing pain in it. Even though the pain is so extreme, you can’t help but still think about the diagnosis you got from the doctor.

mnemonics.meaning: In the morning, you use a gun on your nose to make it dry. Don't worry, there aren't bullets in the gun. It's an air gun! So just imagine shooting the air into your nose every morning to make sure it's nice and dry.
mnemonics.reading: This technique for a nice dry nose was invented by Genghis Khan (かん)! Well, not him, but someone who worked under him. You see, he had a bit of a damp nose problem. Now the next time you manage to get your nose nice and dry, think back to our founding father Genghis Khan and thank him for where you are today.

mnemonics.meaning: A district that lacks things will be in Europe. Picture a map of Europe in your mind. Now picture little words saying which district is lacking what. This one is lacking water. That one is lacking food.
mnemonics.reading: Europe is lacking so much because their 王 (おう) keeps taking everything. Okay, so maybe this is an old view of Europe. But back in the old days the 王s there would take everything from their subjects, so every district would lack something. Good thing things aren't that way now, huh?

mnemonics.meaning: A saw cuts into your heart and you are filled with fear. Well, you were filled with fear before the saw reached your heart too, but now that the saw is cutting into your heart, you’re feeling more fear than ever. Try and imagine this saw slicing into your heart. Are you filled with fear? You should be.
mnemonics.reading: Even more so than your fear of dying, you are filled with the fear that you’ll never get to vacation in きょうと. You always wanted to take a trip to きょうと, but if you die from this saw wound to the heart, you’ll never get the chance to go. I fear you’ll never make it to きょうと. Think of きょうと and how you long for it as you slowly die from that saw wound to the heart.

mnemonics.meaning: An animal eats a child from a plate in a very fierce manner. This is a fierce animal, so it makes sense that it would eat the child in a fierce style. See the fierce animal fiercely eating the child from the plate. It’s very gruesome. See blood and body parts flying everywhere as the animal devours the child.
mnemonics.reading: The reason this fierce animal is eating the child from the plate is because the child forgot to mow (もう) the animal’s lawn. The fierce animal had hired the child to mow his lawn today, and when the child forgot to do it, the fierce animal hunted the child down and ate him. That child really shouldn’t have forgotten to mow the lawn. Imagine you are the child, being eaten by the fierce animal and wishing that you would have just mowed the lawn like you said you would.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami rolls in and destroys all the construction that was being done on the inlet and the bay. Both the inlet and the bay were having a lot of construction done on them to repair the damage from the last tsunami, and then another tsunami rolled in and destroyed all that too. Bummer. Picture all the construction on the bay and the inlet getting destroyed by the tsunami. Look at all of it fall apart and crash to the ground as the tsunami knocks it down. Imagine yourself right near the action, feeling the water spray from the tsunami.
mnemonics.reading: Imagine the Japanese people standing on the bay and the inlet as the tsunami approaches. “Eh (え)? What is that, Akiko?” “Eh? Where? Oh gawd, it’s a tsunami!!” EH? A tsunami you say? Those construction areas are screwed, man. Again, imagine the tsunami demolishing the area. Then be all like, “Eh? A tsunami? Aw, man.”

mnemonics.meaning: In the morning, Korea will still be Korea. Picture Korea first thing in the morning. You can see all the cities, the countryside, everything waking up.
mnemonics.reading: Korea is still here today on this beautiful morning because of Genghis Khan (かん). When he was conquering all that land in Asia and Europe he looked at Korea in the morning light and said, "Nah, they can keep it." Picture Genghis Khan admiring Korea from afar, but letting it live on.

mnemonics.meaning: The narwhal and the turkey are meeting in private to uh, show each other some private things. Doing this they realize they're both male! Picture a male narwhal and a male turkey meeting together in private. Whispering. Giggling. Pointing at each other's male bits.
mnemonics.reading: These male animals are obviously experimenting with things still. Ah, they must be youths (ゆう)!  To be a youth, again! It's just nature. Youths like to learn and try new things. And if two male youth animals wanna get together in private that's their business.

mnemonics.meaning: On every boat there is a table with a lid on it that's used for navigation. When you take the lid off, there is a big map, a sextant, and some little boat miniatures. All the navigation tools. You forget to put the lid back on the navigation station and all those tools and boat pieces go flying around the boat and into the water. Oops.
mnemonics.reading: You watch the navigation equipment roll away and then you feel a slap on the back of your head. Ouch! You turn around and there stands こういち, who you took with you as the navigator of this expedition. And, you just lost all his stuff! Picture this seafaring こういち angrily chasing you around the ruined navigation station, trying to hit you with a telescope.

mnemonics.meaning: To the servant you say: "gun, ground, plate." It is your job to oversee everything they do. You point to the gun. You point to the ground (that's where the gun goes). You point to the plate (you want it). You have to oversee everything the servant does.
mnemonics.reading: Why must you oversee everything? Because you are Genghis Khan (かん), and Genghis Khan oversees everything. If anyone had to oversee a lot, it was Genghis Khan, who had one of the largest kingdoms in all of history.

mnemonics.meaning: Under this roof you jackhammer your religion into people. It's a religion building. They have a lot of different names, churches, mosques, temples, cathedrals, but none of those matter. All that matters is that you really drill whichever religion you want into the heads of the people who come under your roof.
mnemonics.reading: Your religion requires everyone to take off their shoes (しゅう). Mostly because the shoes will help them resist the jackhammering, so you tell them that to join your religion they have to leave their shoes at the door. Picture the pile of shoes left outside. If you see a bunch of shoes like this you can be sure there's a religious place around here.

mnemonics.meaning: If what you say comes out blue, everyone knows that means you made a request. You request a favor and the words slide out of your mouth in a bright, blue blob. They hover in front of you for a few seconds, before splashing onto the person you made the request to. Picture this blue, slimy request. You could have done that thing by yourself, but you requested it of someone else, and now it's all over and everyone can see it.
mnemonics.reading: The next time someone requests something from you, take out your saber (せい) and slice it in half! Now they have the blue request gunk on them, and you can walk away as your already-blue sword absorbs the rest. Oh, and you don't have to fulfill the request (bonus!).

mnemonics.meaning: The soul of a narwhal was sucked into its towel, which is scary! Watch as the narwhal's face contorts as you see its soul get slurped out by the towel it was using.
mnemonics.reading: As you watch this scary scene you can't help but mutter, "Fool," (ふ) under your breath. Then you hear "Fool, fool, fool, it's too scary you fool!" and you realize all of the other narwhals are chanting. You don't know what's more scary. That the narwhal's soul got sucked out, or that all of its kind is calling it a fool now that it's dead.

mnemonics.meaning: There is a cross in your forehead with a thread attached to it, forcing you to search where it leads. You’re not sure how the cross got stuck in your forehead, but you are interested in seeing where this piece of thread leads. The search is on. It hurts to have this cross stuck in your forehead, but try to ignore that as you search for where the thread leads. Imagine gathering the thread in your hands as you move along.
mnemonics.reading: Your search is over. You found the end of the thread. The thread leads you to a sack (さく). A sack filled with more crosses with more threads attached to them. What does it all mean!?! Why are there more crosses and threads in the sack? Are you supposed to take them from the sack and throw them at other people’s foreheads? Maybe. Imagine yourself reaching into the sack and throwing the crosses at other people.

mnemonics.meaning: The servant radical and the servant kanji are exactly the same! Just remember that the kanji also means retainer and you’ll be fine. Retainer and servant are basically the same thing, so remembering this one shouldn’t be too hard for you.
mnemonics.reading: Your servant, also known as your retainer, bangs his shins (しん) all the time so you make him wear jeans (じん) to work now. He bangs his shins on all the furniture in the house, knocking over all your valuables. But at least when he’s wearing jeans it doesn’t leave bruises like it did when he wasn’t wearing pants. Imagine your servant banging his shins on everything in your house. Hand him a pair of jeans and tell him to put them on to soften the blows.

mnemonics.meaning: The leader of the mountain turkeys is our sponsor. He's paying us to say and type everything you're reading. This message is brought to you by our generous sponsor, the leader of the mountain turkeys. Long may he reign.
mnemonics.reading: This same sponsor is also how you made your cyborg (さい). You didn't think you were able to get all those body parts yourself, did you? No no, the leader of the mountain turkeys sponsored you so you could do your experiments. Turn your cyborg over and you'll see a stamp under one of its feet. It says, "Sponsored by" with a little picture of a turkey on top a mountain.

mnemonics.meaning: The dirt you use to go from place to place is the street. Back in the old days, all roads were made of dirt, not like the newfangled roads of today. Imagine using a dirt street to go from one place to another.
mnemonics.reading: As you're walking down the street, staring at the dirt, a guy (がい) bumps into you, "Hey guy, watch where you're going!" As he says this he bumps into another guy. "Watch it guy, I'm walkin' in this street!" "Woah guy, this isn't your business, this is my street!" You walk away from the two guys yelling and head down a different street. You hope all streets aren't full of loud guys.

mnemonics.meaning: Say good luck to one person enough and they'll be stuffed full of that luck. Better safe than sorry. Don't just say good luck once, make sure they're stuffed!
mnemonics.reading: You stuffed them by saying good luck two (つ) whole times! Picture a person with the actual words "good luck" stuffed into their body.

mnemonics.meaning: The servant sits on a stool, holding a piece of thread, looking very tense.  You walk by this tense servant and pause for a moment. They raise their tense eyes up at you and you can see they're shaking.
mnemonics.reading: You ask the servant why they're so tense, and they say they've been assigned to assassinate the King (きん) of England with this piece of thread. Imagine how tense you would be if you were about to try to murder the King! Your entire body would tense up, maybe to the point that you wouldn't be able to actually go through with it.

mnemonics.meaning: At the gate, you kiss the cabinet members, one by one. In order to gain access to this government building, you have to kiss all the members of the cabinet at the gate. What a strange ritual. Imagine kissing all the members of the cabinet. A lot of them are old men. Imagine kissing all of them at the gate. Eww.
mnemonics.reading: You need to kiss each member of the cabinet to gain access to their building. And you need to get into the building to recover your cock (かく). Your prize winning cock has been captured by a member of the cabinet and you need to infiltrate their headquarters and recover your rooster! Imagine yourself sneaking past the cabinet members, finding your cock, grabbing it, and getting out of there. You’ve recovered your rooster! The day is won.

mnemonics.meaning: Your leader sees your bare foot and urges you to put a sock on it. Imagine your leader's face when he sees your bare foot, and just how emphatic he is as he urges you to put a sock on it. He's really worried your foot's going to get cold!
mnemonics.reading: As urged, you put a sock (そく) on your foot. Ahh, that feels so much better. What a great thing, this sock. Feel this sock on your foot. It feels great. Wiggle your toes around inside the sock as you think about how glad you are that you did as your leader urged. Note that this kanji also has the same reading as 足, so keep that in mind too!

mnemonics.meaning: When a yakuza's knife boils, you know something very violent and intense is about to happen. The yakuza member is so upset his knife boils. Right after, they will definitely get violent and intense.
mnemonics.reading: When someone gets violent or intense, they always yell "Let's (れつ) get violent and intense!" In the case of our mnemonic, it's a yakuza member getting violent. So, imagine a yakuza member saying "Ret's get violent!" before doing just that.

mnemonics.meaning: Abbreviation in language is abbreviation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたの略語辞典を貸してもらえませんか？
Can I borrow your dictionary of acronyms and abbreviations?

mnemonics.meaning: Conserve those letters with abbreviation and it's... an abbreviation! By using omission you were able to abbreviate that word into a smaller word.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 時間の都合上、今は詳細については省略せざるを得ませんが、また後ほどご説明させて頂きます。
I have to omit the details for now due to time constraints, but I’ll explain it to you later.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you to remember:  When you get hit in the face with a board, it hurts. It is very 痛い (いた).

sentences: 2chの野球板に書き込みをしたんですが、板違いだと言われてしまいました。
I posted some comments on a forum about baseball on 2chan, but I was told it was the wrong board.

mnemonics.meaning: This is the noun version of 怒る. So instead of being "to be angry," it's just the idea and concept of anger and wrath.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: I have a lot of anger because I carry (いかり) all of my own things (books, luggage, drinks) and no one will ever carry them for me. Plus, the more things I carry, the more anger I carry inside. Ahh!

sentences: 私の怒りは三分以上続かない。
My anger will not go on for more than three minutes.

mnemonics.meaning: An angry energy comes out of you when you have anger. It also can refer to a fit of anger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼の鼻の穴は怒気を含んで膨らんでいる。
His nostrils swelled with anger.

mnemonics.meaning: 痛い is "painful." This is the noun version, it is a pain or pain.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 痛い. No pain here.

sentences: 俺の伯母さん、クソしてる時に胸にするどい痛みが走って、119に電話したんだ。
My aunt had a sharp pain in her chest while pooping and called 119.

mnemonics.meaning: The surface that accumulates into one area is a particular area. This has to do with math. When you add all the surfaces together by accumulating them into one calculation, you get yourself the area!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼のおでこの面積は100平方メートルある。
The area of his forehead is 100 square meters.

mnemonics.meaning: Append and attach this document to your email. It's an attachment.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 添 is what you'd expect. The reading for 付 is the on'yomi reading, which you've never learned. It's ふ, but for this word it becomes ぷ from the rendaku fairies. Just think of an attachment where instead of a document or something, you get an attachment of poop (ぷ). What a gross attachment. Your friend who likes to send poop attachments is dumb.

sentences: 人事部長様、 恐れ入りますが、このEメールに添付された履歴書にお目通し頂けますでしょうか。お忙しいとは存じますが、よろしくお願い申し上げます。
Dear hiring manager, please have a look at the resume attached to this email. Thank you for your time.

mnemonics.meaning: Navigation in the sky is aviation and flight. Vroom vroom sky flying!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの航空会社は四月に新路線を増やす予定だ。
That airline company is adding a new route in April.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: At a banquet or dinner party, you don't only get food, you also 歌 GET (うたげ), which is you getting a song from a singer, because entertainment is just as important as the food when you have a feast such as this.

sentences: 俺はその宴で、ドイツ語訛りの英語を話すとても美しい女性に出会ったんだ。
I met a beautiful woman who speaks English with a German accent at the dinner party.

mnemonics.meaning: A banquet meeting is when you meet together for a banquet (or dinner party).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 宴会で嫌な奴とお酒を飲むのは、会議で議事録を記録するより退屈な仕事だ。
Drinking alcohol with someone you don’t like at a dinner party is a much more tedious task than recording the proceedings of a meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is an exception, but it isn't too hard to remember. It's the same as 中 (なか), so if you think about it it makes sense. It's your insides, just like your belly is your insides!

sentences: 「お夕飯の支度ができましたよ！いらっしゃい。」「ああ、よかった！お腹ペコペコだよ。」
"Supper is ready! Come and get it." "Oh, thank god! I’m starving!"

mnemonics.meaning: A black board is a blackboard.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful of the はん changing to ばん.

sentences: 黒板が使えないので、ホワイトボードを持参しています。
We can’t use the blackboard so I’ll bring in a whiteboard.

mnemonics.meaning: A government colleague is one who works for and is part of the bureaucracy, making him/her a bureaucrat.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あの官僚が我々の素晴らしい提案を断ったなんて信じられないよ。
I can’t believe that the bureaucrats turned down the great offer we made.

mnemonics.meaning: When the cabinet meets for deliberation they are having a cabinet meeting. So governmenty.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: さっきの閣議では何が議題だったんだっけ？忘れちゃった。
What did we discuss at the cabinet meeting held earlier today? I forgot.

mnemonics.meaning: The cabinet colleagues are the cabinet ministers. They're the people in the Cabinet that are all colleagues with each other. They just happen to be known as ministers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は閣僚のふりをしたが、嘘丸出しだった。
He pretended that he was a cabinet minister, but it was such an obvious lie.

mnemonics.meaning: The middle part of Europe is Central Europe, wherever that is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 中欧を旅してみたいなと随分長い間思っていたんですよ。
I’ve wanted to travel around Central Europe for a really long time.

mnemonics.meaning: The things that are weaved are, essentially, just cloth or fabric.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the kun'yomi readings. With 織 you can pull the reading from 織る. With 物 you've probably seen it enough to know that it's often もの and not ぶつ. Just think of a piece of cloth that is monochrome.

sentences: 政治学が専門なのですが、何故か織物会社に就職しました。
I’m majoring in politics, but somehow I started working for a fabric company.

mnemonics.meaning: When something collapses and breaks, it is when a collapse happens. When this happens, it is destruction. It is also probably something that was already crumbling apart.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の祖父母の家はとても古いので、雪の重みで倒壊しかねません。
My grandparents’ house is so old that it could collapse under the weight of the snow.

mnemonics.meaning: We work at the same place and are colleagues, making us colleagues / coworkers.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 残念な事に、私の同僚はあの電車の事故によって大きな商談のスケジュールの組み直しを余儀なくされた。
Unfortunately, the train accident forced my coworker to rearrange his big business meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: To break it all is to break everything. Everything is broken. Complete destruction!!!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: マイホームを持っていたんですが、台風で全壊しちゃったんですよ。
I had my own house, but it was completely destroyed by the typhoon.

mnemonics.meaning: If you approach a building and attach some stuff to it, you're making a contribution. They get to keep it, after all.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 毎年少しだけ、母校へお金を寄付しています。
I contribute a little money to my alma mater every year.

mnemonics.meaning: When you approach to give something, you are probably giving a contribution.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 後進国の発展に寄与したとして、ノーベル賞が授与された。
The Nobel Prize was awarded to them for their contribution to the development of less developed countries.
トーフグが世界平和に寄与していることを知っているかい？
Did you know that Tofugu is contributing to world peace?

mnemonics.meaning: You like it because it gives you an odd feeling in your heart. You don't quite know what it is you like, but that's because it's curiosity that you have.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 子どもの頃、私は好奇心旺盛でした。
When I was a child I was full of curiosity.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

sentences: 「私の娘は人魚なんだ。」「ええっ、それってつまり、あんた魚と結婚したってことか？」
"My daughter is a mermaid." "Whoa! Does that mean you married a fish?"

mnemonics.meaning: You saw 締める, which means "to tighten." So when things tighten, and then they get cut off, it's when you've reached the deadline. You know that feeling? When you get close, you feel a tightening in your stomach. The deadline is near! But, then when your tightening gets cut off completely, it's because you've reached the end. The deadline.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 締める and 切る put together. Notice how the hiragana bits get pushed into the kanji though, that's the interesting part, but also the part that's hard to remember. It's probably because this is a short version of 締め切り, but you'll see 締切 more often.

sentences: うまく締切を明日まで延ばせたの？
Did you have any luck with putting the deadline off till tomorrow?

mnemonics.meaning: You need something so you request it. But, since it's such a strong need, it's not really a request, it's more of a demand.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 労働組合は賃上げを要請した。
The labor unions demanded a wage increase.

mnemonics.meaning: You request then you request again. This is starting to turn into more of a demand if you ask me. Also can refer to a claim or a charge as well.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 荷物を送った送料は後で請求可能だと言われています。
I'm told that I can claim a reimbursement later for the parcel shipping cost.
お金に困ってやみ金から借りたら、法外な金額が請求されて余計困りました。
I desperately needed money, so I borrowed some as an illegal loan. Then I was charged illegal amount of money, so I am now in more trouble.
請求書の金額が間違っているように思うので私はその請求の取り消しを要請します。
I’m going to request a cancellation of the bill because I think we were billed for the wrong amount.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to cut off the part of me that I'm trying to diagnose... well, not literally cut off, but cut off my diagnosing. I have come to a conclusion. A diagnosis!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の息子は四歳の時に喘息だと診断されました。
My son was diagnosed with asthma when he was four.

mnemonics.meaning: The dry seasons is the dry season.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: いつもはこの時期は既に乾季になっているが、依然として雨が降り続けている。
By now it’s usually the dry season already, but it continues to rain.

mnemonics.meaning: The bay door isn't what you might think, it refers to Edo, which is what Tokyo was called back in the day. You'll still see references to it everywhere, though, so it's good to learn. You can also call this Tokyo if you want, but I'd prefer if you answered "Edo," instead.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are the ones you learned with the kanji. Of course, it will be easy if you know the word Edo already.

sentences: だらだらしてないで、さっさと二階に行って宿題をしなさい。日本の江戸時代についてレポートを書かないといけないって言ってたでしょ！
Stop mucking around and go upstairs and do your homework. You said you gotta write an essay about the Edo period in Japan, right?

mnemonics.meaning: You have Europe and America. This word represents the relationship between Europe and America (or Europe and the USA). It can also refer more generally to the West.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 欧米でピンクの薔薇を栽培している所がないか探しているんですが。
I’m searching for a place in Europe and America that grows pink roses.
このホテルの主なお客様は、欧米の方々なんです。
The hotel's main customers are Westerners.
「欧米」に含まれる国を全部挙げることができますか。
Can you name all the countries included in "Europe and the US"?

mnemonics.meaning: The 日 refers to Japan (It's the 日 of 日本). So, you have Japan and Europe, which is Japan and Europe or Europe and Japan.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 日欧貿易に関する会議は、司会者の不在によって横道に逸れてしまった。
The meeting concerning trade between Europe and Japan was sidetracked due to the moderator’s absence.

mnemonics.meaning: 極める is "to carry to extremes." So, 極めて is something similar. It's used to refer to something that's extremely _______.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 極める.

sentences: 君がこの問題の解決方法について具体的には何も考えていないというのは、極めて明白な事実だ。
It’s extremely obvious that you don’t have any idea how we can solve this problem.

mnemonics.meaning: If you're fierce and violent then you are fierce and violent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: このプロジェクトのリーダーを買って出たことを、今猛烈に後悔しています。
I seriously regret that I volunteered to be the leader of this project now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. You can put this on other words to say that it's a "Fierce ____" or "Energetic _____," or something along those lines. If you see this, you know that something is done fiercely or really energetically.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because it's stuck onto things making it all jukugo and such.

sentences: バイクが猛スピードで突っ込んできた。
The motorcycle came rushing forward at breakneck speed.

mnemonics.meaning: You cut your abdomen. This is what you do when you're doing harakiri, aka ritual suicide.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from 腹 and 切る. If you're lucky, you already know the word harakiri as it's made its way into English as well.

sentences: 侍の腹切りをテーマにした映画は来週公開されます。
The movie based on samurai harakiri will be released next week.

mnemonics.meaning: An English brave person. Okay, there are probably other kanji meanings that aren't as common being put into effect here, but if you just think about this as King Arthur, an English brave person, then you can get the meaning of this word. King Arthur is probably England's most well known hero.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この言葉は、英雄たちについて書かれたとある本からの引用です。
This phrase is quoted from a book about heroes.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 迷う means "to go astray" or "to get lost?" Well when you feel like you're about to go astray or get lost it causes hesitation. You end up with a lot of doubt about where to go or what to do. It's a natural progression.
mnemonics.reading: You learned this reading already when you learned 迷う! Just swap the う for an い.

sentences: なんとか迷いを断ち切りました。
I managed to get rid of my hesitation.

mnemonics.meaning: A street road is as wide as a street plus a road combined together. So cool! So wide! It's a highway!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It uses the かい reading (not the がい) because it's at the beginning of the word.

sentences: 東海道、中山道、日光街道、甲州街道、奥州街道は、五街道と呼ばれ、江戸時代の五大陸上交通路であった。
Tokai-do Road, Nakasen-do Road, Nikko-kaido Road, Koshu-kaido Road, and Oshu-kaido Road are called Gokaido, which were the five principal routes used during the Edo period.

mnemonics.meaning: When your belly has decreased in the amount of stuff inside it, you become hungry.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 腹 plus 減る put together. With these two combined, you have はらがへった.  Sometimes you'll see and hear people use just 腹減った, without the が. Just so you know.

sentences: 腹が減ったな。この件については、昼飯を食べながら話さないか？
I’m hungry. Would you like to continue this over lunch?

mnemonics.meaning: This fever is violent. This is the feeling you get when you have crazy passionate enthusiasm, aka you are  impassioned.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女はどうやらお前の熱烈なファンみたいだな。
She seems to be a passionate fan of yours.

mnemonics.meaning: You search then pull items from the index. Best way to search, since it gives you a clear idea of what's going on on a large scale.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just think of the first part of the word index (いん). Where do you search? In the index.

sentences: 英語索引も付けた方がいいんじゃないかな。
We should make an English index too.

mnemonics.meaning: When you enter an inlet, you've gone into the inlet. It's also where water goes inside of the inlet (it's entering the inlet from the ocean, or whatever), so that's another way to think about it.
mnemonics.reading: For this reading, just imagine this as 入り with 江 pushed on at the end!

sentences: バルト海の北の入江で知らない人からプロポーズされたんですが、とてもロマンチックだったのでつい承諾してしまったんです。
I was proposed to by someone I didn’t know in a cove north of the Baltic Sea. It was so romantic that I accepted.

mnemonics.meaning: With the 日 of 日本, the 日 means Japan. Then, you add Korea into the mix and you have Japan + Korea. This word means Japan and South Korea or South Korea and Japan (depending on where you're from, I guess).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この風習は日韓両国でよく見られます。
This custom is frequently seen in both Japan and Korea.

mnemonics.meaning: A dry cup of liquid is one that's worth cheering to. This is the Japanese way to say "cheers!" or "toast" or whatever else you say before drinking something.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: さあ、乾杯、乾杯！それ、ぐいと一杯、飲み干したまえ。
Alright, cheers cheers! Hey, bottoms up!

mnemonics.meaning: You examine then search. These are the steps you take in order to perform a lookup of some kind (or, as the case may be in modern times, do an internet search).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 後でネットで検索してみるよ。
I’ll look it up on the Internet later.
私がよく利用する検索エンジンはグーグルです。
The search engine I use most often is Google.
こんなにたくさんの料理本を持っているのに、結局クックパッドで検索しちゃうんですよね。
I have so many cookbooks, but I end up searching on Cookpad.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm going to diagnose you and then make a guess as to what's wrong with you during this medical exam.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先生は診察の予定がみっちり詰まっています。
The doctor has a jam-packed medical exam schedule.

mnemonics.meaning: A big servant is bigger than the rest of the servants. One type of servant is one who serves the people (as is the case with this one). A big servant is someone high up in the realm of serving the people. So, let's call this big servant a minister or cabinet member. Big cheese.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は大臣たちに会議の前に資料を配るのを忘れてしまったために、首になっちゃったんだよ。
She was fired because she forgot to hand out the documents to the cabinet members before the meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: Sometimes even though you're very much awake and alive you need to sleep for a little bit, so you take a nap. But you're not dead! You're totally alive, so let's hope no one thinks you're doing anything but dozing off.
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned both of these readings by now so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 運転中に居眠りしてたみたいなんだ。
It seems like they dozed off while driving.

mnemonics.meaning: The navigation methods are the methods used for navigation.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どこで空中航法を学んだんですか。
Where did you learn aerial navigation?

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how 直行 is "nonstop"? Well, with 直航 it's the same thing, but it's only used for flights and boat trips, making this a nonstop flight or direct voyage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この便はポートランドから東京まで直航しないで途中でアラスカに寄港します。
This flight does not go directly from Portland to Tokyo, but stops in Alaska on the way.
子供がまだ小さいのでできれば直航の飛行機で行きたいと思っています。
My children are still small, so I would like to take a direct flight if possible.
この船は神戸港に直航します。
This ship is on a direct voyage to Kobe Port.

mnemonics.meaning: When you sponsor an announcement, you're allowing those you're sponsoring to create some kind of notification for all those they want to get in contact with.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: サラ金から、借金の返済を求める催告状が何度も何度も届いています。
A consumer credit company has been sending me notification letters over and over, demanding that I pay back my debt.

mnemonics.meaning: You oversee and look at all that is in your domain. You are keeping an observation over everything.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 監視カメラは持ってるんですが、まだテープを確認した事はないんですよね。ちゃんと撮れてるのかな。
I have a surveillance camera, but I haven’t checked the tape yet. I wonder if it’s working properly.

mnemonics.meaning: Odd numbers are odd numbers (as in, 1, 3, 5, 7, though they are a bit strange as well).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 奇数とは2で割り切れない数字のことです。
Odd numbers are numbers that cannot be divided by two.

mnemonics.meaning: One cup of liquid is equal to one cup (or one cup of liquid).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just remember that 一 becomes いっ, and 杯 becomes ぱい.

sentences: 「ちょっと一杯飲みに行かない？」「いいね。」
"Let’s go for a drink." "Sounds like a plan."
子供の時に「一杯のかけそば」という映画を一度だけ観たことがあります。
When I was a child, I watched a movie called "One Cup of Soba Noodles in Broth" just once.
次年度の予算のこととで頭が一杯な状態だったので、その夜は一杯もお酒を飲む気にはなれなかった。
My mind was so full of the following year's budget that I didn't feel like having even one drink that night.

mnemonics.meaning: An alone (一人) daughter is a daughter with no other daughter siblings, making her the only daughter.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 一人 plus 娘 put together into one, single (daughter) word.

sentences: 「何でのっけから彼女に一人娘が売春しているなんて言ったんだ？」「ごめん。軽率だったよ。」
"Why did you tell her that her only daughter is prostituting to begin with?" "I’m sorry. I spoke out of turn."

mnemonics.meaning: 痛み is "pain." 止める is "to stop." What stops pain if you use it? How about a painkiller.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 痛み and 止める put together into one word. Not too painful, right? Just remember the rendaku on the ど.

sentences: 彼は痛み止めを飲んで、また畑を耕し始めた。
He took a painkiller and kept plowing the field.

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to ride in a car, the ticket you'll need is a passenger ticket, not just any old ticket. This is generally a ticket for public transportation, so think of the "car" here as a train car.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: バスの乗車券はどこで買える？
Where can I buy a bus ticket?
割引乗車券はありますか。
Do you offer discount tickets?
電車の乗車券を内ポケットに入れたはずなのに、見当たらないの。
I was sure I put my train ticket in my inside pocket, but I can't find it.

mnemonics.meaning: I request and then I request again. So many requests, but nobody will listen to me. My last hope is to get a bunch of people who have the same ideas together and make a petition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: もしご迷惑でなければ請願書に署名して頂けませんでしょうか。
If you wouldn’t mind, would you please sign this petition?

mnemonics.meaning: You have a fear, this fear is scary, oh, and it's a symptom, so it's kind of just in your head. What kind of symptoms occur when you are scared and have fear? How about when you have a phobia.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私も父も高所恐怖症です。
My dad and I are both afraid of heights.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are beautiful and lovely are very beautiful, pretty, and often clean, too. You can call someone 綺麗. You can also mention how clean something is with 綺麗. Gives you some insight as to what "beauty" is in Japan, I suppose. Take your baths, folks.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「君みたいに綺麗な女性に会ったのは初めてだよ、サーモン。」「フグったら、嘘ばっかり。」
"Salmon, you’re the most beautiful woman I’ve ever met." "Fugu, that’s such a lie."

mnemonics.meaning: The religion teachings are what makes up a religion. If you don't have the teachings of the religion, nobody will learn about it, and it will stop being a religion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女が、世界宗教会議の記録を取る書記を務めます。
She will be the secretary who records the transactions of the world religions meeting.

mnemonics.meaning: To lend is 貸す. This is the noun version. It is something that has been rented, a rental.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 貸す.

sentences: 今は貸し倉庫で寝泊まりしているんです。
I’m living in a rental warehouse now.

mnemonics.meaning: An abbreviation version of a diagram isn't the completed diagram, nor is it one you spend a lot of time on. It's the abbreviated version, so it's more like a rough sketch or a rough map.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: あなたの家からうちまでの略図を書いて、メールでお送りします。
I’ll draw a rough map from your house to mine and email it to you.
あなたが書いた略図のメモをちょっと見せてもらえませんか？
Do you mind letting me look at the rough sketch memo you made?
略図を書いたのはいいんですが、略しすぎて自分でもよく分からなくなってしまいました。
I drew a rough sketch, but I omitted too much and now I can't understand it myself.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scary? It's also scary.
mnemonics.reading: You know what's really scary, like double scary (because kanji and vocab both mean scary)? How about your coworkers (こわ). They are all insane, and you know it. Absolute nutjobs they are.

sentences: 火星でマグニチュード7の地震が起きたんだってさ。怖いね！
It seems that a magnitude 7 earthquake occurred on Mars. Scary!

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of fear? When you feel fear, you think something is scary.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: How scary is it? It's Oh so (おそ) scary!

sentences: 恐ろしいと思うかもしれないが、自然の法則には逆らえないんだよ。仕方がないさ。
You may feel scared, but you can’t defy the laws of nature. It’s no use now.

mnemonics.meaning: A search search is a more intense search, like the ones for a missing person.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 警察は捜索活動を続けています。
The police are continuing to work on the investigation.

mnemonics.meaning: A religion sect is a sect within religion, most likely, but it can be simply referred to as a sect or denomination.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この宗派には、会議で議長を務めるための規則があります。
There are some rules for acting as chairman of meetings in this religious sect.

mnemonics.meaning: A merchandise shop street is a street with all kinds of shops and merchandise on it. Sounds like a lot of shopping goes on here in this shopping district!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の弟は正真正銘の馬鹿だよ。昨日、鼻で牛乳を飲んでみたかったみたいで、商店街に牛乳を買いに行ったんだけど、そこで道に迷って結局牛乳買わずじまいだったんだから。
My brother is a complete moron. Yesterday, he went out to get some milk in the shopping district so he could try and drink milk with his nose, but he got lost there and ended up not buying it.

mnemonics.meaning: 招く is "to beckon," so a cat that beckons is known as a maneki neko or a beckoning cat. These are the cat statues places in front of shops that move their arms up and down and are like, "Hey, come on in!"
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the kun'yomi readings for both kanji, which you know already!

sentences: ここを出る時、電動招き猫のコンセントを挿しっぱなしにしないでね。
Don’t leave the electrical Maneki Neko plugged into the outlet when you leave here.

mnemonics.meaning: Sleepy sleep medicine is sleeping pills. Don't take too many or you might get addicted.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: さっき飲んだ睡眠薬のせいで、手足が思うように動かないんだけど。
I’m so uncoordinated right now because of the sleeping pill I took.

mnemonics.meaning: Some kind of sleep medicine? That's sleeping pills.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 眠い plus 薬 put together in one ... zz zzzzzZZZzz Just remember that くすり turns into ぐすり here because of rendaku.

sentences: おい、お前、今の見てたか？俺、今ドリブルで三人のバックを抜いたんだぜ！俺ってば、ほんと、最高！相手チームにあげた眠り薬入りのオレンジジュースがうまく効いてたみたいだな。
Did you see that? I just dribbled around three defenders! I am the man! The orange juice with sleeping pills that I gave the other team worked perfectly!

mnemonics.meaning: The Korea Country is Korea, of course... well, South Korea that is.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この韓国ドラマ、再放送されるのかな。
I wonder if this Korean drama series will be rebroadcasted.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have troublesome (迷惑) mail, you have mail you don't want. This is known as spam, spam mail, or junk mail. On a more technical level it's unsolicited mail.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 迷惑, so if you know that you know this (and then this vocab word won't be unsolicited as well!)

sentences: 迷惑メールが次から次へと送られてくる。
I get one spam mail after another.
迷惑メールが多すぎて、精神にい常をきたしそうだよ。
I get so much spam it's driving me insane.
コウイチからのメールはいつも迷惑メールフォルダに入ってしまうんだけどどうしてなんだろう？
Emails from Koichi are always found in the junk mail folder. I wonder why.

mnemonics.meaning: The master who sponsors you is the one who provides your sponsorship. Without this person, you wouldn't have sponsorship at all, which is why you call them "master" (plus, that was one of the rules with the sponsorship).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 競馬場の芝についてのシンポジウムが市当局の主催で開かれた。
The racetrack turf symposium was able to happen because of city government sponsorship.

mnemonics.meaning: A watch over board is a board that goes over your store and watches over everything. What board on a store watches everything? It's the one that gets the most visibility, so it's probably the store sign.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Be careful of the はん changing to ばん.

sentences: 酔っぱらいの男が殴ったせいで、お店の看板がへこんでいるんです。
There is a dent in the store sign because some drunk guy punched it.

mnemonics.meaning: That's very odd and strange, making it odd and strange.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今年の夏が例年になく暑かったせいなのかは分かりませんが、奇妙な発疹が胸に出ましてね。
I’m not sure if it was because this summer was unusually hot, but a strange rash broke out on my chest.

mnemonics.meaning: When your tenseness is stretched out as far as it is, it becomes not just tenseness, but stress as well. The tension is crazy when you stretch it out like this!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「明日、就職の面接があるんで、ちょっと緊張してるんだよね。」「え〜そうなの？うまくいくといいね。」
"I have a job interview tomorrow. I’m a little nervous." "Oh, really? Well, I’m sure you’ll do fine."

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are strong and intense are strong and intense (the "strong" meaning is more along the lines of the "intense" meaning, so not so much like my muscles are super muscly and strong).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ひっさびさにタバコ吸ったら、強烈なヤニくらくらっちまったよ。
If I smoke for the first time in a while, I get an intense tobacco high.

mnemonics.meaning: The big abbreviation is where you take everything and abbreviate it down to show the big picture. This abbreviation is the summary or outline of something bigger.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: まずは事件の大略を説明してくれないか？
Can you explain the outline of the incident first?

mnemonics.meaning: The one who oversees and coaches is the one who gives the supervision and direction. I see it all! I coach! If you're a movie fan, you might already have seen this word used to mean director.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 今日は仕事で期末試験を監督しました。
I supervised a final exam today at work.
マイケルは、宮崎はやお監督の映画を他のアニメ映画と比べています。
Michael is comparing movies directed by Hayao Miyazaki to other anime movies.
あの映画監督の名前が思い出せないんだけど。何て名前だっけ。
I can’t remember the name of that movie director. What was his name?

mnemonics.meaning: I fear it. It is scary. It is pure terror.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ヤクザにお釣りが百円足りないと言われた時に、とてつもない恐怖を感じました。
When a yakuza told me that the change I gave him was 100 yen short, I felt an incredible amount of fear.

mnemonics.meaning: Three cups of liquid is three cups of liquid, or more simply, three cups.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Just watch out for 杯, which becomes ばい thanks to our old friend rendaku.

sentences: その時ちょっとへこみ気味だったもんで、ビールを三杯一気飲みしちゃったんだよね。
I was depressed at the time, so I chugged three glasses of beer.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means abbreviation, so the verb vocab version is to abbreviate or to omit.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is, strangely, the same as the reading you learned with the kanji. りゃくす.

sentences: 日本の若者はすぐ単語やフレーズを略したがる。
Young Japanese people tend to abbreviate words and phrases.
略さずにフルネームを書いてください。
Please write your full name without abbreviating it.
略して話されても部外者の私には何のことか全然分かりません。
As an outsider, I have no idea what you are talking about when you speak in abbreviated form.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means accumulate and the verb version is to accumulate.
mnemonics.reading: If something accumulates, you can start with one, but you need at least two (つ) things to say it has accumulated. If you don't, then there's nothing accumulating at all.

sentences: 体重を減らすために、日常の食事の量を極端に減らす必要はないよ。それよりも、バランスの良い、健康な食事を取ることの方が重要だ。ちりも積もれば山となるって言うじゃないか。
You don’t have to drastically decrease the amount of food you normally eat to lose weight. It is more important to have a balanced, healthy diet. It’s said every little bit counts.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember how you learned that 怒る means "to get angry?" Well this is when someone else gets angry and it's because YOU made them angry. It means to anger someone.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading when you learned 怒る, so you should know this one too!

sentences: 父さんを怒らせると後が面倒よ。
You’ll be in trouble after making dad mad.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means append, so the verb vocab version is to append.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To append something to something else, you can just sew (そ) it onto something else.

sentences: そのシェフは、ステーキにバニラアイスクリームを添えた。
The chef garnished the steak with some vanilla ice cream.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means approach, and the verb version is to approach, to visit, to drop in and to stop by.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You haven't learned this reading yet so here's a mnemonic to help you: If you're too shy to approach people just learn how to use a yo-yo (よ)! Then people will approach you to compliment you on your sick skills. You won't have to do it yourself!

sentences: 学校の帰りに、図書館に寄るつもりです。
When I come home from school I plan on dropping by the library.

mnemonics.meaning: You know 構え, which is a stance? This is the verb version, making it to assume a stance, or most often, to get ready to fight.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 構え, so if you know that you'll be ready for this fight.

sentences: ポーカーをする時は、気長に構えることが大切です。
When you play poker it’s important to prepare patiently.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means break so the verb vocab version is to break something, because you're doing the breaking. You know this because someone is trying to sue (す) you for the things you broke of theirs.
mnemonics.reading: The thing you broke? A beautiful ceramic koala (こわ). Watch it shatter to the ground, because you threw it there. What a jerk you are.

sentences: この河豚を自分なりに料理してみたんですが、お腹を壊してしまいました。
I cooked this blowfish in my own way and it wrecked my stomach.

mnemonics.meaning: The meaning of this word is the same as 任せる. Both words are pretty common, but 任す is slightly less common than 任せる. Here's the mnemonic again, just in case you need a refresher: If you pass a duty on to someone, that means you're going to entrust something to that person, or you're going to delegate something. In other words, you're going to leave something to them, so that they do it for you.
mnemonics.reading: This uses the same reading you learned with 任せる.

sentences: この店のことは全て君の判断に任すよ。
I'll leave everything about this store to your judgment.
大きな仕事を任されて、うれしいけど少し不安でもある。
I'm happy to be entrusted with a big job, but I'm also a little nervous.
今回、プロジェクトマネージャーを任されることになった田中です。よろしくお願いします。
I'm Tanaka and I've been assigned as project manager. I look forward to working with you all.

mnemonics.meaning: In order to diagnose a patient, you must first go to examine a patient. When you examine them you know what's wrong with them and then you can diagnose them, which is why this verb is to examine.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 見る, which you have to do when you are examining a patient. So, you look and see all you can about the patient while you examine them, making this reading み as well.

sentences: 赤ちゃんがちゃんと育っているのか、お医者さんに診てもらいたいんです。
I want a doctor to examine my baby to see if she’s growing well.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means dry. This verb vocab version is to get dry, to become dry, or to be dried. You're not doing the drying, it's just happening. That's coo', you say, things can get dry all by themselves.
mnemonics.reading: The 川 (かわ) has started to get dry. Need to use less water around here otherwise it'll become completely dry.

sentences: 洗濯物はまだ乾いていません。
Our laundry hasn’t dried yet.
プランターの土が乾いてきたので水をやりました。
The soil in the planter was getting dry, so I gave it some water.
「足を三発撃たれたみたいだ」と、ビエトは乾いた声で言った。
"Looks like I got shot in the leg three times," Viet said in a dry voice.

mnemonics.meaning: Remember 迷う? It means "to get lost." If you get lost on a road, you are still lost, wandering around looking for the correct turn. This word means to be lost or to get lost.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the words 道 and 迷う.

sentences: 私は道に迷うのが得意です。
I’m good at getting lost.

mnemonics.meaning: What's that feeling when your belly stands up? It's that feeling where something jumps up into your throat (in this case your belly) and you get all pissed off. This word means to get mad.
mnemonics.reading: The readings are 腹 plus 立つ put together. The たつ becomes だつ, though.

sentences: 本気で腹立つんだけど。練習のジャマだわ！
It makes me so mad. They are in the way of our practice!

mnemonics.meaning: カツ comes from the word "cutlet" and means just that. And a pork カツ is what any Japanese food fan will probably know as simply tonkatsu, aka breaded pork cutlet.
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi of 豚. You haven't learned that yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you: You really like breaded pork cutlet so you just ate a whole ton (とん) of it. Imagine how you feel after eating a ton of tonkatsu.

sentences: この辺は、豚カツ屋が少ない。
There aren't many tonkatsu restaurants around here.
豚カツ定食にしようと思います。
I think I'll have the breaded pork cutlet set meal.
あーーー、なんで昨日あんなに豚カツ食べちゃったんだろう。
Ahhh, why did I eat so much tonkatsu yesterday?

meanings: to get to the bottom of

mnemonics.meaning: 極める is "to carry to extremes." If you carry something to the extremes (aka the end), and then you see it to the extremes while doing it, you're going to see through whatever you're doing.
mnemonics.reading: The readings come from the words 見る and 極める put together. See through this word and learn it.

sentences: 自分のこの目で真実を見極めたいんです。
I want to see the truth with my own eyes.

mnemonics.meaning: 眠い is "sleepy." The verb version is to sleep. *yawn*
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 眠い.

sentences: 「ぐっすり眠れた？」「ああ。爆睡したよ。」
"Did you sleep well?" "Yeah, I crashed."

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed, this word means to stuff in, as in you're doing the stuffing. You know that this is the case because when it comes to the mail (める), you stuff that mail into the garbage as hard as you can (it's all junk).
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the kanji, so you should have no troubles here.

sentences: お弁当にご飯を詰めといてくれない？
Can you put some rice in my bento box for me?

mnemonics.meaning: A person requests something, so you are the one to take it. You're really nice to accept their request. What a nice person you are!
mnemonics.reading: What's another word for "to accept" or "to receive"? How about 受ける? They share a reading!

sentences: お前の顔を立てるためだけにこの仕事を請けたんだからな。
I only took this job so that you could save face.

mnemonics.meaning: If 誘惑 is temptation, then the verb version would be to tempt.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know the word 誘惑 first, though.

sentences: 彼女はたくさんの男を誘惑する悪魔だ。
She is a devil who seduces many men.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means tighten, so the verb vocab version is to tighten.
mnemonics.reading: What can you do if you want something to tighten or to become tight? You need to hug your sheep (し) really close until... The sheep tightens into a tiny little ball. Cute!

sentences: このシートベルトは自動的に締まってくれます。
This seat belt tightens on its own.
大西さんの体はよく締まっていますね〜。
Mr Onishi's body is well toned isn't it!
初めての管理職ということで、身の引き締まる思いをしています。
This is my first managerial position and I’m very tense.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means urge so the verb vocab version is to urge.
mnemonics.reading: Someone with a weird accent is trying to urge you to eat "Unagah" (うなが). This person really means "unagi," and this person also doesn't realize how delicious unagi is (and thinks he's tricking you). You ask him what "Unagah" is. Go ahead and say it out loud.

sentences: お天気のお姉さんが、視聴者に傘を持って行くよう促した。
The weather lady urged viewers to take their umbrellas with them.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means visit and the verb vocab version is also to visit. What makes it different from 訪ねる, though? With 訪ねる, you're going somewhere or visiting someone with a clear purpose. With 訪れる, the emphasis is on the act of visiting a place (and not a person), regardless of purpose. So, if you're simply saying that you're going to go visit the Kiyomizu Temple in Kyoto, you could say 訪れる. On the other hand, if you're visiting the Kiyomizu Temple to discover something, or you're going to pay a visit to a teacher in Kyoto for some advice, you could use 訪ねる. Those uses we just described for 訪れる are for when it is transitive. However, it can also be intransitive, if the action is done by something rather than someone. In that case, it means "to come", as in "winter comes" (冬が訪れる) or "peace comes" (平和が訪れる). 訪ねる, on the other hand, cannot be used in this way.
mnemonics.reading: The reading isn't the same as 訪ねる, though, I'm afraid. It's おとず, so think how this verb is the one where you do have a (fun) purpose to visit wherever you're visiting. That being said, you forgot what you were visiting as well. When you finally remember, it's because you were looking down to think. It's to look at the toes of the giant Buddha statue. "Oh Toes!" (おとず) you exclaim.

sentences: もしあのラーメン工場に訪れたいのであれば、できるだけ早くに予約を入れる方がいいですよ。
If you want to visit the ramen factory you should make your reservations as far in advance as possible.

mnemonics.meaning: Two cups of liquid equals two cups of liquid, aka two cups.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 電車が運行を見合わせている間に、珈琲を二杯飲みました。
I had two cups of coffee while railroad operation was suspended.

mnemonics.meaning: If 健康 is "health," then something that is not this is unhealthy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 健康 first.

sentences: 不健康な野球選手についてのテレビ番組は、全国放送される予定ですよ。
The TV show about unhealthy baseball players will be broadcasted nationwide.

mnemonics.meaning: I'm so for this I'm willing to sponsor you. I am going to urge you to do this until you do it, so much so I'll give you money. This is one great urge and press for you to do this!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どうすれば顧客に未払分の支払手続きを丁寧かつ強く催促することができるのでしょうか。
How can I press a customer to take action on his overdue payment politely but also strongly?

mnemonics.meaning: Things are tense and we have to hurry! This is quite the urgent emergency!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 緊急地震速報を携帯で受信した三秒後に、地震が起きました。
Three seconds after receiving an emergency earthquake report on my cellphone, the earthquake occurred.

mnemonics.meaning: In the body, liquids accumulate. It can be the body of a cup, a body of a bucket, or the body of your body. Whatever it is, this body accumulation represents the volume of liquid in your body.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 父さんにガレージの体積を測るように言われたんだけど、理由は知らないよ。何か変だよね。
My dad told me to measure the volume of our garage, but I don’t know why. It seems kind of weird to me.

mnemonics.meaning: The zen religion is a part of Buddhism. It is the Zen Sect of Buddhism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その禅宗に関する映画は、この映画館で上映中です。
The movie about the Zen sect of Japanese Buddhism is playing at this theater.

mnemonics.meaning: See the rolling hills with the road going off into the background to another hill? That's why this is the hills radical.

In the ground of the rice paddy is a treasure. You pull it out of the mucky ground. This will renew your life for the better. Again, this treasure will change your life! Pull out the treasure. Think about all the things you will be able to renew in your life. Your car. Your boat. Your house. You lost it all but now you'll be able to get it back.
mnemonics.reading: Again, you are going to renew your life! Everything will be better. Then, the person who caused all this grief grabs your treasure and runs. こういち is running off with the treasure that was supposed to renew your life! Yell at こういち to give your treasure back. Then, fall to the muck as you realize you won't be able to renew your life anymore.

mnemonics.meaning: A demon on a jet is pretty alluring. Demons themselves are pretty intriguing, but put one on a jet? Now that’s alluring. See this demon flying around in his jet. Do you feel allured? You should. Hear the roar of the jet engine as the demon cackles.
