mnemonics.reading: This alluring demon on a jet wants one thing and one thing only. Meat (み). Human meat. This demon needs human meat to survive so he is taking his jet into the city to feast on some meat. The demon won’t be so alluring once you see him scarfing down humans, tearing the meat from their bones. How gross.

mnemonics.meaning: You fly north to the moon and break your back when you finally land on it. You weren’t braced for impact so when you hit the moon, your back took all of the impact. Imagine flying north to the moon. Feel the force of being rocketed through space on your journey. Now feel your spine telescope and your back break. It really hurts.
mnemonics.reading: Your back hurts so much that the only way to properly explain the pain is in haiku (はい) form.  I flew to the moon. It is there I broke my back. My back hurts real bad. Say this haiku out loud. Memorize it and use this haiku to remember this kanji.

mnemonics.meaning: A horse gets trapped in a small room with a stool and an insect, and together they create a very boisterous situation. The horse and the insect are both scrambling frantically to get out of the small room, knocking the stool around all over the place. Imagine the boisterous sounds coming from this small room. Hear the horse neigh and stomp his hooves, hear the insect buzzing loudly, and hear the wooden stool rattle around as the horse and insect try to escape the room.
mnemonics.reading: At the height of their boisterous sounds, there's a sudden, awful CRONCH(!) and you see the soul (そう) of the insect slowly rising out of the room, through the ceiling. The horse gets even more frightened now that it killed the insect and saw an actual soul float by its head and it grows even more boisterous.

mnemonics.meaning: When you eat you want to see the shape of your gun from under a towel, so you decorate your house with them. Just picture it: an entire home decorated top to bottom with guns covered in towels, so only the outline shows. As your guests try to eat you say, "Guess what gun this is?! Haha, you got it wrong, pull the towel back."
mnemonics.reading: If you actually decorate your house like this it will give people quite a shock (しょく). In fact, they might be so shocked they run out of there screaming. Maybe you should be more conscious of other people when you decorate. Or at least, don't shock people into fainting or yelling or leaving. Guns do that, you know?

mnemonics.meaning: If you want to buy a geoduck you have to go to the bank beforehand to deposit enough money. If you don't deposit your money you won't have enough in your account to buy even one! They're expensive, after all. Imagine yourself depositing your money beforehand. Imagine the delicious geoduck you'll be able to buy now that the money has been deposited into your account!
mnemonics.reading: You go to the bank to make the deposit and there is a kid standing in your way playing with a yo-yo (よ). You try to squeeze past and he hits you in the face with the yo-yo! Now you can't see! Now you can't make the deposit! Imagine trying to make a deposit to your bank after getting hit in the face with a yo-yo. You can hardly see what you're shoving your money into. You hope it isn't the hands of the kid that hit you!

mnemonics.meaning: If you are anti one sided paper you should bind them all up into an edition. One sided paper is just anti everything. It's bad for the environment. It's bad for easy reading. Put all those one sided papers together into one, big edition instead.
mnemonics.reading: The first edition you create is a fan fiction all about the adventures of Han (はん) Solo. You hated how short and one sided his story in Star Wars seemed to be, and trying to keep track of it all was really hard. But not anymore! Please read my super special Han Solo edition of the Star Wars story. I ripped out all the one sided pages that had him in it and put them into a single edition together so it's just the good stuff now.

mnemonics.meaning: You've made yourself a tree bookshelf (that is, a bookshelf cut into a tree), so you build a fence to keep the riffraff out. Your tree bookshelf is often being raided by the neighbors, and since it's outside, all you can do is build a fence around it to protect it. Better check out that fence-building book in your tree bookshelf.
mnemonics.reading: On your fence, you hang up a sack (さく) to accept donations. People put money and books in your fence sack to keep your tree bookshelf well stocked.

mnemonics.meaning: Traveling in the direction of the ocean, you take a gun and shoot a crab, then stick a flag in the beach and claim it as your own. The crab was the only thing standing in the way of you conquering the area. Now that the flag is in the ground, no one can dispute who it belongs to. Look at your flag and hear it flapping in the wind. Also hear your ears ringing a bit from when you shot that crab. Look at all the bits of exploded crab strewn around the area. Yowza.
mnemonics.reading: To make sure that no one removes your flag, you lock it to one of the lifeguard posts and you throw away the key (き). Since no one will have the key to unlock the flag, no one will be able to remove it. Picture yourself locking this flag up with your key. Imagine turning the key in the lock and hearing the click when it is secured.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami knocks a cleat off a child and the shoe begins to float away in the water. This child was just out playing soccer, minding his own business, when the tsunami crashed in and knocked his cleats off his feet. Now the cleat is floating away with the tsunami. Your cleat is floating away but you’re floating too. The water is really deep now, but you try and float towards your cleat to retrieve it. Imagine floating in this wet water reaching for your lost cleat.
mnemonics.reading: While you float in the water, an uni (う) jabs into your foot. “Uwaaa~ (うわ)” you cry. That uni really hurts. They’re all spikey and painful and junk. “Uwaaaa~” Say “Uwaaa~” out loud a few times while you imagine an うに stabbing you as you float along with the tsunami water. What a day you’ve had.

mnemonics.meaning: You run every day and soon you become a human that can go beyond the normal speed limits of man. You run and you run and you run. This training allows you to become super human. You go beyond the limits of a normal human. You become a human who can run really fast. Run fast! Go beyond the limits imposed upon you by nature! Imagine yourself running faster than any human has ever run ever. Feel yourself cutting through the air, wind breaking across you as you break the sound barrier. Boom!
mnemonics.reading: To solidify your ability to go beyond the abilities of other humans, you etch (えつ) sacred runes into your legs to preserve your running abilities. Etching these runes makes sure that your skills will never deteriorate. Etch these runes into your legs. Go ahead and run a finger over your legs and pretend to etch runes into them. These runes you etch will allow you to run fast forever.

mnemonics.meaning: The sun is being called on to boil the earth by illuminating it. We don't want the earth to actually boil, but we do want some of that boiling hot sun light to illuminate all of the darkness of the universe and let us see.
mnemonics.reading: The person who calls the sun asking it to illuminate the earth is the Shougun (しょう). It's very specifically the Shougun's responsibility to make sure the earth is illuminated every morning. Picture the Shougun calling out to the sun, asking it to illuminate our planet with its boiling hot rays. You better thank the Shougun the next time you see him for everything he does for you.

mnemonics.meaning: A tsunami rips a flag off your house in the rain, causing a leak where it was ripped out. The rain and the tsunami combined just tore the flag right off your house. The force was so strong that it actually removed part of the wall, and now you have a leak in your home. Look at this leak in your house and see the rain water coming in. Hear it drip drip dripping down the wall.
mnemonics.reading: The leak is getting worse and worse and so is the tsunami, when you see something outside. It’s a bunch of roe (ろう) floating in the waves. Using your quick thinking skills you scoop it up and shove it into the cracks where the water is leaking in. It works like a charm! Did you know that roe can plug any leak? It’s true. If you don’t mind wasting some, you should break a leak into your own house and then try to plug it back up again with some salmon roe.

mnemonics.meaning: The lineage radical and the lineage kanji are the same. Know your radicals, yo!
mnemonics.reading: You trace your lineage back and realize that every single person in your family loved cake (けい). Most of them were cake bakers, too! You come from a lineage of cake makers and eaters. No wonder you love cake so much! (And if you hate cake, no wonder your family doesn't like you.)

mnemonics.meaning: A servant holding a gun sits on the ground to see if he can find something to look at. The servant is on watch duty and has the gun to protect the perimeter. He patrols the grounds to look at the distance to see if there are any trespassers. Look at this servant. He’s doing a great job. Oops, looks like he sees you. Yup, he’s pointing his gun at you. Imagine staring down the barrel of his gun as you slowly back away.
mnemonics.reading: You start backing away, but then you realize that you are Macho Man Randy (らん) Savage. Randy Savage backs away from no fight! I mean, look at this guy – this servant guy. Take away the gun and he’s not much to look at. You can take him. Pretend you are Macho Man Randy Savage. Run at this servant guy, take his gun away, and beat him up. Ohhh yeaaahhh!

mnemonics.meaning: You meet a woman from another clan under the rising sun to prepare for marriage. Your clan and her clan are standing together as the two of you watch the sun rise together. Marriage is a big deal and it's going to connect your two clans, so you have to do the ceremony in the sun in front of everyone so they can see.
mnemonics.reading: For the marriage to be official, you need to wait for a condor (こん) to appear. If it doesn't show up before the sun goes down again, the marriage was a failure. You have to try again tomorrow with a different woman. Do you want to go through with this marriage? You better hope you see a condor then! It's the official bird of love and unification, ya know. That's why so many people wait until they're older to get married these days, because there aren't as many condors thanks to deforestation.

mnemonics.meaning: Your soul will cross through your body and into the net of your clothes so that you'll be hit with nostalgia when you wear them again. Nostalgia for all the things that happened every single time you wore those clothes. When you put on an old piece of clothing, a shirt maybe, or some pants, feel the nostalgia that was embedded in it and left there by your soul.
mnemonics.reading: This nostalgia ties knots (なつ) in your stomach and your chest. Even if the memories and feelings weren't particularly bad, there's something about the wistful feeling of nostalgia that knots up your insides. Feel these nostalgic knots inside you. Now tie knots in the clothes that make you feel nostalgic so you don't wear them again.

mnemonics.meaning: You put your fingers and an ear on a stool in the sun so you can get your photograph taken. This is a glamour photo, so you have to be in one of these weird, cheesy poses for it to come out jusssst right. Imagine putting your fingers and your ear on a stool, now try to relax your head a little bit, and smile for the camera. This is a professional photograph, so you better do what you're told!
mnemonics.reading: As you're getting the photograph taken, the photographer suddenly gets angry at you. "You sat (さつ) down!" he screams. "I sat down?" you ask. "Yes! And now the photo is ruined!" You've never gotten a professional photograph taken before, but if you had known if you sat(s) down you'd ruin the shot you never would have. Remember everyone, if you sat down while your photo was being taken, you ruined it.

mnemonics.meaning: The tree pirate jumps from a tree and attacks you by hitting you with a pillow. It hurts a little bit, but the fact that tree pirates use pillows as their weapons is a bit anticlimactic.
mnemonics.reading: As he hits you with his pillow he makes a demand: "Give me your Mac cooler (まくら). He wants the device that cools down your Mac computer. You give him your Mac cooler and he goes on his way. He's quite happy he can cool down his Mac, now. The trees are quite warm and he hears this will help to cool down his tree apples.

mnemonics.meaning: On a scooter running in one direction is a gun-toting child. This is a terribly dangerous situation, but to the child it is just play. Imagine a child riding a scooter with a gun having a good time. "Come play with me!" they shout. "No!" you yell back.
mnemonics.reading: Everything is play for youths (ゆう), even if it's a terrible, scary, not good situation like this one. Imagine trying to explain to the youth that this is not play and that they should stop, but them youths can't stop playing. P.S. From the WaniKani staff to you: Don't let youths play with guns, please.

mnemonics.meaning: The soul of a person has a hook that can make them pleasant. When you see, hear, or feel something pleasant, can't you feel that hook pressing into the middle of your body? Imagine that feeling you get when everything is just SO pleasant. There is a pressure from your soul's hook digging in. It's a good feeling though, a pleasant one! It isn't too hard or too soft.
mnemonics.reading: If you want to feel this pleasant feeling just look at a kayak (かい). Kayaks are the most pleasant boats in the world. Feel that pleasant feeling in your chest just from reading about kayaks in this mnemonic right now. Go look up pictures of kayaks to get some of that pleasant high. Mm, your soul is hooking you real good.

mnemonics.meaning: Those that can only eat a part of a shellfish are probably a bit poor. Poor people can't even afford a whole shellfish. They have to settle with just a part.
mnemonics.reading: And since they are poor, they are getting these shellfish parts from the trash bin (びん). It's quite unfortunate. Imagine a poor person going through a garbage bin to find only a part of of a shellfish. What a sad sight.

mnemonics.meaning: If you do yoga correctly, you will not only prolong your body but your life! Do you want to prolong your life? Then do yoga correctly!
mnemonics.reading: You can prolong your life with correct yoga techniques, but unfortunately, if you ever stop doing yoga after you've started this prolonging process, it will just end (えん) suddenly. Correct yoga will prolong your life but no yoga will end it. Do you think that's a fair trade?

mnemonics.meaning: Take your fingers, put them on this turtle shell, and push push push! Push the turtle right on out of there. Picture yourself using your fingers to push a turtle out of its shell. It really doesn't want to leave, so you have to push really hard.
mnemonics.reading: You're trying to push this turtle out so you can use the shell for your new obi (お). You keep seeing other people wearing turtle shell patterns on their obi, but you're going to go a step further. You're going to MAKE your obi out of actual turtle shells! You just have to push this darn turtle out first. Imagine pushing some turtle shells flat to make a beautiful obi. Wear it out, watch everyone gasp in awe. Oh... oh no! They're trying to push you out of your obi like you did the turtle. They're mad about your turtle crime!

mnemonics.meaning: If you look for a leaf among the hills you will notice they are scarce. The hills have no trees around them, so there are no leaves. The leaves are scarce here on the hills. Imagine being on the hills. You want a leaf to find and take back as a souvenir but there are none. Imagine looking feverishly for a leaf even though you don’t really expect to find one.
mnemonics.reading: Still looking for a leaf, you determine that they are far too scarce to find here. Just before you give up, you discover a giant bowling (ぼう) ball. As you pick it up, another one comes thundering down the hill knocking over a tiny tree. Leaves are scarce here because someone is using these hills for their bowling. The bowling balls knock over everything, and leaves can't grow.

mnemonics.meaning: You're in prison and all you have is a spoon. You use that prison spoon to scoop up nice scents and fragrances out of the air when you have outdoor time and bring them back into your cell. It smells really bad in prison, but your prison spoon is full of all of the lovely scents you remember from when you were free.
mnemonics.reading: You can't remember what any of these scents are anymore, you've been in prison for so long, so you call them all neo-scents (にお). They're neo, they're new. Try to come up with some neo-scents right now. This is neo-laundry, this is neo-flowers, and this is neo-delicious-steak I'll never get to eat because I'm in prison sniffing a spoon.

mnemonics.meaning: The next plate is the one you will steal. This one would be too obvious, better wait for the next one. Wait for this next plate. Here it is—now steal it! Imagine stealing this plate and making off with it.
mnemonics.reading: You steal this plate from a とうきょう restaurant, so after you steal it, picture yourself running through the streets of とうきょう as you lose your pursuers. Be careful not to drop that plate! Wouldn’t want to steal something just to break it. Imagine running through the streets of とうきょう. See all the sights and hear all the sounds. Just don’t get too distracted, you gotta get to a safe place and stash your stolen plate away.

mnemonics.meaning: Picture a shellfish lifeguard. They're not going anywhere. First, they're a shellfish, so they can't really move. And, they're a lifeguard, so they need to be in their lifeguard tower. How does this shellfish lifeguard get stuff? Through subscription services. See a bunch of subscription boxes around the lifeguard tower. It gets everything this way.
mnemonics.reading: The shellfish lifeguard's favorite subscription is its subscription to こういち magazine. It has all the latest こういち versions, news, and interviews.  See the shellfish lifeguard drooling as its こういち magazine subscription arrives. "I will read this one now, but I can't wait until next month," it says as a boat sinks in the distance. Hint: when you see the "lifeguard" radical, the reading is probably going to be こう.

mnemonics.meaning: A scooter with a mohawk, now that's the most suitable hairstyle you could ever think of for a scooter! You keep seeing scooters all over the city with mohawks and you can't get it out of your head that it's the most suitable thing you've ever seen.
mnemonics.reading: You want this suitable hairstyle for your scooter too, and luckily you're a techie (てき), so it's easy for you to install one. Imagine going online to check out some of your techie message boards and learning the most suitable mohawk for your scooter then installing it yourself.

mnemonics.meaning: There are some feathers resting on a stand and you and the following of the feathers are following the feathers. The feathers have a following, and you are one member of the following. You and your fellow followers follow the feathers wherever they may go. Imagine you and the following following the feathers all around. Following the feathers isn’t always easy, but you do it anyway. Imagine touching one of the feathers and feeling the smooth texture on your skin.
mnemonics.reading: While you and the following are following the feathers from their departure from the stand, one of the members of the following drops an egg and yolk (よく) spills everywhere. What a mess! Being a quick thinker, you use one of the feathers to soak up the yolk and clean up the mess. Imagine cleaning up egg yolk with a feather. The rest of the following follows your example and takes the other feathers, helping you clean up the yolk.

mnemonics.meaning: You're stuck in a prison on the sun with nothing but a spoon. Lucky for you a tsunami is coming, so you take your spoon and use the tsunami to quench your thirst. You spoon the hot, hot water into your mouth as fast as you can. This is the only way to get water on the sun. Imagine this thirst of yours. You've been in this sun prison for longer than you can remember. You've been holding onto this spoon, waiting for this moment for so long.
mnemonics.reading: This method of quenching your thirst reminds you of being in a car wash (かわ). The water pours over you in waves, and you're stuck inside a metal cage. Totally the same thing as a car wash, right? Imagine quenching your thirst in a real car wash. Open your mouth and let the soapy water dump on over and in you. You'll never be thirsty again!

mnemonics.meaning: You take some bamboo and attach it together into a token of appreciation for your friend. Your friend greatly appreciates this token of friendship. Imagine trying to attach some bamboo together into a token for someone.
mnemonics.reading: You hand over the token but your friend drops it and yells, "You fool (ふ)! I'm allergic to bamboo!" Imagine the embarrassment you feel, forgetting they were allergic to bamboo. Oh well, it’s the thought that counts. You’re still a fool, though.

mnemonics.meaning: If a tsunami hits, it's raining, and you're outside trying to use a rake, you're going to be very wet and damp. Imagine how wet and damp you'd be with tsunami water up to your knees and rain pouring down on your head. You struggle with your rake anyway.
mnemonics.reading: You can't stand how wet and damp you feel in these clothes so you rip them off and rake in the nude (ぬ)! You're still wet, but at least you don't have the feeling of damp clothes touching your body now. You'll have to be really careful raking in the nude though.

mnemonics.meaning: You are floating above everything, at least that's how your spirit feels. You're having an affair, and feel like nothing will catch you but... wait, what's that? Is that your wife? Oh no... not floating anymore, you're not.
mnemonics.reading: This kanji uses the kun'yomi read for the first kanji, and the on'yomi reading for the second. You've learned them both already, so you should be able to read this too.

sentences: 「彼は浮気をして、それを携帯電話を持っていないあなたのせいにしたってこと？」「要約するとそんなところね。」
"So he had an affair and then blamed it on you for not having a cellphone?" "That about sums it up."

mnemonics.meaning: The alluring power is the power of allure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私はゴルフの魅力に取り憑かれてしまいました。
I became obsessed with the charm of golf.

mnemonics.meaning: One look at... just one. A little one. Just a look. Just a glance. That's all I want. It also has another meaning! When you're talking about computers and you want to see everything in one look, you will arrange it into a nice list or table. That way you only have to look at the data one time!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 連絡先の一覧から中々上司の名前が見つからないんだけど。
I’m struggling to find my boss’s name on my contact list.

mnemonics.meaning: You change again. This is more along the lines of an alteration, because you changed once in order to get to where you are, and then you get changed again to become altered, which is why it's an alteration (though change works too).
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 上司に、もっとお互いのメリットを強調するような企画書に変更するように言われました。
My boss told me to alter the business proposal so that it emphasized the mutual benefits more.

mnemonics.meaning: The play park ground is where you go play. It's fun. It's an amusement park!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 「スカイダイビングをして、その後遊園地に行くんだけど、一緒に行かない？」「えーっ、絶対に嫌！」
"I am going to go skydiving then afterwards go to a theme park. You want to join me?" "What? Absolutely not!"

mnemonics.meaning: Everything is suitable and right. Therefore it is appropriate, proper, and suitable. Strangely enough, this also means irresponsible. Maybe it's because when everything is suitable and right for you, you're taking too much and not leaving enough for everyone else, making you irresponsible?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 適当な答えを選んでください。
Please choose the appropriate answer.
あいつは適当な事ばかり言っている。
That guy often says irresponsible things.
居酒屋で、同僚が店員に「適当にお願いします」と言って注文をしたことに驚きました。
I was surprised when my colleague was ordering in an izakaya and said to the waitress: "Choose whatever you think is best".

mnemonics.meaning: The clothes with which I decorate myself with is my attire or my fashion.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私は服飾専門学校を卒業しました。
I graduated from a fashion technical school.
今の服飾の仕事は、遊び半分でしてるんですよ。
I'm working in the clothing business now, mostly for fun.
コイツ、今、服飾の専門学生と付き合ってるんだよ。
That guy's dating a fashion student.

mnemonics.meaning: The previous extent of time was a while ago. Just think to a previous extent of time that was indeed a while ago, now, associate!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the words 先 and 程, put together.

sentences: 先程あなたからの手紙を読ませて頂きました。
I read the letter from you some time ago.

mnemonics.meaning: The back scene is the scene going on in the back. You don't really notice it, because it's the background.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグの本社を背景にして写真を撮ってもらえませんか。
Could you take my picture with the Tofugu headquarters in the background?

mnemonics.meaning: Something that's behind your back is in the background. It's also probably plotting against you, behind the scenes. Sneaky, sneaky.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. As long as you know the readings for these kanji, you should be able to read this word just fine.

sentences: 背後に敵が潜んでいたことに全く気づかなかった。
I completely didn’t notice the enemy lurking in the background.

mnemonics.meaning: Deposit your gold here in the bank. When you do that, it is a bank deposit.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は帆立の養殖で稼いだ金は全て預金している。
He deposits all the money he earns from raising scallops.

mnemonics.meaning: If 官僚 is "bureaucracy," then adding a 的 to it would make it bureaucratic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Knowing 官僚 will help a lot too.

sentences: この会社では官僚的な形式主義がまかり通りすぎている。
There’s too much bureaucratic red tape in this company.

mnemonics.meaning: You are strong so you break into someone's home, hold them up, then steal from them. Ha ha! Take that, next door neighbor! This is a burglary / robbery, depending on how crazy you get after you use that strength to break down that door.
mnemonics.reading: The reading for 強 is all messed up. Think about how when you commit a robbery, you go (ごう) into someone's house, then you go to jail as well, if you're caught.

sentences: 銀行強盗をやってみないか？今を逃がすと一生ないよ。
Do you want to rob a bank? It’s now or never.

mnemonics.meaning: You have edition rights over this. This edition is yours, and if anyone copies this edition, they get in trouble. You have copyright.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この手紙には、版権に関する契約更新予定日が記載されています。
This letter states the possible contract renewal date for the copyright.

mnemonics.meaning: The 電 is what powers electric things. Many times, these electric things light up (especially back in the day, when electricity did this a lot more than other things). So, you have "lighting." Then, you have decorate. So, if you decorate with lighting, you have decorative lighting.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 省エネのために電飾にOAタップを使ってるって聞いたんだけど、タコ足配線にするのは危ないわよ。
I heard that you use power strips for decorative lighting to eliminate wasted energy, but you might overload the circuits so it’s dangerous.

mnemonics.meaning: If you combine 電気 (electricity) with 柵 (fence) you have an electric fence. Shocking, I know.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: 電気柵を張りめぐらせる畑が増えている。
More and more fields are surrounded by electric fences.
お父さんが電気柵を設置してくれたんです。
My dad installed the electric fence.
イノシシや猿への対策として、電気柵を導入した。
We've installed electric fences as a countermeasure against wild boars and monkeys.

mnemonics.meaning: Someone who has to shift their dwelling is someone who moves their home (and in this case) to another country. They are an emigrant / immigrant. Welcome to this country, friend!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 国外移住者になるのは容易なことではない。
It’s not easy to be an international immigrant.

mnemonics.meaning: An exhibition that you look at and all the people come meet together. Well, that just sounds like the description of an exposition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この博覧会は無料で入場できます。
You can enter this exhibition free of charge.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. Isn't that fencetastic?
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the on'yomi, which you learned with the kanji. Just think about the sack (さく) hanging on the fence.

sentences: 柵に足がはさまって抜けない。
My leg got stuck in the fence and I can't get it out.
今日の午後は柵をペンキでぬります。
I'll paint the fence this afternoon.
その犬は柵を軽々と跳び越えてしまった。
That dog jumped over the fence so easily.

mnemonics.meaning: The first edition is the first edition.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼の小説の初版は半年で売り切れた。
The first edition of his novel sold out in six months.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  The one with the flag is the Mad Hatter (はた). Just imagine looking through a group of people. You have to find the Mad Hatter, and he has to find you. That's why he offered to wear a flag on his hat.

sentences: 私は可愛い爪楊枝の旗を衝動買いしてしまいました。
I bought the cute toothpick flags on impulse.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are almost exactly the same, but instead of just meaning again it also means furthermore and moreover. This is one of those good paragraph-starting essay words!
mnemonics.reading: The reading is a bit different from what you learned with the kanji, though. Just think about how again he dropped the 皿 (さら). Wow, what a screw up. Again and again.

sentences: 留学後、更に英語を上達させるには、ネイティブスピーカーと喋り続ける必要があります。
After studying abroad you need to continue speaking to native speakers to further improve your English.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You did not learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Say (せ) your height right now. Say it. SAY IT. Imagine I'm getting all in your face, saying "say it" at you.

sentences: 紫色のドレスを着ている背の高い女性は、あなたのご友人ですか？
Is your friend the tall woman in the purple dress?

mnemonics.meaning: It's pleasant but also fast. When getting on a train, it's nice to find a train that's both of these things. What makes it pleasant? That would be the high speed. What makes it fast? Also the high speed. Really, if you're on a train you'd rather get to your destination sooner than later, so a high speed 快速 train is the way to go.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: コウイチは、昨晩、150キロの快速球を投げ込んで才能の違いを見せつけている夢を見た。
Koichi dreamt last night that he showed off his talent of throwing with a 150-kilometer-per-hour fastball.

mnemonics.meaning: You know that 旅行 is a trip. The other part is new marriage. What's the trip you go on after a new marriage? The honeymoon!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 新婚旅行でハワイに行くのが待ちきれないよ〜。円高の恩恵にあやかって、お金使い果たすぐらい買い物しまくるつもり！笑
I can’t wait to go to Hawaii for my honeymoon! Yen is high, so I’m going to spend all my money on shopping. Haha.

mnemonics.meaning: Illuminate and make things bright, my illumination!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 照明器具の周りを蠅が2-3匹ブンブン飛び交っている。
A couple of flies are buzzing around the lighting equipment.

mnemonics.meaning: Ready for this one? An iron fence  is an iron fence. Don't you love it when it's straightforward?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Be careful though, 鉄 is normally read as てつ, but in this case it is shortened to てっ.

sentences: そこに鉄柵をめぐらすのはどうでしょう。
How do you feel about enclosing that with an iron fence?
出来るだけ早く鉄柵を修理しないといけません。
I have to repair the iron fence as soon as possible.
見て！鉄柵に何か引っかかっているよ。
Look! Something's caught on the iron fence.

mnemonics.meaning: If you become aware of something to an extent you'll end up saying I see or That's right! But you won't see if you didn't become aware enough. So it's that extent of understanding you're trying to reach before you can chime in with an "Ahh, indeed."
mnemonics.reading: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. The reading for 成 is from 成る and it keeps the る part. It's just hidden in the kanji. If you can remember that, you'll know this reading!

sentences: 成程、これなら誰にも見つからずに手紙を出すことができる。
I see! I can send this letter without anyone finding out.

mnemonics.meaning: The 日 is the 日 in 日本, making it mean Japanese in this word. If you are Japanese in lineage then you are of Japanese descent.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私の妻は日系アメリカ人の三世です。
My wife is a third generation American of Japanese descent.

mnemonics.meaning: If 幼稚 is childish, then a garden for childish people would be a place full of lots of children, probably growing in some way. When you're growing little children in a garden, you're putting them into some kind of school. In this case, it's a kindergarten.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 幼稚 as well.

sentences: 幼稚園のクリスマス会のスケジュールをまた微調整しなくちゃいけないかもしれないの。
We might have to make another small adjustment to the kindergarten Christmas party schedule.

mnemonics.meaning: We are lacking and things are scarce. We have a lack and scarcity of resources.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ビタミンDが欠乏しているかどうかはどうすれば分かりますか。
How can I know if I’m deficient in Vitamin D?

mnemonics.meaning: Something is leaking and whatever is leaking is exiting what it was in before. This is when a leak occurs.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ﻿全壊したビルからガスが漏出して危険だから近寄らないように。
Gas is leaking from the totally destroyed building and it's dangerous, so don't get near.
トーフグの機密情報が漏出してしまったようです。
It appears that confidential information about Tofugu has been leaked.
原油の海への漏出事故を防ぐために、どんな手段を講じていますか。
What kind of measures does your company take to prevent accidental leakage of crude oil into the sea?

mnemonics.meaning: You'll hear this a lot of in polite speech, used in place of 見る (it'll be ご覧になって下さい, literally "please become so that you are looking at _____"). The meaning is the same as the kanji, though, so this part should be easy at least. Why don't you ご覧 the reading explanation, now.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji. Go look at the next lesson, now.

sentences: 娘さんの試験の結果はもうご覧になられましたか。
Have you seen your daughter’s examination results yet?

mnemonics.meaning: Let's bind this marriage up with a marriage. No better way to make a marriage happen than a marriage, right?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 「シャーク、私がフグと結婚したってどうして分かったの？」 「ただ人づてに聞いただけさ。」
"Shark, how did you know that I got married to Fugu?" "You know. I just heard it through the grapevine."

mnemonics.meaning: When you request marriage with someone else, you are doing a marriage proposal. Will you marry me, Brad Pitt?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ホタルは、どの求婚者にも、結婚の条件として無理難題を突き付けた。
Hotaru sets impossible tasks for any man who wants to marry her.

mnemonics.meaning: This has a similar meaning to 主人 (head of household). You can remember it also as the meaning you learned with the kanji 主, which is master.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is of course different from what you learned with the kanji. Think of this: The person who was your head of household was very strict. Anytime you did anything that was incorrect or bad, he/she would pull out the noose (ぬし), but would call it a "noosey" to be cute, since you were just a kid.

sentences: この家の主の名前は何ですか。
What is the name of the head of this household?
あの城の主にはあとつぎがいないらしい。
I heard that the master of that castle doesn't have any heirs.
この池には、古池の主と呼ばれる大きな殿様蛙がいると言われています。
It’s said that in this pond there is a huge leopard frog called the master of the old pond.

mnemonics.meaning: 精神 is your spirit, both religiously and spiritually. When those are sick, you have a problem. Back in the day, a mental illness was thought to be a sickness with your spirit. Nowadays you can just call it a mental illness or mental disorder.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you know 精神 already, though.

sentences: 僕の友達は精神病で頭が少しイッちゃてるけど、良い人だよ。
My friend is kind of messed up in the head from some type of mental illness, but he’s a nice guy.

mnemonics.meaning: A country's flag is the flag they use for their nation. It's the national flag.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The こく gets shortened to こっ, though, so look out for that.

sentences: やっべーな。お前この巨大国旗を買ったのかよ？いったいどこに掲げるつもりなの？
No way! You bought this huge national flag? Where the heck are you thinking of putting it up?

mnemonics.meaning: Boisterous sound is when there's a lot of noise around you. It's the din of the crowd or environment.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 騒音問題について、お隣さんにどうやって切り出したらいいんだろう。
How should I approach my neighbor about a noise problem?

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of nostalgia? It's nostalgic.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. Do you remember doing that? Oh man, those were the days. How 懐かしい.

sentences: 懐かしい曲がスピーカーから鳴り響いていました。
A nostalgic song was echoing out of the speakers.

mnemonics.meaning: Here we have I followed by the particle が, giving us a somewhat old-fashioned and stylized way of say our, one's own, or my. One explanation for this is that in ancient Japanese, が was used as a possessive particle, much like の is in modern Japanese.
mnemonics.reading: You haven't learned this reading for 我 so here's a mnemonic to help you: Let you present you with our walrus (わ). Well it's my walrus really, but I'm happy to share.

sentences: 我が家の今日のディナーはエビフライです。
Today's dinner at our house is deep-fried shrimp.
だれだって、結局我が子が一番可愛いんだよ。
In the end, everyone loves their own child the most.
課長、あんたの受け売りをそのまま、我が物顔で言ってたよ。
The section chief was saying exactly what you said, as if it were his own words.

mnemonics.meaning: If you go beyond your rights, you are going too far. You're doing what you're not supposed to do, and you're overstepping your authority.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お巡りさん、差し出がましいようですがそれは越権行為では無いでしょうか。
Officer, I’m afraid you are overstepping your bounds.

mnemonics.meaning: Back in the day, you'd use shadows to photograph things. Now it's all fancy and digital. So, with that in mind, a photograph shadow was someone doing a photoshoot of some kind. And, in even more modern times, it has become a movie shoot as well. More simply, it can be photographing or filming as well. Basically, if it has to do with taking photos or video, 撮影 is your dude.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: お待たせして申し訳ございません。それでは、撮影を始めましょうか。
I’m sorry to have kept you waiting. Let’s start shooting now.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, huzzah!

sentences: 結局夫のために高い枕を買うはめになりました。
I ended up buying an expensive pillow for my husband.

mnemonics.meaning: Steal what other people make? Wow. Way to go. That is plagiarism.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 他人の作品をパクったら、盗作で訴えられるかもしれないよ。
If you stole someone else’s work, you could be sued for plagiarism.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of pleasant? It is also pleasant.
mnemonics.reading: This word's reading is pretty weird. We're going to think back to a couple different words to put this one together. The word for heart (心), is こころ. The word for good is よい (or いい, but for this word's sake, よい). A "good heart (feeling)" is one where your heart feels nice and warm and fuzzy (figuratively, not literally. If it's literal, go to the hospital please). That is a pleasant feeling. A こころよい feeling.

sentences: 彼女の声は小川のせせらぎのように耳にとても快い。
Her voice is very pleasing to the ear, like the babbling of a brook.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is both pleasant and suitable is still really pleasant.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: エアコンのある生活は快適だ。
Life with an air conditioner is pleasant.

mnemonics.meaning: Pleasant comfort brings you a lot of pleasure and you get a lot of enjoyment out of it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: もう少しで、快楽に溺れるところだったわ。
I was close to drowning in pleasure.

mnemonics.meaning: When you have the feeling of pleasantness, you are experiencing pleasure.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 人に恥をかかせることで快感を味合うような人にはなってもらいたくないわ。
I don’t want you to be a person who derives pleasure from humiliating people.

mnemonics.meaning: You are poor and money / food is very scarce for you, making you poor.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: サーモンって本当に物欲が強い女性だよね。フグが言ってるほどお金持って無いって知った途端、彼のこと貧乏って呼んで、振っちゃったんだもんね。
Salmon is a really materialistic girl. When she found out that Fugu didn’t have as much money as he said he did, she called him poor and left him.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of poor? It's poor.
mnemonics.reading: You know the word 先ず (まず)? It means something along the lines of "first of all." So, if you're poor, first of all (まず), you're going to want to get some help. Second of all, learn how to play the guitar and make funny jokes.

sentences: もしまた貧しい環境に陥ったとしても、また億万長者になれるように努力すると思います。
Even if I went back to being poor again, I’d probably still work hard to become a billionaire.

mnemonics.meaning: Prolong it for a long while. We need more time. We need a prolonging or  extension of some kind.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 延長コードがごちゃごちゃになっているのが許せないの。
I can’t stand how extensions cords get tangled up.

mnemonics.meaning: If the extent you go to do something is properly (よく) done, then you did it properly and well!
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading.  You learned this reading already! Nice!

sentences: ひき肉を程よくこねます。
Mix the ground meat well.

mnemonics.meaning: If you exit that edition out of your hands and into the world, you've gotten something published! That is publishing.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その本を出版するのに二年もかかりました。
It took me two years to publish the book.

mnemonics.meaning: When your subscription enters into effect, you have made your purchase. This one's a bit weird because it seems like it should refer to a subscription, but I guess it is a one time subscription, and your subscription lasts your whole life?
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この店で偽のシャネルN°5を購入しました。
This is the store where I bought the fake Chanel Number 5.

mnemonics.meaning: If you create subscriptions to buy things, you're probably in the purchasing department. It's your responsibility to set up subscriptions and buy everything for everyone else because you're the purchasing person.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is on'yomi, which is great for 購 but not as great for 買. Luckily, the reading for 買 is buy (ばい), which is the same as the meaning, which is a pretty awesome coincidence.

sentences: 私は消費者の購買意欲について研究をしています。
I’m researching customers’ purchasing motivations.

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
mnemonics.reading: This has the same reading as the kanji you learned, meaning you know the reading!

sentences: 俺は押しに弱いんだよなあ。
I’m weak-willed to pressure.

mnemonics.meaning: Again you have life! Either this is a rebirth of some kind, or you have received resuscitation and another shot at life. Whatever it is, you have life again, so that's great!
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼女は自分の息子は更生の見込みがあると信じている。
She believes that there is hope of rehabilitation for her son.

mnemonics.meaning: And again it has become new! It was old, but now it's all nice. This is quite the renewal.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 先方は、いくつかの修正を伴う契約更新を提案してきているんだが、あまり気が進まないんだよね。
They are proposing an updated contract with several alterations, but I’m still reluctant.

mnemonics.meaning: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of scarce? It's also scarce.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: When things are scarce, you have to boat (とぼ) all the way across the lake to find any resources or food, as your side of the lake is picked dry.

sentences: 日本語能力だけじゃなく、対人能力も乏しいんです。
Not only are my Japanese abilities lacking, but my personal abilities are too.

mnemonics.meaning: Stealing photographs of you. Wait, you didn't know you were being photographed / filmed? That's secret photography or secret filming Creeeeeepy.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 電車内で居眠りしているところを盗撮されたんです。
Photos were taken of me in secret while I was napping on the train.

mnemonics.meaning: The lineage of the sun (太陽) is that of everything surrounding it. This is the solar system.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help to know 太陽.

sentences: 太陽系には惑星はいくつあるんだっけ？
How many planets does the solar system have?

mnemonics.meaning: Your 精神 is your spirit. If you add 的 to it, your spirit becomes spiritual.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 精神的に病んでいた時、毎日一人で公園をブラブラしていました。
When I was mentally troubled, I was wandering aimlessly around the park alone every day.

mnemonics.meaning: These are stolen (steal) goods. So, I'll give you a deal, because, you know, they're stolen goods.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: ここではみんな盗品を売ってるので、「泥棒市場」と呼ばれています。
People sell stolen goods here, so it’s called "thieves’ market."

mnemonics.meaning: A subscription has been read. Each magazine that comes in you read. This is your subscription.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. The on'yomi for 読 (どく) is the same as the reading in 読者. In case you forgot, think about how you just got a subscription to dock (どく) magazine. It's all about docks and dock related things. How exciting.

sentences: 全アメリカ人がトーフグのニュースレターを購読しているという噂が、日本中に広まった。
The rumor that all American people subscribe to the Tofugu newsletter spread throughout Japan.

mnemonics.meaning: The body of the lineage is part of a bigger system. Add 的 to it, and you have systematic.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 私達は、体系的な日本語学習教材を提供しています。
We are offering systematic Japanese learning material.

mnemonics.meaning: The following day is the day coming the day you're talking about. It's the next day.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 列車は翌日平常運転に戻りました。
The railroad service went back to normal the next day.

mnemonics.meaning: The next moon refers to the next month.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 彼は翌月黄色いドアがある小さな家に引っ越しています。
He is moving to the small house with the yellow door next month.

mnemonics.meaning: The next morning is the next morning.
mnemonics.reading: The reading can be what you've learned with the kanji, よくあさ, or it can be the on'yomi reading across the board, よくちょう. Both are good to remember because よくちょう is more formal (you'll use that reading in writing more often) and よくあさ is more informal - you'll use that in speaking more often.

sentences: 申し訳ありませんが、お客様の足つぼマッサージのご予約は、本日の夜9時から翌朝9時30分にご変更されております。
I’m afraid that your 9:00 p.m. foot-pressure massage has been pushed back to 9:30 tomorrow morning.

mnemonics.meaning: The next year is the next year.
mnemonics.reading: The reading can be the on'yomi for 年 or the kun'yomi. So, you can do either よくねん or よくとし, or preferably both.

sentences: 翌年彼は起業しました。
He started his business the next year.

mnemonics.meaning: A cut token is a token you cut out from a sheet of paper into smaller sheets, and each of these pieces is a ticket.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is 切る cut short to きっ, then ふ rendaku'd to ぷ. It's a bit of a troublesome word, so concentrate on this now a bit so you can get it in the reviews.

sentences: そのツアーの切符は、現地で購入することもできます。
You can buy tickets for that tour on site.

mnemonics.meaning: 攻撃 is an attack. Make that into a verb and you have to attack.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. It will help to know 攻撃 as well.

sentences: 「コウイチ！怒り狂ったライオンの群れが俺たちの町に向かって突撃してくるよ。俺たち、もうすぐ攻撃されちまうよ。どうしたらいいんだ？」「心配するな。俺に任せとけ。」
"Koichi! There’s a pride of raging lions charging toward our town! They are going to attack us very soon. What do we do?" "Don’t worry. Leave it to me."

mnemonics.meaning: When you have a thirst, you tend to become thirsty.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji. Go grab a cup of water so you don't become dehydrated, okay?

sentences: ええっと、喉がカラカラに渇いてたから、ビールを飲み過ぎちゃったんだよね。俺は今、ベロベロだ〜。
Well, I was really thirsty so I drank too much beer. I’m drunk~

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means scent or fragrance so the verb version is to be fragrant or to smell good.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: この香水は、全く匂わない。
This perfume doesn't smell at all.
その工場からは、チョコレートの香りが匂います。
It smells like chocolate from the factory.
春の花畑では、色んな種類のチューリップが匂い、人がたくさん訪れて香りを楽しみます。
In spring, different kinds of tulips are fragrant at the flower garden and people visit to enjoy the smells.

mnemonics.meaning: 怖い is "scary." This is a verb version, making it to be scared or to be afraid of.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 怖い.

sentences: 私の主人は逆さ睫毛の手術を受けるのをとても怖がっていたんですよ。
My husband was very scared of getting surgery for his ingrown eyelashes.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means shift and the verb vocab version is to be shifted. You know that this is the one where something is shifted (and you're not doing the shifting), because it's really rude (る) to be shifted, and you don't like it when people do it to you (because it happens quite a lot, strangely).
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as 移す, so use that to remember this!

sentences: 臭いが服に移るから、焼肉は好きじゃないの。
I don’t like Korean barbecue because the smell gets on your clothes.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means stuffed. The vocab word is to be stuffed, as in something is stuffed and you're not doing the stuffing. You know this because when it comes to まる the cat, he stuffs himself into boxes on his own, so you don't have to stuff him into boxes for him. It just happens, and you can watch and be entertained (obviously you need to go watch some Maru videos if you haven't on YouTube, just saying).
mnemonics.reading: This word uses the reading you learned with the kanji!

sentences: 魚の骨が喉に詰まっちゃった。
I got a fish bone stuck in my throat.

mnemonics.meaning: 冷たい is "cold." This is the verb version, so you're making something cold. This word is to chill something.
mnemonics.reading: To chill something, you need to apply cold, not heat (ひ).

sentences: 指をドアで挟んじゃって、今氷で冷やしてるの。
My finger got caught in the door and I’m chilling it with ice now.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means decorate. The verb vocab version is to decorate.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To decorate something, you don't really need a cause (かざ). You should just do it, just because.

sentences: クリスマスツリーの飾り付けをするのが好きです。今年はツリーを暖炉の横に飾りました。
I like decorating the Christmas tree. I put it beside our fireplace this year.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means deposit so the verb vocab version is to deposit or to entrust. You use this word when you are leaving something with someone else.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  In terms of places where you want to deposit your money, the last place on your list should be a zoo (あず). I mean seriously, you know the animals are just gonna munch up all your dolla bills.

sentences: え？今、いくら預けたって言った？
What? You deposited how much?

mnemonics.meaning: 診断 is a diagnosis. Make this into a verb, and you have to diagnose.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その医者が私に癌だと診断するほんの少し前に、ある看護婦さんが私の事をちらっと振り返って見たんです。
Right before the doctor diagnosed me with cancer, a nurse glanced over her shoulder at me.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means die out so the verb vocab version is to die out. You know that this one is "to die out" because you're up in the air (える), looking down at the dinosaurs, who are all dying out. Thank goodness you're up in the air, because the ground is all on fire.
mnemonics.reading: The reading can come from 絶つ, so as long as you know that word you know this one as well.

sentences: 電気や水が絶えることなく供給されているのはとてもありがたいことです。
We are very grateful for the uninterrupted supply of electricity and water.
悲しいけど、コウイチの命はここで絶えてしまったんだ。
It's sad, but Koichi's life has ended here.
トーフグメンバーが笑い茸と呼ばれるキノコを食べてからというもの、トーフグのオフィスでは、笑いが絶えることはない。
Since Tofugu members ate a mushroom called "panaeolus papilionaceus," there has been no end to the laughter in the Tofugu office.

mnemonics.meaning: If you illuminate the things I've done, I start to feel embarrassed. Please don't embarrass me. :(
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: The thing you feel the most embarrassed about is your 手 (て). It's all blue and scary looking.

sentences: えっ、有り難う。照れるなぁ。
Oh, thank you. I’m blushing!

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means float so the verb vocab version is to float.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from the reading you learned with the kanji. う!

sentences: スイカも南瓜も水に浮く。
Watermelons and pumpkins float in water.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means go beyond, the verb vocab version is to go beyond.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: To go beyond child (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

sentences: 日本語では、線路は続くよどこまでもの歌は、「線路は続くよどこまでも、野を越え山越え谷越え」という感じで始まります。
In Japanese, the song "I’ve Been Working on the Railroad" begins with, "the railroad continues forever, over fields, mountains, and valleys."

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means pain, and this verb is transitive, so it means to inflict pain. In other words, it's to injure something or to hurt someone. This verb focusses on the pain involved in an injury, so it can only be used for things that feel pain, like people and body parts.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned that reading with the word 痛い.

sentences: ゲームのやりすぎは目を痛める。
Playing games too much will hurt your eyes.
スリッパでフルマラソンをしたら足首を痛めた。
I ran a full marathon in slippers and injured my ankles.
母は今でもそのことで心を痛めている。
That incident is still breaking mom's heart.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means leak so the verb vocab version is to leak.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: Causing you to leak all over the floor (we're talking blood, here) is your friend Moe (も). If you know someone named Moe, imagine them doing this. If you don't, think of a famous Moe.

sentences: ねえ、なんかガスが漏れてる臭いがしない？
Hey, doesn’t it smell like leaking gas?

mnemonics.meaning: 並ぶ is when something is lining up. 並べる is when you're lining something up. In other words, 並べる is transitive. It means to line something up or to put something in order. You know this because when it comes to bears (べる), you have to line them up yourself, because they won't be doing it for you, that's for sure.
mnemonics.reading: The reading of the kanji is same as for 並ぶ, so if you know that you can figure out the reading for this one as well.

sentences: ボーリングのピンを並べるのにどうしてそんなに時間がかかったんですか。
Why did it take you so long to line up the bowling pins?

mnemonics.meaning: The kanji is boisterous. The verb version is to make noise or to be boisterous. Basically, you're being boisterous when you make a lot of noise, so that's where it comes from.
mnemonics.reading: When you go to make noise and be boisterous, you go to the local 沢 (さわ) swamp. It's an awesome place, and people don't complain about the noise.

sentences: 騒ぐな！死にたいのか？死にたくなけりゃ黙ってろ。
Don’t make so much noise! Do you wanna be killed? If not, just shut up.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. The kanji itself means approach, and the verb version is about making or letting something approach. That's why it means to move something close to, to pull something over, and also to contribute something.
mnemonics.reading: You want to move something close to you, but it's out of reach. The solution, of course, is to take out your trusty yo-yo (よ) and lasso that thing and pull it closer!

sentences: オモチャをカベに寄せた。
I moved the toys close to the wall.
車をワキに寄せて停めた。
I pulled the car over and parked.
このポッドキャストには色んなコメントが寄せられた。
All kinds of comments were posted on this podcast episode.

mnemonics.meaning: Pork bone ramen is tonkotsu ramen or, very logically indeed, pork bone ramen.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You know both of these readings, so you should be able to read this on your own.

sentences: ここは豚骨ラーメンの店です。
This place is a tonkotsu ramen restaurant.
この豚骨ラーメンを食べると懐かしい気持ちになるよ。
This pork bone ramen makes me feel nostalgic.
是非、九州に豚骨ラーメンを食べに来て下さい。
By all means, please come to Kyushu to eat tonkotsu ramen.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means play and the verb vocab version is to play.
mnemonics.reading: You want to play with everyone, but every once in a while someone doesn't want to play with you. You know what? That's okay. If someone doesn't want to play with you, they're the a**hole (あそ), not you.

sentences: 「宿題が済むまで、外で遊んじゃだめだからね。」「言われなくても分かってるよ！」
"You can’t play outdoors until you finish your homework." "You don’t have to tell me, I know!"

mnemonics.meaning: Can we prolong this period of time to a later date? I want to postpone, if possible.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: その洪水は広範囲に及ぶ被害を引き起こしたため、被害地域の高校は期末試験を一ヶ月延期した。
Since the flood caused widespread damage, the high schools in the area postponed their final exams for another month.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means prolong and this verb means to prolong.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you:  Do you mind if I go to prolong things? The answer? "No (の), I don't mind."

sentences: この写真を延ばして壁に飾りたいなと思ってるんです。
I want to enlarge this photo to put it on the wall.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means push so the verb vocab version is to push.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, actually!

sentences: すみません。今朝タイムカードを押し忘れちゃったんですが、どうすればいいですか？
I’m sorry, I forgot to punch my timecard this morning. What should I do?

mnemonics.meaning: 登録 is registration. Make that into a verb and you have to register.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 臓器提供者として登録をしたきっかけは何ですか。
What motivated you to register yourself as an organ donor?

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb.  The kanji itself means retreat, and this verb version is when you make something retreat. In other words, it means to repel something, to dismiss something, or to reject something. This is a transitive verb. That means it takes a direct object. You repel something, like bad luck. You reject something, like a proposal.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word has okurigana (hiragana attached to the kanji) you know that it's probably going to be the kun'yomi reading. You learned this with its intransitive pair verb 退く, but here's a mnemonic just in case: Remember the re-zoner? Well, to repel bad luck, she, re-zoned (しりぞ) the whole place. No bad luck allowed inside the zone.

sentences: このお守りには、災いを退ける力がある。
This charm has the power to repel misfortune.
議会は全ての議案を退けた。
The council dismissed all of the proposals.
日本にとってアメリカの意見を退けることは難しい。
It's hard for Japan to reject the opinions of the U.S.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means steal, so the verb vocab version is to steal.
mnemonics.reading: What are you going to steal? How about a noose (ぬす)? Wait, why are you stealing a noose? That sounds like trouble to me...

sentences: あいつは絶対に中途半端なことはしない奴だから、3106カラットのダイヤモンドを盗むための壮大な計画を立てているに違いない。
He’s the kind of guy who never does something halfway, so he must have a magnificent plan to steal the 3106 carat diamond.

mnemonics.meaning: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means photograph. When you make that into a verb, you are doing a photograph, aka making it become to take a picture. It can also be to film as well. Really anything to do with a camera.
mnemonics.reading: Think of the reading like you do the meaning to take a photograph. You "take" all these things, and how do you say "to take" in Japanese? It's 取る, aka とる, which happens to be the same reading!

sentences: 子供の幼稚園の卒園式で記念写真をたくさん撮りました。
I took a lot of photos at my kid's kindergarten graduation ceremony.
マイケルは自撮りを上手に撮る方法について詳しく知っているはずです。
Michael should know details about how to take selfies well.
写真を撮るために、彼は野球帽を後ろ向きに被り直した。
He put his baseball cap on backwards to take the picture.

mnemonics.meaning: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means wet or damp, so the verb version is to wet or to dampen something.
mnemonics.reading: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

sentences: 髪をよく濡らしてから、シャンプーをするといいですよ。
It's good to wet your hair before shampooing.
大事なUSBなので、コーヒーや水で濡らさないで下さいね。
This USB is important, so please be careful not to get it wet with coffee or water.
先輩にフラれてから、毎日涙で枕を濡らしています。
Since I was dumped by my senpai, I've been soaking my pillow with tears.

mnemonics.meaning: 研修 is a training or study of some kind. If it's in your current life (生) that you are doing the training, then you are a trainee. This is a lot like how a student is in the status of "study life."
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The reading from 研修 should also help you too.

sentences: こちらが、新しい研修生の三浦くんです。
This is the new trainee, Miura.

mnemonics.meaning: When you associate with a certain lineage, you trace yourself back with a group of people. This group of people is your tribe, your lineage, your group.
mnemonics.reading: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji, probably because this word gets stuck onto other things to describe tribes and groups.

sentences: 私、アキバ系のオタッキーな男性に何故か魅力を感じるんだよね。
Somehow I’m attracted to Akihabara style, nerdy men.

mnemonics.meaning: A floating world painting is what you call an ukiyo-e woodblock print in Japan. The "floating world" refers to an evanescent world that is impermanent (floating), just as beauty and entertainment is. Back in the day, this type of art was made into woodblock prints and paintings. Unfortunately, we don't have a name for these in English because they're so unique and special, but they come up more than you'd think, so get used to ukiyo-e!
mnemonics.reading: The readings don't really line up perfectly, but they're close (although mixed in terms of what has what reading). Take a look at the word and break everything down. 浮 takes the kun'yomi うき (from 浮く), 世 also takes the kun'yomi よ, and then 絵 takes the on'yomi え. Put that all together and you have うきよえ! Or if you already know the word ukiyo-e, that works too!

sentences: その浮世絵についてお話をしませんか？
Why don’t we talk about the ukiyo-e?

mnemonics.meaning: Not yet marriage? You haven't been married. You're unmarried.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 結局、未婚の女性ではないという真実を彼に話すはめになりました。
In the end I told him the truth that I’m not an unmarried woman.

mnemonics.meaning: Things that are not pleasant are unpleasant or uncomfortable.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: 上司の不快なジョークに笑いたくもないのに笑っている自分が嫌いです。
I don’t want to laugh at my boss’s unpleasant jokes and I hate myself when I do.

mnemonics.meaning: Something that is not suitable is unsuitable and inappropriate.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: この職が私にとって適不適かを考えているんですが、まだ答えは出ていません。
I’ve been thinking about whether this job suits me or not, but I haven’t found the answer yet.

mnemonics.meaning: Something is reverse, that much you know. The さま comes from 様, which could mean manner. So, something that is in a "reverse manner," is something that is upside down.
mnemonics.reading: The reading comes from 逆らう and 様, put together. A bit of an upside down reading if I do say so myself, but you do what you gotta do.

sentences: どうして蝶々を逆さまに描いたの？
Why did you draw the butterfly upside down?

mnemonics.meaning: If you view and look at something, you are viewing that thing, or seeing it.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: トーフグテレビの撮影現場を観覧しました。
I watched the TofuguTV shooting.

mnemonics.meaning: A leak of water is a water leakage.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well.

sentences: どんなに値段が高くても、その漏水検出器を買うべきだと思います。
No matter how expensive it is, we should buy the water leakage sensor.

mnemonics.meaning: You put one cup of liquid... no, one full cup of liquid spirit into what you're doing. None of this half-cup garbage. A full one. That means you're going at it with all one's might.
mnemonics.reading: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. If you know the readings of your kanji you'll know how to read this as well. Will help if you've seen 一杯 before.

sentences: 今は古い写真を捨てることが私にできる精一杯です。
Getting rid of old pictures is the best I can do for now.
